Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 20 September 1979

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-Petition s have been lodged for

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation as follows and copies will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the appropriate Ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Peution

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of this country does not have the support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the change is causing and will continue to cause,

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread, serious and costly problems;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the compulsory tactics being used to force the change

Speaker: NA
Text: are a violation of all domestic principles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the people are free to utilise whichever system they prefer

Speaker: NA
Text: and so enable the return to imperial weights and measures

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever the people so desire;

Speaker: NA
Text: That weather reporting be as it was prior to the passing of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Metric Conversion Act;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Australian Government take urgent steps to

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the traditional mile units to be restored to our

Speaker: NA
Text: highways;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Australian Government request the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments to procure that the imperial and metric sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems be taught together in schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Lynch, Mr Aldred, Mr Burns, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Goodluck, Mr Jarman, Mr Macphee and Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Street.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dismay at the reduction in the total expenditure on edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation proposed for 1980 and in particular to Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government School bear the burden

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent while non-Government school will receive an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of 3.4 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: We call on the Government to again examine the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals as set out in the guidelines for Education expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980 and to immediatelyrestoreand increase substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: in real terms the allocation of funds for education expendiTo

Speaker: NA
Text: ture in 1980 to Government schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Anthony, Mr Armitage, Mr Dobie, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard, Mr Les Johnson, Mr Sainsbury and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West

Speaker: NA
Text: National Women's Advisory Council

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS of Representatives assembled: The Petition of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been democratically elected by the women ofAustralia;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council is not rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: Metric System resentative ofthe women of Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory CouncU is a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: of criminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: CouncU imposed on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council be

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary representatives without intervention and interference by

Speaker: NA
Text: an unrepresentative 'Advisory CouncU'.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Braithwaite, Mr Fisher, Mr Lucock and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Martyr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound wUl ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Radio Licence Fees

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the unprecedented SO per cent increase in fees for

Speaker: NA
Text: mobile ship-to-shore boat radio licences and the 100 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in fees for life saving ship station radio licences is

Speaker: NA
Text: unjustified and discriminatory

Speaker: NA
Text: disincentive for boat owners to obtain such radios thereby

Speaker: NA
Text: imperilling safety at sea while CB operators in motor ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles still pay only $25 for their licence and can have up to

Speaker: NA
Text: five radios on the one licence for unlimited use.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petiuoners call on the government to reduce fees for

Speaker: NA
Text: these licences and to revise the regulations concerning boat

Speaker: NA
Text: radios.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr John Brown, Mr Humphreys and Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: James.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sale of Publicly Owned Enterprises

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of undersigned citizens of AustraUa respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a definite limit to the quantity of Australia's min-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly ourresourcesshould be managed and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped under Australian ownership and control.

Speaker: NA
Text: Publicly owned trading enterprises and corporations have

Speaker: NA
Text: been established and operated for the benefit of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: since Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Trans

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Airlines, Housing Loans Insurance Corporation,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat Board, were all designed to operate to the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Nation as a whole under public ownership.

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions) Act The Fraser government's irresponsible proposals to sell off

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation's interest in the Ranger Uranium Mine, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, and to dispose of

Speaker: NA
Text: successful statutory corporations such as Trans

Speaker: NA
Text: Airlines, would be contrary to the Nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: willrejectoutright proposals of the Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: government to sell the Ranger Uranium Mine, the Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Corporation and Trans Australia Airlines.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Armitage and Mr Morris.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That a grave threat to the life ofrefugeesfrom the various

Speaker: NA
Text: States of Indo-China arises from the policies of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: That, as a result of these policies, many thousands of ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: ugees arefleeingtheir homes and risking starvation and

Speaker: NA
Text: drowning. Because of the failure of the rich nations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world to provide more than token assistance, theresourcesof

Speaker: NA
Text: the nations of firstrefuge,especially Malaysia and Thailand,

Speaker: NA
Text: are being stretched beyond reasonable limits.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a wealthy nation within the region most affected,

Speaker: NA
Text: is able to play a major part in the rescue as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: resettlement of these refugees.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be possible for Australia to:

Speaker: NA
Text: establish and maintain on the Australian mainland

Speaker: NA
Text: basic transit camps for the housing and processing of

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000refugeeseach year;

Speaker: NA
Text: because the increases act as a

Speaker: NA
Text: mobilise the Defence Force to search for, rescue and

Speaker: NA
Text: transport to Australia those refugees who have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to leave the Indo-China States;

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the offer of those church groups which propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: resettle some thousands ofrefugeesin Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The adoption of such a humane policy would have a

Speaker: NA
Text: marked effect on Australia's standing within the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Fisher and Mr Jarman.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Radio Licence Fees

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representadves in ParUament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: peution ofthe undersigned citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we oppose the increase in Radio Licence Fees on

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Radios for the following reasons:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Radios are an essential pan of safety equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Marine radio users save the government millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in search and rescue.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Increased Ucences will deter the boating fraternity

Speaker: NA
Text: from purchasing and using radios for their own, and

Speaker: NA
Text: others safety.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also oppose the Radio Regulation that allows and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courages the use of CB radios in boats for the following

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The difficulties and delays involved in obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: positive identification

Speaker: NA
Text: message.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The break down in communication between marine

Speaker: NA
Text: radio bases and boats, and boats using CB radio that

Speaker: NA
Text: are in trouble.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Costs for search andrescuewill esculate due to these

Speaker: NA
Text: delays.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Safety standards will be lowered, Sea Rescue Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bership will decline,

Speaker: NA
Text: ing members under less efficient radio

Speaker: NA
Text: communication.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petiuoners therefore humbly pray the government

Speaker: NA
Text: willreconsiderthe licence fee and also consider a reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: for pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also humbly pray that the regulation allowing the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: CB radio in Marine situations be rescinded.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Braithwaite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Speaker and the House of Representatives in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spectfully showeth that the very survival of mankind is at

Speaker: NA
Text: stake, with the stockpile of nuclear weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: person on earth 24 times over and with conventional arms of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing sophistication having enough destructive power

Speaker: NA
Text: to destroy most life on earth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Noting that, while millions starve, expenditure on the

Speaker: NA
Text: arms race is $1000 milUon per day for the World and $7

Speaker: NA
Text: million per day for AustraUa; and noting that the UN Chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren's Fund (UNICEF) has listed 'peace and disarmament

Speaker: NA
Text: as a theme for the International Year of the Child; and

Speaker: NA
Text: further noting that a reduction in expenditure on arms could

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute in both developed

Speaker: NA
Text: eradication of hunger and disease and to the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: more adequate housing, education, health services, econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic security and social welfare for all people:

Speaker: NA
Text: In the interests of children in Australia and around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world,-particularly in developing countries, and as a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of highest priority during the International Year of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ChUd,

Speaker: NA
Text: We call upon the AustraUan Government to give poUtical

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership both nationally and internationally in working

Speaker: NA
Text: towards

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) general and complete disarmament under effective

Speaker: NA
Text: international control;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) the establishment of the Pacific and Indian Oceans as

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear-free zones; and

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) the disbanding of all nuclear bases.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound wUl ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Dr Everingham.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Red Army Choir

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Red Army Choir is a miUtary propaganda unit

Speaker: NA
Text: Disarmament glorifying the Soviet regime which is still hostile to the demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic way of life. The Red Army is the main instrument in

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping formally free people under subjugation, and its

Speaker: NA
Text: presence enables blatant violations of Human Rights to be

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrated. The support, therefore, of such instruments of a

Speaker: NA
Text: totalitarian regime can only harm the development of free

Speaker: NA
Text: able to kill every and liberal thought under it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners humbly pray that the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment assert its support for the aspirations of subjugated

Speaker: NA
Text: people by denying entry into this country to the Red Army

Speaker: NA
Text: Choir.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth that inflation is having a catastrophic

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on the living standards of the aged. To overcome this

Speaker: NA
Text: the Retired Persons' Rights Association recommend that:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The Government is called upon to announce a timeta-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble for abolition of the income test, starting in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) By restoring to the maximum rate the test free

Speaker: NA
Text: pension paid to all over 70 years of age.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by conceding a test free pension (as paid to all

Speaker: NA
Text: over 70} to all over 69 years of age, by the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1979-80 year.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Pending abolition of the income test, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is called upon, in the 1979 Budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: fa) To restore half-yearly indexation of pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) to increase the qualifying 'other incomes', both

Speaker: NA
Text: for the full pension and the health benefit card,

Speaker: NA
Text: the amounts necessary to compensate for C.P.I,

Speaker: NA
Text: increases since the present amounts were fixed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that action be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to improve social security benefits forretiredpersons.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr MACKenzie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petiuon of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, as it is clear that unemployment is a long term prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem in Australia, the Government should extend to the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed the same assistance as is given to any other disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged member of the community. There is an urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: need to alleviate the financial hardship and emotional stress

Speaker: NA
Text: that the unemployed are suffering.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. That the Government adopt positive policies to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment,

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. That the basic Unemployment Benefit be raised to at

Speaker: NA
Text: least the level of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fessor Henderson,

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. In line with other Social Service additional income

Speaker: NA
Text: awards, and in order to encourage work creation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes and the fostering

Speaker: NA
Text: that the $6 per week additional income limit be raised

Speaker: NA
Text: to at least $20 per week.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. That the financial penalities above the earning of $20

Speaker: NA
Text: per week, assessed on a monthly basis, be calculated at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same rate as other Social Security benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. That the Commonwealth grant subsidies to state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments so that the unemployed can be granted

Speaker: NA
Text: transport concessions in order that they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: penalised in job seeking.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. That pharmaceutical and medical concessions be

Speaker: NA
Text: granted to the unemployed equivalent to those

Speaker: NA
Text: received by other Social Service beneficiaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Leo MCLeay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petiuon received.

Text: nographic or obscene material depicting children;

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. To make specifically illegal the importation, publi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, distribution and sale of such pornographic

Speaker: NA
Text: child-abuse material in any form whatsoever such as

Speaker: NA
Text: magazines, novels, papers or films;

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. To take immediate police action to confiscate and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: stroy all child pornography in Australia and urgent ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriate legal action against all those involved or

Speaker: NA
Text: profiting from this sordid exploitation of children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able House will protect all children and immediately pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: hibit pornographic child-abuse materials, publications or

Speaker: NA
Text: films.

Speaker: NA
Text: of initiative and self respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: Health of Aboriginal Children

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That there are Australian Aboriginal children living under

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of inadequate nutrition in a background of poor

Speaker: NA
Text: housing, hygiene, and' overcrowding that amounts to 'a

Speaker: NA
Text: Third World enclave in the midst of affluence' (see also the

Speaker: NA
Text: Report from the House of Representatives Standing Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on Aboriginal Affairs "Aboriginal Health" 1979);

Speaker: NA
Text: That such a state of affairs is intolerable in our country;

Speaker: NA
Text: That only an effort on an unprecedented scale could create

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions that would give these children therightsset out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child.,

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will make generous funding available for the specific

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of:

Speaker: NA
Text: Making a real improvement in the health, housing, edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and welfare of the Aboriginal people,

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so with due regard for the needs, hopes and aspir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations ofthe Aboriginal people themselves;

Speaker: NA
Text: Providing increased help, encouragement and opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for Aboriginal people to train as nursing aides and in other

Speaker: NA
Text: paramedical roles, and as fully qualified nurses, doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: social workers;

Speaker: NA
Text: Providing increased health education for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people in ways that are acceptable to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Ruddock.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representadves in Parliament assembled. The peution of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That restoradon of provisions of the Social Security Act

Speaker: NA
Text: that applied prior to the 1978-79

Speaker: NA
Text: offset the rising cost of goods and services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thereasonadvanced by the Government for yearly pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments 'that the lower level of inflation made twice-yearly

Speaker: NA
Text: payments inappropriate' is not valid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Great injury will be caused to 920,000 aged, invalid,

Speaker: NA
Text: widows and supporting parents, who rely solely on the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion or whose income, other than the pension, is $6 or less

Speaker: NA
Text: per week. Once-a-year payments strike a cruel blow to their

Speaker: NA
Text: expectation and make a mockery of a solemn election

Speaker: NA
Text: pledge.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, your petiuoners call upon their legislators

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Restore twice-yearly pension payments in the Autumn

Speaker: NA
Text: session.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Raise pensions and unemployed benefits above the

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty level to 30 per cent of A.W.E.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petiuoners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Shipton.

Speaker: NA
Text: UNEMPLOYMENT

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide)-I give notice

Speaker: NA
Text: that on the next day of sitting I shall move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House, recognising that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) For persons aged 35 years and over who show up in

Speaker: NA
Text: the June labour force survey, the average period of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment is 47 weeks;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) For persons aged 45 to 54 the average period of un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment is 44 weeks; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) For persons 35 to 45 the average duration of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment is 34 weeks;

Speaker: NA
Text: and asserting that the lengthening period of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment for family heads hasrepercussionsin social

Speaker: NA
Text: costs for which Australia will pay over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: ation, is ofthe opinion that the Federal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should providefinancialassistance to State and local

Speaker: NA
Text: government for adult job creation, training and

Speaker: NA
Text: retraining schemes.

Text: TELECO M AUSTRALIA AND

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA POST

Speaker: Mr LUCOCK
Text: Lyne)-I give notice that at the

Speaker: NA
Text: next sitting I shall move:

Text: Telecom Australia and Australia Post should be amended to

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: SPECIAL YOUTH EMPLOYMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: TRAINING PROGRAM

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget is of vital concern to

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: I refer the Minister for Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Youth Affairs to his statements of

Speaker: NA
Text: December last year and January of this year

Speaker: NA
Text: when he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Get off your tails and start hunting for jobs because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is not going to hand them to you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: To make work and work generating initiatives fashionable

Speaker: NA
Text: to them, a real impact will have to be made on the cool

Speaker: NA
Text: to: young to whom dole bludging is a bit of a joke rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: something to be overcome if humanly possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is this the philosophy behind and the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Government's decision to slash the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget appropriation for the Special Youth Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment Training Program by $5 5m or 69 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent?

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: A s the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: knows, the funding in this year's Budget for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Youth Employment Training Program

Speaker: NA
Text: flows from two decisions made last year. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of Motion decision was made in the Budget of 1978 when

Speaker: NA
Text: the period of training was reduced from six

Speaker: NA
Text: months to 17 weeks and the amount of rebate,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, subsidies to employers, was reduced from

Speaker: NA
Text: $64 to $45 per week. In December 1978 the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government decided that in order to cut out em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployer abuse of the Special Youth Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Training Program it would review the eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria so that the young unemployed people

Speaker: NA
Text: who would benefit from the program would be

Speaker: NA
Text: those who would not meet the normal employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment requirements of an employer. These people

Speaker: NA
Text: might be termed the hard core unemployed, that

Speaker: NA
Text: generis, those young people who, because of a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: educational competence or some other attri-

Speaker: NA
Text: butes, find it very difficult in a tight labour mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket to obtain employment. We thought- I think

Speaker: NA
Text: quite properly-tha t the public money which we

Speaker: NA
Text: were putting into this program should be put to

Speaker: NA
Text: the most effective use possible. We do not be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of Motion lieve, as the Australian Council of Trade Unions

Speaker: NA
Text: does not believe, that the Government should be

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a direct wage subsidy to employers in

Speaker: NA
Text: those circumstances. Therefore we limited the

Speaker: NA
Text: target group of young people to the speciaUy

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged in the current labour market.

Speaker: NA
Text: From those two decisions in August 1978 and

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1978 flowed inevitable funding

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences which appear in this year's Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: in which we have provided enough funds for the

Speaker: NA
Text: anticipated demand by employers and the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of this particular young unemployed group. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course the other side of our funding, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is not prepared to acknowledge, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the massive increase in the funds that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: making available to assist apprentices through

Speaker: NA
Text: our Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-

Speaker: NA
Text: time Training Scheme. We have almost doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: to $55m the amount of money that we are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding to employers to engage more apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we are in a time of economic recovery and

Speaker: NA
Text: when there is increasing demand by industry for

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled workers and a demand by young people

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain a skill, I think one

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the priority of the Government in putting

Speaker: NA
Text: $55m towards apprenticeship support.

Speaker: NA
Text: NAVY PATROL BOATS

Speaker: Mr DEAN
Text: Ca n the Minister for Defence in-

Speaker: NA
Text: form the House on progress with construction of

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 new patrol boats for the Navy which are

Speaker: NA
Text: being built in nonh Queensland? Is the project

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeding satisfactorily? Will the lead ship question.

Speaker: NA
Text: being constructed in the United Kingdom be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered to the Navy on time?

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Text: Th e lead ship HMAS Fremanwhat

Speaker: NA
Text: tle, which is being constructed in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom by Brooke Marine Ltd, was due to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter Australian waters towards the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: year. I regret to inform the honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man and the House that she will not now arrive

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australian waters until February next year. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall explain briefly to the House the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: that. Trials have indicated that the lead ship

Speaker: NA
Text: overweight by approximately 20 tonnes. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: it clear also that the Australian Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian taxpayer, is completely protected by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of an indemnity. The honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: will appreciate that North Queensland Engin55,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: eers and Agents Pty Ltd, which is building the

Speaker: NA
Text: follow-on boats in Cairns in north Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so following the specifications prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: Brooke Marine. As a consequence of that, boats

Speaker: NA
Text: 2,3 and possibly 4 may be overweight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can assure the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: House that trials are continuing to see in what

Speaker: NA
Text: manner and form the overweight can be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced. Present trials indicate that the overexisted

Speaker: NA
Text: weight has been caused by oversized hull

Speaker: NA
Text: plating, hull fitting and some equipment. I am taxpayer.

Speaker: NA
Text: informed on technical and professional advice

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are good grounds for optimism that

Speaker: NA
Text: the overweight problem will be substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced in relation to the boats to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: adverted. As to the other boats which will follow

Speaker: NA
Text: on, there will be no problem in existence.

Speaker: NA
Text: UNEMPLOYMENT

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I direct my question to the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that Australia has nearly the highest rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment in the Organisation for

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Co-operation and Development coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries? Is it also a fact that 60 per cent of our un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed are under the age of 25 years? Is it also

Speaker: NA
Text: a fact that Italy is the only other country in the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD where the unemployment rate has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: above the 60 per centfigure?Why has Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: performed so poorly in providing jobs for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in comparison with the rest of the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: can see the purpose oped world?

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e basic reason that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the present unemployment problem is because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic pohcies pursued by the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration in the years 1974 to 1975.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Minister will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume his seat. I ask honourable members to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main silent while the Minister is answering the

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: M y simple statement brought

Speaker: NA
Text: raucous laughter from the Opposition. I wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: these statistics will bring forth from Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition members. Between May 1974 and May

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975 under the Whitlam Labor Government full

Speaker: NA
Text: this time unemployment increased by 138,700.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: Yo u have had four years.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: for member for Batman asked a question. The Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: is ister is now answering it. I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Batman remain silent

Speaker: NA
Text: the while the answer is being given.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: During that period, May 1974 to

Speaker: NA
Text: May 1975, civUian employment decreased by

Speaker: NA
Text: It decreased because private employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, that is, employment in the private sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: is decreased by a massive 155,000. That simply

Speaker: NA
Text: by means that in one year under the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration 155,000 jobs were destroyed as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the economic policies ofthe day. During

Speaker: NA
Text: and the that same period government employment

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by nearly 100,000. In simple economic

Speaker: NA
Text: terms, that means that 155,000 jobs, which

Speaker: NA
Text: at no cost to the taxpayer, were replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: by 100,000 jobs which were financed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Is there any reason not to understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party policies of today under the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, like those of the Whidam

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration, must depend upon high taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas our economic policies are dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon creating the condiuons whereby we will get

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth in the private sector and,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the private sector, real jobs that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: of lasting benefit to the community? The effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness of our policies is shown by the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 12 months 64,400 additional jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: have been created in the work force, the bulk of

Speaker: NA
Text: which are in the private sector. This, we know, is

Speaker: NA
Text: where we will get increasing employment

Speaker: NA
Text: growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other factor is that Australia came late

Speaker: NA
Text: into an era of high youth unemployment conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent upon economic policies the results of

Speaker: NA
Text: which appeared from 1974 to 1975. What we

Speaker: NA
Text: have done as a government, since we came into

Speaker: NA
Text: office in late 1975, is to embark upon a massive

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of our manpower and training

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. Since we have come into office we

Speaker: NA
Text: have invested over $400m in these programs

Speaker: NA
Text: which has assisted over 400,000 young and old

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. This financial year, we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: mvesting $ 132.2m in our manpower and training

Speaker: NA
Text: programs which will assist 210,000 people. In

Speaker: NA
Text: our National Employment and Training Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: the number supported will be 31,000; in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Program for Unemployed Youth,

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000; in the Special Youth Employment Train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Program, 49,000; in our Commonwealth Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate for Apprentice Full-time Training Program,

Speaker: NA
Text: 85,000; and in our Community Youth Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme Programs, 40,000-a total of 210,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians supported by government money

Speaker: NA
Text: which we are prepared to invest in their future.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION: INDEPENDENT ADVISORY

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEE

Speaker: Mr SHACK
Text: In the past the Treasurer has

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed himself broadly in favour of an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent advisory committee on taxation in

Speaker: NA
Text: line with the Asprey Review Committee rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendation. Is the Treasurer able to inform

Text: the House whether he has further considered this

Text: proposal?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I t is true, as the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Tangney says, that I have com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented favourably on a recommendation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asprey report that an independent advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: committee on taxation be established. I can tell

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member and the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has approved a recommendation of

Speaker: NA
Text: mine that such a committee be established. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that it will make a valuable contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice on taxadon matters currently coming

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government. The committee will comp-

Speaker: NA
Text: lement that advice and not compete with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am presently giving consideration to the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel who might be invited to serve on the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee and who might be interested in serving on

Text: the committee, and I have sought the views of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of professional and other organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: as to suitable people. I hope within a matter of a

Text: few weeks to be able to announce both the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel of the committee and the precise terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: reference of the committee. I see this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: committee as playing a very valuable role, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in terms of giving alternative technical

Speaker: NA
Text: advice to the Government on what is undoubt-

Speaker: NA
Text: edly an act of this Parliament of continuing rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evance to everybody.

Text: I ask the Minister for

Text: by January 1980 only four out of every 100

Speaker: NA
Text: officially registered unemployed people will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive training assistance? Is it a fact that last

Speaker: NA
Text: August the comparable figure was 13 out of

Speaker: NA
Text: every 100? Is it also a fact that the expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: $140m on the National Employment and Train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing System, the Community Youth Suppon

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme, the Commonwealth Rebate for Ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentice Full-time Training scheme and the Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation Program for Unemployed Youth rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents 0.12 per cent of the gross national

Speaker: NA
Text: product, while Canada and the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America spend six times that amount and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweden spends 20timesthat amount? Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: all the other member countries of the Organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation for Economic Co-operation and Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment out of step with Australia?

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: I f the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: gives me more particulars ofthe statistics that he

Speaker: NA
Text: produces from other countries, I will take his

Text: question on notice and give him a detailed

Text: answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: HOME BUILDING COSTS

Speaker: Mr BRADFIELD
Text: I s the Mimster for Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Construction aware of recent statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: and Press reports which indicate that home

Speaker: NA
Text: building costs have risen, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: months of July and August of this year? Could

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister identify the base causes of these

Speaker: NA
Text: rises? Could he also indicate whether these in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases mean that homes will become more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for home buyers to obtain in the future?

Speaker: Mr GROOM
Text: I am pleased that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Barton has raised this subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this week the Austrahan Bureau of Stat-

Speaker: NA
Text: istics released its figures on increases in home

Speaker: NA
Text: building material prices in Australia. The figures

Speaker: NA
Text: show that in the month of August an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.4 per cent occurred. This compares with an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the month of July of 1.3 per cent. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a slight increase of 0.1 per cent over

Speaker: NA
Text: previous month'sfigure.It is true that the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last couple of months were higher than

Speaker: NA
Text: thefiguresfor a number of previous months. The

Speaker: NA
Text: increase has been influenced by higher prices for

Speaker: NA
Text: clay bricks, for timber-both hardwood and

Speaker: NA
Text: softwood-an d for steel and cement products.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member asks why the increases

Speaker: NA
Text: have occurred. It is always difficult to pinpoint

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for increases of these kinds in these sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of indices. The figures for several months were

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely low and eventually it was obvious that

Speaker: NA
Text: some upward readjustment would occur. That

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a factor in the latest increases. Also, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen increases in petroleum and chemical

Speaker: NA
Text: prices which obviously feed through eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: to building material costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite the moderate increases which have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken place in the last two months, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment certainly has a very good record in contain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing costs in the building sector. The house build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing materials index has declined in each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: years that this Government has been in office. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that that is a very significant achievement

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed. As all honourable members on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the House will know, by comparison,

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of all kinds soared during the period of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Administradon, and that included build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing costs. I give an example: In the year ending

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1979 this Government achieved afigureof

Speaker: NA
Text: 9.6 per cent and this compares with a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: figure of 22.9 per cent in the 12-month period to

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of January 1975. For the latest 12-month

Speaker: NA
Text: period, including August, the figure is 10.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. This Government is now achieving inflauon

Speaker: NA
Text: figures about half, or less than half, of what

Speaker: NA
Text: were during the period for which the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was in office. For non-residential

Speaker: NA
Text: building material costs, thefigurefor August was

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.2 per cent. When the present Opposition was in

Speaker: NA
Text: government we sawfigurestwo and three times

Speaker: NA
Text: that percentage. If we look back to April 1974 we

Speaker: NA
Text: see afigurefor one month of 4.1 per cent, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with 1.2 per cent for August 1979. We saw

Speaker: NA
Text: a yearly increase of 26 per cent at about that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. Thefiguresduring that period were very

Speaker: NA
Text: high indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not possible to assess accurately the

Speaker: NA
Text: flow-on effect on the cost of new houses resulting

Speaker: NA
Text: from these price increases, but one point that

Speaker: NA
Text: must be made is that the housing industry de-

Text: UNEMPLOYMENT: MIGRANT INTAKE

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment and Youth Affairs: Is it a fact that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Text: W e are clever today, are we not?

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the MANS study has been very

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough both in its activities and its public

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipation and is studying all the questons rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant to coming to a decision about and a con-

Text: clusion as to what will be the future airport

Speaker: NA
Text: of Sydney. I look forward to receiving the report

Speaker: NA
Text: on 14 December. I also look forward to consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tations with my colleague, the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Planning and Environment, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Landa, so that the two Governments can settle

Speaker: NA

Text: take away all of the concerns of the people of

Text: ment so that the future needs of Sydney are prop-

Text: erly planned. I hope that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: AIR POLLUTION

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I s the Minister for Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that despite the obvious advantages of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas and diesel fuel in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributing to the quality of air in the inner city

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, and in particular in the City of Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the New South Wales Government on 27

Speaker: NA
Text: July gazetted a regulation under the Clean Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1961 that requires motor vehicle manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turers to proceed to the costly, and in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: pollution control, unsatisfactory implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: of phase 3 of Australian Design Rule 27A? Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, will the Minister inform the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: the approximate number of State Government

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles at present utilising the cleaner fuel LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: import into his ques- or diesel?

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Text: I shall take the last part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question first. No, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to give him that information. I will see i f i

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain it from the New South Wales Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and provide it for him. It is a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales Government has passed regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations to gazette something equivalent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: third stage of Australian Design Rule 27A. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will have the effect of increasing the fuel con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of motor cars by up to 5 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, it is quite regrettable that the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government has gone against the rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendation accepted by the majority of the

Speaker: NA
Text: States in the Commonwealth at the last Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Transport Advisory Council meeting on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. I am convinced, as are other State

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers for Transport, that there are more cost

Speaker: NA
Text: effective ways of improving the current pollution

Speaker: NA
Text: control situation. These include more stringent

Speaker: NA
Text: parevaporative hydrocarbon controls at minimal

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. Also they provide an energy saving, over-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming in-service problems with present vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to improve emission and fuel performance with

Speaker: NA
Text: proper attention to other sources of hydro-

Speaker: NA
Text: carbons. I think New South Wales has made a

Speaker: NA
Text: serious mistake in implementing these regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations. It will be a costly mistake in terms of fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous South Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately followed the party line taken by

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales in this matter. I am hopeful

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a result of discussions with the new Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Transport, he might be able to convince

Speaker: NA
Text: his Government of the wisdom of moving back

Speaker: NA
Text: from the position adopted by his predecessor. I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to those discussions at an early date

Speaker: NA
Text: because I think the new South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government will take a more flexible attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: when compared with the dogmatic approach

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the previous Administration. The

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting thing about Sydney is that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: informed that there was a marginal improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the air quality between 1976 and 1977.

Speaker: NA
Text: This information comes as a result of monitoring

Speaker: NA
Text: the air quality of Sydney. Therefore, it seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that New South Wales is quite unwise to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose this further cost on the motor car user when

Speaker: NA
Text: such doubtful benefits-i f any at all-ar e to be

Speaker: NA
Text: gained by its action.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: Honourable require

Speaker: NA
Text: members may recall that the interim report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee was tabled in May 1977. This

Speaker: NA
Text: independent committee was appointed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in September 1976 to advise on the lition

Speaker: NA
Text: operation, conservation and longer term develstables.

Speaker: NA
Text: opment of the four official residences of the posal

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government-Governmen t vided

Speaker: NA
Text: House and the Lodge in Canberra and Admirvolve

Speaker: NA
Text: alty House and Kirribilli House in Sydney. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman of the Committee was Mr Andrew it

Speaker: NA
Text: Grimwade. Its other members were Mr Guilford

Speaker: NA
Text: Bell, Dame Helen Blaxland, the Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: James Cope, and Mrs Ruth Gullett. I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: thank Mr Grimwade and all the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee for their work which had involved,

Speaker: NA
Text: I know, a considerable sacrifice of their time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The four establishments are official residences

Speaker: NA
Text: serving the ongoing needs of government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings have already been declared part of

Speaker: NA
Text: National Estate and are well worthwhile

Speaker: NA
Text: preserving as symbolic items in our country's his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory and cultural heritage. Already these four

Speaker: NA
Text: residences contain significant items

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian which includes pieces of early Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: furniture and works of art. For example, a short

Speaker: NA
Text: while ago a notable portrait of Mr Watson, the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Australian Labor Party Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: came into the possession of the Australiana Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: and that now hangs in the Lodge. The report recits

Speaker: NA
Text: ommends that there be continuing machinery in

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of a permanent advisory trust to be

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for advice to the Government on the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation, development and efficient operpleased

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of the buildings and grounds of the official

Speaker: NA
Text: establishments. The Government agrees that

Speaker: NA
Text: such continuing machinery is necessary and

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a permanent body to be known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Official Establishments Trust.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of the other recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee have been accepted. Included in

Text: of which of two sites is the more appropriate for a

Text: possible new Prime Ministerial residence which

Text: one day may be necessary. So that the second site

Text: may be released for other purposes, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has asked the new Trust to advise as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible which of the two sites is the more sui-

Speaker: NA
Text: table. I emphasise that no decision has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to build a new Prime Ministerial residence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present Lodge is serving its function well

Speaker: NA
Text: is expected to continue to do so for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: A few of the Committee's recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: will be referred to the permanent body for

Speaker: NA
Text: further consideration. These cover suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: working arrangements in the financial area and

Speaker: NA
Text: further consideration before decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: are reached. The Government has decided not to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept recommendations that future planning for

Text: Government House be based on eventual demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: of existing structures other than the historic

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor does it accept at this time the pro-

Text: that official establishment facilities be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: in Melbourne. Both proposals would in-

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure outlay wliich the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: sees as inconsistent with the general restraint that

Text: is currently maintaining on its spending. Im-

Text: recommendations accepted, those rejected and

Speaker: NA
Text: those to be referred to the new permanent body.

Speaker: NA
Text: the gentleman seeking to table the recommendations

Text: or to have them incorporated in Hansard?.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND

Speaker: NA
Text: CONSERVATION: REPORT ON

Speaker: NA
Text: OFF-ROAD VEHICLES

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr GROOM
Text: Braddon-Minister for Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Construction)-b y leave-Fo r the infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation of honourable members I wish to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement on action taken so far by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the recommendations on the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment and Conservation following that

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's inquiry into off-road vehicles. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has taken a number of initiatives as

Speaker: NA
Text: a consequence of recommendations arising from

Speaker: NA
Text: the mquiry into off-road vehicles. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House of these. This is in keeping with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's policy that Ministers should

Speaker: NA
Text: make a statement on action stemming from re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports of parliamentary committees.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House of Representatives Standing Comvolved

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on Environment and Conservation

Speaker: NA
Text: solved in September 1975 to inquire into the

Speaker: NA
Text: pact of off-road vehicles on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: environment. The Committee's report was

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled in the House in March 1977. The major

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for managing off-road, or

Speaker: NA
Text: reation, vehicles is vested in the State governimported.

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. Recommendations in this report refer

Speaker: NA
Text: only to action by the Commonwealth, indepenand

Speaker: NA
Text: dently or in conjunction with the States and

Speaker: NA
Text: government and other bodies. The Government restrictions.

Speaker: NA
Text: has examined all recommendations and taken a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of actions as a result.

Speaker: NA
Text: But Government action can be effective only

Speaker: NA
Text: it is backed by community awareness and consearch

Speaker: NA
Text: cern. This is particularly true in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: reation vehicles, where the behaviour of individdamaged

Speaker: NA
Text: ual riders and drivers is critical to the protection

Speaker: NA
Text: of the environment. Because of this, the Governnew

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been especially concerned to imof

Speaker: NA
Text: plement the Committee's recommendations tralian

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at promoting environmental awareness

Speaker: NA
Text: recreation vehicle users. One contribution to this

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a film produced by Film Australia for

Speaker: NA
Text: the former Department of Environment,

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Community Development. The film, present

Speaker: NA
Text: called 'Making Tracks', shows in a simple way

Speaker: NA
Text: the effects which vehicles can have on the bush

Speaker: NA
Text: and the beach. It has been made for showing to further

Speaker: NA
Text: recreation vehicle clubs, schools, environment

Speaker: NA
Text: centres and all groups which have an interest

Speaker: NA
Text: recreation vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another activity undertaken by the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Department in this direction was the preparation

Speaker: NA
Text: of a code of ethics for recreation vehicle users.

Speaker: NA
Text: This code was discussed with recreation vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and relevant State bodies as

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended by the Standing Committee. The

Speaker: NA
Text: code has been printed as a poster and as a sticker

Speaker: NA
Text: for doors and motorcycle fuel tanks and has been

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed to recreation vehicle clubs, motor

Speaker: NA
Text: registries, automobile associations, environment

Speaker: NA
Text: centres and other relevant bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Standing Committee also recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth encourage a national

Speaker: NA
Text: symposium on off-road vehicles. A national

Speaker: NA
Text: workshop on off-road vehicle management was

Speaker: NA
Text: held at the Canberra College of Advanced Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation last December, and was attended by rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives from the Commonwealth, State and

Speaker: NA
Text: local government, off-road vehicle clubs and

Speaker: NA
Text: environmentalists. The workshop aimed to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: administrators, planners, managers, users of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recreation vehicles and others to a closer under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing and appreciation of the problems in-

Speaker: NA
Text: in the use of recreation vehicles and the

Speaker: NA
Text: repotential environmental damage. Other rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: imommendations of the Committee were that the

Speaker: NA
Text: importation of over-snow recreation vehicles be

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibited and that an environmental impact

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment should be carried out before any new

Speaker: NA
Text: rectype of off-road recreational vehicle was

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government examined these rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations, but considers that legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: controls on use after entry into Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: local would be far more effective than import

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of recommendations concerned de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence training areas. In association with the

Speaker: NA
Text: if Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation, the Defence Department is

Speaker: NA
Text: reccontinuing its program of regenerating areas

Speaker: NA
Text: by defence training activities. Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment impact statements on the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: defence training areas include consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: the effects of vehicles on the terrain. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Territory is one area in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: in Commonwealth has a direct concern in the regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation of recreation vehicles. The Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Capital Territory has examined carefully the

Speaker: NA
Text: HousStanding Commttee's recommendations. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department monitors the use of trail

Speaker: NA
Text: and mini bikes, operates three bike tracks in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory and is looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: sites for these activities. It is also review-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the need for a registration system for rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: in reation vehicles. In the States, Victoria and

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland already have legislation and other

Speaker: NA
Text: States and the Northern Territory are consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing legislation or other forms of control.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Standing Committee's report has

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to the attention of members of the CounEnvironment

Speaker: NA
Text: cil of Nature Conservation Ministers, the Auslater

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Environment Council and the Recreation

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers' Council. The Ministers concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: have agreed to discuss the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: with other State colleagues. In this way, I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the report may influence the

Speaker: NA
Text: control legislation in States which do not have it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through the ministerial councils we will follow

Speaker: NA
Text: these developments. '

Speaker: NA
Text: I would just like to add one further point.

Speaker: NA
Text: this statement the term 'recreation vehicle'

Speaker: NA
Text: generally been adopted rather than the term

Speaker: NA
Text: 'off-road vehicle' which was the term used in the

Speaker: NA
Text: report. The name 'recreation vehicle' is preferred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the term 'off-road vehicle' which I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: courages a use of vehicles which are intrinsically

Speaker: NA
Text: damaging to the environment. All vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: should preferably be driven or ridden on some

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of track. In conclusion, let me repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has considered the report and

Speaker: NA
Text: taken action as it believes necessary. I hope that recreationists-challengin

Speaker: NA
Text: recreation vehicle users will support government the

Speaker: NA
Text: activity in this field and take care to protect the over

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I present the following paper

Text: Off-Road Vehicles-Government's Response-Ministeria l

Text: ment and Conservation was tabled in the Parliaments

Text: ment. In essence the Government's response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee's recommendations has been

Speaker: NA
Text: flimsy and deplorable. This nation has a serious

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. Clearly environmental responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: has been the unwanted child of this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will recall that with the

Speaker: NA
Text: change of Government in 1975 the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: ministry was abolished by the Fraser Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It was absorbed into the odds and sods de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment, namely, the Department of Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: been ment, Housing and Community Development.

Speaker: NA
Text: was downgraded further still by

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming a division of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Science. Now it comes within the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and the Environment. Let us be clear

Speaker: NA
Text: where this Government stands in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: environment matters. Its priorities in that regard

Speaker: NA
Text: preparation of are very low indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Environmental management and the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of off-road vehicles on the Australian continent

Speaker: NA
Text: are very serious problems. They are matters

Speaker: NA
Text: In which create problems for the environment itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: has The disturbance created by the use of off-road

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles is a problem to communities. In this re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard I refer to an article relating to the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: off-road vehicles published in the Sydney Morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ening Herald as far back as April 1976. The article

Speaker: NA
Text: outlines the basic conflict between the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: off-road vehicles and the preservation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment and environmental qualities in

Speaker: NA
Text: that urban areas. The article states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The root problem is that the type of use desired by ORV

Speaker: NA
Text: g terrain-i s in direct conflict with

Speaker: NA
Text: soil conservation techniques that have been developed

Speaker: NA
Text: the years. Despite their claims, the ORV enthusiasts

Speaker: NA
Text: have not succeeded in rewriting these rules in the way that

Speaker: NA
Text: nature understands. The effects of soil loss are, in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: our lifetimes, permanent and negative.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the basic conflict because these vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: on are damaging and they are even more damaging

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are not used in a responsible way. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should note that in many areas of Australia there

Speaker: NA
Text: is intense public opposition to the activities of ir-

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible off-road vehicle users. Let me make

Speaker: NA
Text: it quite clear that my criticism is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of off-road vehicles. I instance a

Speaker: NA
Text: case in the Newcastle area only a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago where public reaction against the use

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these vehicles was so strong that wires

Speaker: NA
Text: strung across bush tracks used by trail bike

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously in an attempt to decapitate a

Speaker: NA
Text: trail bike riderwho came along. Fortunately the

Speaker: NA
Text: wire was discovered before a fatality occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: That indicates the intensity of public reaction to

Speaker: NA
Text: is the activities of some of these off-road vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also rather a sad reflection on govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: in AustraUa generally that State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have refused consistently to pick up the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility for setting aside areas for use

Speaker: NA
Text: exclusively by off-road vehicle enthusiasts. An

Speaker: NA
Text: off-road vehicle can be a work vehicle, as is used

Speaker: NA
Text: by departments or as is used by land users, or it

Speaker: NA
Text: can be a recreational vehicle, as is used by thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands upon thousands of AustraUans. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: organised clubs or groups which do have sound

Speaker: NA
Text: principles and regimes to follow as to where they

Speaker: NA
Text: use their vehicles and how they use their vehicles,

Speaker: NA
Text: and which do have regard to the noise problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that they create. But it is clear from the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: statement that to date there has been insufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation by governments of the suitability of

Speaker: NA
Text: areas that should be set aside for off-road vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The use of these vehicles has several aspects.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, there is the damage to the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: itself-th e damage to ground vegetation and to

Speaker: NA
Text: beach and foreshore areas, the destruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: wilderness areas and reserves, and the erosion

Speaker: NA
Text: problem overall in all those cases. Then there is

Speaker: NA
Text: the noise problem. This is much more a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in urban and outer urban areas. I acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem that it creates to wildlife, but I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal more specifically with the problem for

Speaker: NA
Text: urban and outer urban areas. There are cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: people virtually being driven out of their homes

Speaker: NA
Text: by the high pitched whine and noise of these ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles because they are operated without

Speaker: NA
Text: silencers or are used irresponsibly by people

Speaker: NA
Text: without regard to the disturbance they are cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating. Then there is the danger to the users them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. There are regular instances of vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: overturning, of accidents and of users being

Speaker: NA
Text: killed because of poor operation of the trail bike,

Speaker: NA
Text: the sand dune buggy or the beach buggy, what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever was being used. But added to that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: public danger of these vehicles careering along

Speaker: NA
Text: beaches. So there is the noise, the damage, the

Speaker: NA
Text: despoliation and, as I said before, the danger to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people who are using the beaches for swim-

Speaker: NA
Text: ming, for sunbaking or just for quite walks. This

Speaker: NA
Text: report from the Government does not really face

Speaker: NA
Text: up to those problems. However, it does admit

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it rather regrettable

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations put forward in the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Environment and Conservation- a report that

Speaker: NA
Text: took some 18 months to bring down, a report

Speaker: NA
Text: that took a great deal of effort by the Comhim. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's members, together with submissions

Speaker: NA
Text: from any organisations-di d not even rate a prohibited

Speaker: NA
Text: mention in the Minister's response. A key recshould

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendation of the Committee was recommenreational

Speaker: NA
Text: dation No. 5, which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: specific legislation should be introduced in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Territory and the Northern Territoiy as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: ible and should cover the following points:

Speaker: NA
Text: registration of vehicles for recreation use;

Speaker: NA
Text: display of registration plates;

Speaker: NA
Text: third party insurance of these vehicles;

Speaker: NA
Text: age/power limits as in Victorian legislation;

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance with ADR28 on noise levels;

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of areas specifically intended for ORV use;

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibition of the use of vehicles off road except in areas

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically set aside for off-road use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last item does not even rate a mention in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's response. Yet that is an area-thi s is

Speaker: NA
Text: still the case in the Australian Capital Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: and it was the case in the Northern Territory-i n

Speaker: NA
Text: which tbis Government could have acted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past 2'/4 years. But it has obviously decided not to

Speaker: NA
Text: act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us turn to recommendation No. 7, which

Speaker: NA
Text: reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government encourageresearchto

Speaker: NA
Text: be undertaken on the carrying capacity of various

Speaker: NA
Text: ecosystems.

Speaker: NA
Text: A key part of the evaluation of the measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be taken to maintain the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and thereby make the use of these vehicles com-

Speaker: NA
Text: patible with the management and preservation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the environment does not rate a mention by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. Recommendation No. 8 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government sympathetically con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider request from non-government bodies for financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance for this type of research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once again there is not a mention of this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's response because it is not a financial

Speaker: NA
Text: priority. I do not think that it even rates with the

Speaker: NA
Text: moral priorities. Recommendation No. 9 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: the import of over-snow vehicles for recreational pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses be prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's response to that has been to

Speaker: NA
Text: say:' We shouldn't use our import powers to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol the entry of these vehicles. Let's wait until

Speaker: NA
Text: after they get here and leave it to somebody else

Speaker: NA
Text: to sort it out'. That is exacdy what the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done and that is exactly how this prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem has arisen over the years. It is a confession of

Speaker: NA
Text: that six of the 1S recfailure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-Yo u misinterpret what I said.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: I t is not a misinterpretation, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister interjects. I will read his words to

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the importation of over-snow recreation vehicles be

Speaker: NA
Text: and that an environmental impact assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: be carried out before any new type of off-road rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle was imported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now that is all off-road recreation vehicles, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just over-snow recreation vehicles. As the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: as posster said in his speech, the Government considers

Speaker: NA
Text: that legislation for controls on use after entry into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia would be more effective than import

Speaker: NA
Text: restricuons. That is a confession of failure. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: refusal to face up to what I have said is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious problem. In effect the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: passing the buck down the line to State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and further down the line to local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and local government receives the major

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of complaints. There is intense public op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position to the way in which some of these ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles are being used and local government, least

Speaker: NA
Text: of all, has the powers to control and regulate this

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. It is the Government's refusal to face

Speaker: NA
Text: up to that that is at the core of this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recommendation No. 10 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation of tracks no longer in use should be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the company, government depanment or

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for creating the tracks.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a non-defence area. The Minister's state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment referred to activities by the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence in respect of areas under its control.

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome that. But the Minister makes no

Speaker: NA
Text: ence to other areas of land under the control of

Speaker: NA
Text: non-defence departments of government. There

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should have acted, but it has

Speaker: NA
Text: not acted. Recommendation No. 13 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: further research be done by the Commonwealth Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Transport with a view to decreasing the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: limits imposed on motor bikes under ADR 28.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the important problem that I referred

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier in my remarks. That is where the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: upset and disturbance are created, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: for aged people in urban and outer urban areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: People have been forced to sell up their homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and get away from the constant noise created

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of these vehicles travelling around urban

Speaker: NA
Text: streets. Recommendation No. 14 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible authorities require proprietors

Speaker: NA
Text: implement good conservation programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: No mention at all was made of this in the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's speech. Again, it could have been part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: public relations exercise; it could have been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded in the code that has been developed;

Speaker: NA
Text: could have been an exercise that

Speaker: NA
Text: readily carried out by the Federal Government if

Speaker: NA
Text: it had had the desire.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn back to recommendation No. 4 which

Speaker: NA
Text: reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Environment, Housing and Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Development-

Speaker: NA
Text: That was the name of the portfolio in earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: days-

Speaker: NA
Text: request the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velop national guidelines for legislation and management

Speaker: NA
Text: policy regarding off-road vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has referred to that in his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. But, regrettably, all he has said was: 'That

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been taken up with the State conser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation Ministers'. But the Government has had

Speaker: NA
Text: 2Vi years in which to take it up and to consider it?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jacobi-Tha t is pretty quick for it.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: Yes, I confess that it is, for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Committee of the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament are entided to be told what

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: the Minister has responded to that recommen-

Text: under discussion, but we cannot tell you any-

Speaker: NA
Text: underthing about it'. That indicates the lack of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: person reby the Government for this very important

Text: problem.

Text: MULTILATERAL TRADE
