Text: NEGOTIATIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker has received letters from both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowen) and the honourable member for St Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: George ( Mr Neil) proposing that definite matport

Speaker: NA
Text: ters of public importance be submitted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House for discussion today. As required by

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Order 107, Mr Speaker has selected the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which, in his opinion, is the most urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: and important, that is, that proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's failure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the multilateral trade negotiations and the codes of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct thereunder.

Speaker: NA
Text: I therefore call upon those members who ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove of the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: (11.55)-Th e matter before the House is of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance and is self-explanatory. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not disclosed to the Parliament or to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people concerned what its policy is in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the multilateral trade negotiations-

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the concessions that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has given-an d its attitude to the codes of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct which are prescribed under those nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiations. For some time the Opposition in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House has been urging the Government to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clare and disclose what its policy is on these vital

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. The reason for so doing is that it affects

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of Australian industry. In a series of

Speaker: NA
Text: statements that have been made in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and outside the House we have all sorts of views

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward by Government Ministers. At this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage we might say that we have about four Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isters for Trade-th e Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Fraser), the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Anthony), the Minister for Special Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Representations ( Mr Garland) and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to come in with his ideas as to how trade should be

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can understand the situation in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Government trying to grapple

Speaker: NA
Text: with a policy which apparently they have not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: d been able to agree upon amongst themselves;

Speaker: NA
Text: but it does little credit to the Government, when

Speaker: NA
Text: it is talking about unemployment and the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of creating employment opportunities, that

Speaker: NA
Text: it cannot give any lead to industry. People in the

Speaker: NA
Text: textile and apparel manufacturing industry

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to know where they are going to stand

Speaker: NA
Text: from the point of view of investment. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: working on the basis of a life of virtually six

Speaker: NA
Text: months or 12 months, depending on what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is going to decide. If honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members take notice of what the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs said yesterday and look at the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: on negotiations with the Third World, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will see that the reasoning adopted there is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no need for us to have a textile and

Speaker: NA
Text: apparel industry. That might be argued, but at

Speaker: NA
Text: the present time we have 107,000 people in that

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and, with the multiplier factor, the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment of another 200,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: to disclose its policy in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: The industry leaders come to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and say: 'What is your policy? Are we expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to survive or do you want us to go out of busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness? If it is the latter, why should we bother to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in new machinery? Why should we bother

Speaker: NA
Text: to put our money into something which has no

Speaker: NA
Text: future? What is the Government's policy in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard.'? I am impressed that they are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce figures which show that there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial reduction in the manufacturing base;

Speaker: NA
Text: that some 57,000 employees have gone in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last three years. The textile and apparel industry

Speaker: NA
Text: says: If this continues, why should there be any

Speaker: NA
Text: will to keep going?' For example, the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders say that, should no permanency be given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the industry from the point of view of a five or

Speaker: NA
Text: seven year plan, 10,000 jobs could be lost in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ballarat and Bendigo alone. They talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that a factory in Talbot, Victoria, has opened

Speaker: NA
Text: and closed four times in the last five years. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to say that if the Government is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: get rid of that industry areas such as Geelong,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ararat, Stawell, Casdemaine, Warrnambool,

Speaker: NA
Text: Talbot, Wangaratta and others will lose substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial numbers of employees, and that every indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try in Swan Hill has been forced out in the last 15

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I have given honourable members the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: tails ofjust one industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a genuine concern that we cannot find

Speaker: NA
Text: out what the Government has offered by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions in the multilateral trade nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiations. It is not valid to say that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our capacity because our exports have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased in value. The big argument is in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection with the quantity. That is the point. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, you know of the extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which the sugar industryfindsitself

Speaker: NA
Text: now because of the attitudes adopted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community in subsidising

Speaker: NA
Text: its sugar, dumping it on the world, and virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: wrecking our industry. So, when we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about doing business with the world, let us look

Speaker: NA
Text: at it on the basis that we are basically doing busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness with the developed countries of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: and those countries are out to look after them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. When we ask in this Parliament what con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions we have given to the EEC, we are un-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to find out. When we ask in this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: what concessions we have given to Japan, we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot find out. We are told that we have got

Speaker: NA
Text: some concessions. We are told that we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to sell some buffalo beef and a few

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes of cheese. But what did we give in return?

Speaker: NA
Text: In regard to the EEC, I am advised that, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: we might have got $200m work of concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: from it, we might have given $400m by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: our concessions and this can affect our industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not want any more secrecy. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want any more ineptitude. The real thrust

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are about is that we seem to have four

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers all saying different things. Somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that they ought to be called the 'gang

Speaker: NA
Text: four' or the Marx Brothers. No solution is evideemed

Speaker: NA
Text: dent from what they say. We want to know

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Government's policy. Not only should we

Speaker: NA
Text: know it in the interests of ordinary democracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about the industry leaders, the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement and everybody else wanting to know

Speaker: NA
Text: where funds ought to be invested or where there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be job opportunities? These arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made under the multilateral trade

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations. We were not able to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly. It would appear that we had to rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese to put our case. The question is: What

Speaker: NA
Text: industries have been affected? We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: told nothing about the matter although a total

Speaker: NA
Text: number of statements have been made.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make the salient point that it appears that

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America Congress has been told

Speaker: NA
Text: all about it. I have here a document entitled:

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the President ofthe United States

Speaker: NA
Text: to His Congress', dated 19 June. That document

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates the arrangements that have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: with Australia. It deals with the understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: on meat and the understanding on dairy prodprovided

Speaker: NA
Text: ucts, United States tariff concessions and section

Speaker: NA
Text: IV deals with Australian tariff concessions. This

Speaker: NA
Text: document can be obtained in any area in

Speaker: NA
Text: increasAustralia because it has been tabled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Congress. These matters have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been discussed or disclosed and have not even

Speaker: NA
Text: been tabled or prepared to be discussed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. The document relates to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, including: Tobacco, refrigerators, trac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors and textiles. All these matters are the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of concessions. We cannot find out what they are.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will have a serious effect on the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of industry leaders. They have come to the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position and said that it is about time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government clearly indicated its position. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been no consultation with industry leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: and the trade union movement as to the direction

Speaker: NA
Text: we are heading. It is understandable that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese, the European Economic Community

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States are keen to look after

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. They have obviously made their own

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements as to how they will give safeguards

Speaker: NA
Text: to their employees and manufacturers. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: not the situation in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the two big problems associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the codes of conduct. They relate to specific

Speaker: NA
Text: instances. The codes provide that there be no

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies, countervailing duties or government

Speaker: NA
Text: procurement. The people who have made rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentations to us have said that the removal of

Speaker: NA
Text: of subsidies could well affect the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Export Expansion Grants Scheme if the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments entered into are deemed to be illegal. This

Speaker: NA
Text: of could well be so. Export finance could be

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a subsidy. If that is the position the

Speaker: NA
Text: what Government's policy in this area could be

Speaker: NA
Text: declared illegal if it adopts the codes of conduct.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to government procurement. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that if government purchases are over

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 175,000 the contracts cannot have the protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of being open only within the domestic mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket; they have to be open to the international

Speaker: NA
Text: market. At present goods and services procured

Speaker: NA
Text: diby the Australian Government are estimated to

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount to $4 billion per annum. The codes of

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct would also cover State government pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: chases which involve an additional $8 billion- a

Speaker: NA
Text: of $12 billion. Australian industry could

Speaker: NA
Text: well have to forfeit that amount of government

Speaker: NA
Text: the money which it is presently receiving. Do

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members think that the textile and

Speaker: NA
Text: 'A apparel industry could survive if it is unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: get government procurement contracts? Hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: bedding, linen, sheets and nurses uniforms

Speaker: NA
Text: amount to a significant factor to that industry. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government enters into the arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: under the codes of conduct, then a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: curement contract of over $175,000 would be li-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to go to the international market. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, it would go to an overseas country. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last Budget provided $ 170m to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: the Export Expansion Grants Scheme. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: codes of conduct as determined by the EEC, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States and Japan is agreed upon this

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme would be illegal. So it is in the interest

Speaker: NA
Text: not only of normal parliamentary courtesy and

Speaker: NA
Text: debate but also of industry following its rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations that the Government refrain

Speaker: NA
Text: from taking a decision on the subsidy codes of

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct for some time until it becomes clear

Speaker: NA
Text: from the actions of our trading partners what the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences might be. Whilst there may be no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that the United States, the EEC and Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: will look after themselves and will sign the codes

Speaker: NA
Text: of conduct, it is important that we clearly indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate our position. I make it clear that if we accept

Speaker: NA
Text: this package we will concede not only the disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage of distance but also the disadvantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: unequal concessions. The Government has again

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated its inability or unwillingness to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the realities of world trade. We under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the problems which arise from imposing

Speaker: NA
Text: too much protection. Nobody would argue about

Speaker: NA
Text: that. But at present, with coming recessions, the

Speaker: NA
Text: energy crisis and rapidly increasing unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment throughout the world it is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: we look at the purchasing power of other nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Purchasing power in the Third World is not

Speaker: NA
Text: readily identifiable but it can be expected to sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vive in the countries which have a stranglehold

Speaker: NA
Text: on us if we are put in the position of having to

Speaker: NA
Text: subscribe to these codes of conduct. This would

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that our industries could go to the wall. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are not talking about restrictions on the Third

Speaker: NA
Text: World. We are talking about our understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the position at present because of unplanned

Speaker: NA
Text: action by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to tyres which are covered in this

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. In the Firestone Australia Pty Ltd factory

Speaker: NA
Text: at Auburn in Sydney on 21 August 700 workers

Speaker: NA
Text: were laid off because the company could not

Speaker: NA
Text: keep up with the competition. That is indicative

Speaker: NA
Text: of what is happening. Again I make the point

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have to have structural adjustment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has to be change. But let it be understood

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are about. Do not let us have all the

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocrisy from the Prime Minister. He becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: a free trader overseas and an arch protectionist

Speaker: NA
Text: at home. I am told that in a speech on 9 May

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Conference on Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Development meeting he clearly indicated that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would virtually drop tariffs. Yet when he

Speaker: NA
Text: came back to Australia he imposed an import find

Speaker: NA
Text: customs duty on previously freely imported

Speaker: NA
Text: modities. This behaviour brings Australia into

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace in world negotiations. Last year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government seemed to be extremely protection-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist. This year its policy is one of extremely free

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. Is it any wonder that industry in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: does not know which way to turn? This is remi-

Speaker: NA
Text: niscent of the problems we had-extremis t and

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistent.

Speaker: NA
Text: In raising this discussion of a matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance we urge the Government to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a draft statement of what it has in mind before

Speaker: NA
Text: making any final decisions on the codes of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct and to make public in full the tariff con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions offered before they are settled. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the important thing we say to the Government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is useless for us to talk to industry leaders on

Speaker: NA
Text: what we understand the situation to be. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: repeated requests in this Parliament we cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: get details. Yet astoundingly we are able to get

Speaker: NA
Text: them by a normal process of obtaining a copy of

Speaker: NA
Text: what was tabled in the United States. I ask per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission of the right honourable gentleman to

Speaker: NA
Text: table the concessions which are outlined in the

Speaker: NA
Text: document entitled: 'A Message from the Presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent of the United States to his Congress' and

Speaker: NA
Text: which relate to what is called an agreement with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Armitage)-Is

Speaker: NA
Text: leave granted?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: No , leave is not granted.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Leave is not

Speaker: NA
Text: granted.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: That is indicative of

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation. This published information can be

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained somewhere else. Major industry leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: want an undertaking- I hope one is given in

Speaker: NA
Text: reply-tha t the Government will not agree to the

Speaker: NA
Text: docucodes of conduct until everybody has had a

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to put their point of view. I repeat that

Speaker: NA
Text: having no subsidies and countervailing duties

Speaker: NA
Text: could affect the whole of the Export Expansion

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants Scheme. But most importantly, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: codes of conduct, government procurement con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tracts would be thrown open to world tender if

Speaker: NA
Text: they involve more than $175,000. I make the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that $12 billion a year is involved in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area. If those contracts are thrown open it would

Speaker: NA
Text: destroy our industry. That is what the people

Speaker: NA
Text: at from industiy are saying when they come to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: They cannot get any decision from the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. They have approached the Opposition, for

Speaker: NA
Text: which they never vote-le t us make that clear-t o

Speaker: NA
Text: out our position which is to provide stability

Speaker: NA
Text: comin Australia, economic development and under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing of future employment opportunities. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness to the people of Australia the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should now indicate what its attitude will

Speaker: NA
Text: be.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Richmond-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Resources) (12.9)-The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) in

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing this matter of public importance is try-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to discredit the Government's negotiating

Speaker: NA
Text: performance at the round of Multilateral Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Negotiations and he is trying to heap confusion

Speaker: NA
Text: and concern on the minds of people involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: certain sections of Australian industry. If any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, his effort today really displays his own

Speaker: NA
Text: of knowledge. He has not kept himself as well

Speaker: NA
Text: informed of what is going on as he might have. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very pleased to have this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak so that some of those people who might be

Speaker: NA
Text: confused will know how eminently successful the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government has been in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: these negotiations and in what it has achieved for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. What are negodations of this nature?

Speaker: NA
Text: They are negotiations by Australia to seek cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain benefits such as access to markets at the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: est possible price. Although we have to give con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions, naturally we want to keep them as

Speaker: NA
Text: minimal as possible. By the same token, we want

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve our objectives of lower tariffs round

Speaker: NA
Text: the world and of getting access to markets. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we have done has been of immense importance

Speaker: NA
Text: and value to the Australian export industries and

Speaker: NA
Text: it has had a negligible effect on Australian dom-

Speaker: NA
Text: estic industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have maintained a consistent policy

Speaker: NA
Text: proach and we have continued to make inforindustry-th

Speaker: NA
Text: mation available to the Australian public during

Speaker: NA
Text: the negotiations and when we have been in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to notify the public of what has been

Speaker: NA
Text: going on. We have accepted the challenge to

Speaker: NA
Text: come involved in the Multilateral Trade Negoproduce

Speaker: NA
Text: tiations round to try to liberalise international

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. As AustraUa is a major trading nation it

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we do everything possible to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: international trade flowing. Our major objective

Speaker: NA
Text: in these negotiations, which have been continuthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ing since 1972, has been to achieve a greater libtralian

Speaker: NA
Text: eralisation of agricultural trade-t o get greater

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the North American market, to Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: and into the European Economic Community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have used whatever political weight and

Speaker: NA
Text: influence we have to try to get a recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: our point of view.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: made some play on the fact that a number of quantity

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers have been involved in making comno

Speaker: NA
Text: ments related to these negotiations. If we can

Speaker: NA
Text: a benefit from a visit by the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Fraser) to Europe, to the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: or Japan then why not take advantage ofhis pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition which enables him to exercise great

Speaker: NA
Text: influence on other governments? Within the EEC

Speaker: NA
Text: in which we have needed to do immense lobby-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to have our point of view accepted we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a special Minister who has devoted a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of time to becoming acquainted and fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: iliar with the people who make the decisions in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. A lot of homework was necessary on

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe because it was during the three years of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor regime that AustraUa was almost

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely shut out of Europe. Of course it was dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: lack ing that period that we were also shut out of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan. In 1974 Japan completely shut out our

Speaker: NA
Text: beef.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Tha t is not so. You nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiated the arrangements. You are still shut out

Speaker: NA
Text: with hides.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Listen to the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: ofthe Opposition making those inane comments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, as well as the whole world, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: shut out from exporting hides into Japan. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: was during the Labor Government of 1974 that

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUa was actually shut out of Japan. Diplo-

Speaker: NA
Text: macy was required to get our points of view

Speaker: NA
Text: registered and heard in order to establish a new

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship with these countries and today, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have that situation. I quite frankly admit that the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of negotiations, particularly as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture is concerned, has not been as good as

Speaker: NA
Text: we hoped. But at least we made some progress-

Speaker: NA
Text: very valuable progress. Most significant gains

Speaker: NA
Text: aphave been made for Australia's biggest single

Speaker: NA
Text: e beef industry. This year it is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing something like $2,500m worth of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce. A few years ago the beef industry was in a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrible state because it could not get rid of its

Speaker: NA
Text: beproduce. There was a reduction in the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: it could get into the United States; it was

Speaker: NA
Text: practically shut out of the EEC and Japan. The

Speaker: NA
Text: is industry was in a terrible situation of oversupply

Speaker: NA
Text: and ruinously low prices. But as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Multilateral Trade Negotiations we have made

Speaker: NA
Text: most remarkable achievement for the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle industry. It is the most significant

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that has ever happened for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle industry. Bear in mind that this year it is

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's biggest industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: What have we achieved? We have achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: of guaranteed access to the markets of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States, the EEC and Japan and soon I hope to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to finalise arrangements with Canada for a

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian meat to go in to its market

Speaker: NA
Text: matter what the circumstances. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: get words, a minimum amount of meat can be sold

Speaker: NA
Text: through those markets. If all the export quotas

Speaker: NA
Text: were reduced to the minimum amount it would

Speaker: NA
Text: account for approximately 70 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's beef exports. That is a remarkable

Speaker: NA
Text: and wonderful security for the beef industry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has never before had anything like that.

Speaker: NA
Text: It always has been completely exposed and vul-

Speaker: NA
Text: nerable to the closing off of overseas markets as

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw during the period Labor was in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: But now we have a guaranteed access for a mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum amount and that has been the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement in the Multilateral Trade Negot-

Speaker: NA
Text: iations. We placed a good deal of emphasis on

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry because it was in a tremendously

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate situation and needed some form of se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity for the future. It now has arrangement that

Speaker: NA
Text: will cover it for the next 10 years, for the decade

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 1980s. I hope the people associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: and dependent on the Australian cattle industry

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate what the Australian Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done. As well we have accomplished other

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller things.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Wha t are the concessions?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I will discuss the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions in a minute.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Yo u have five minutes left.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Tha t is adequate to cope

Speaker: NA
Text: with the honourable member when I tell him

Speaker: NA
Text: what some of the concessions are. We have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions that will help the dairy industry. One

Speaker: NA
Text: concession involves an increase of the cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: quota into the EEC and the United States. Pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously we had a quota of only 1,600 tonnes in to

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States whereas now we have a quota

Speaker: NA
Text: of 4,000 tonnes. What about wool? Since the be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning of this century we have been arguing and

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting with the United States for reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool duty. As a result of those negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a 60 per cent reduction in the tariff level

Speaker: NA
Text: on wool and I hope that the revival of, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: additional sales of wool to, the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: market will be worth a lot to the Australian in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry. The United States market is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest markets in the world but manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually ceased to use our wool because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: deterrent of the higher duty on wool imports. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to get many other useful benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: in course of the negotiations including quotas on

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh fruits, dried fruits, canned fruits, meat

Speaker: NA
Text: offals, wheat gluten and beef tallow which

Speaker: NA
Text: although relatively small benefits are important

Speaker: NA
Text: to our industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have endeavoured to keep the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public informed on these negotiations. It all

Speaker: NA
Text: started in 1972 in informal discussions in Geneva

Speaker: NA
Text: when officers of my then Department indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: their willingness to participate in these great

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational talks which were to take place. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1973 the Tokyo declaration was made and since

Speaker: NA
Text: then there has been progressive development. I

Speaker: NA
Text: felt that in Australia there was a bipartisan ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the international negotiations but ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously the Department Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition is trying to make some political capital out

Speaker: NA
Text: of them. Last year a major statement was made

Speaker: NA
Text: on Australia's new approach to the negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were prepared to enter into them on the for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mula approach. In other words, we were pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to trade a 40 per cent across the board

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff cut, if that was necessary, with certain

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications. This year after major negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: which I was invloved in had taken place, I made

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement to the House on the progress up to

Speaker: NA
Text: that stage. The Prime Minister and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Special Trade Representations ( Mr Garland)

Speaker: NA
Text: made statements on 9 May this year. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made Press statements concerning the code and

Speaker: NA
Text: had provided to industry information which I

Speaker: NA
Text: will mention in a minute.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members might well ask what we

Speaker: NA
Text: have paid to get the benefits for wbich I have

Speaker: NA
Text: asked. We have given concessions. Basically,

Speaker: NA
Text: those concessions have amounted to a binding of

Speaker: NA
Text: existing levels of tariff. In other words, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to get the full benefit of the 25 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: across-the-board tariff cut that the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government inflicted upon industry in 1974. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have negotiated to get the full benefit of that

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff cut. As a result, not one single industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff will be reduced. We have bound approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 120 items. That has been the price that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have had to pay. There has been no reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: at all in industrial tariffs. There have been a few

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions in non-industrial tariffs but we have

Speaker: NA
Text: not had to pay any price. All we have done is

Speaker: NA
Text: frozen approximately 120 items. There will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff cuts on industrial items. I said initially that

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole purpose of negotiations is to try to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the best benefit at the least price. Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members must acclaim that we have done a

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent job in our negotiations when we

Speaker: NA
Text: have come out of them without having to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: anything more than making a binding on indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial tariffs. If there have to be any adjustments

Speaker: NA
Text: on those bindings because of an Industries As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance Commission investigation there will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be further negotiations and we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay in another area.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Wha t about the codes?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: asked about the codes. I am coming to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Five codes are under examination. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not committed itself on whether it will

Speaker: NA
Text: in- be a signatory to those codes. It has circulated

Speaker: NA
Text: them to all the relevant industry people. Officers

Speaker: NA
Text: of my Department are travelling from State to

Speaker: NA
Text: State talking with State governments, industry

Speaker: NA
Text: people and the trade unions. When we get a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse from these people the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a position to know whether it will sign all

Speaker: NA
Text: these codes or none at all. What could be a more

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible way of approaching this matter than

Speaker: NA
Text: that? We are canvassing the reaction of industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unions and State governments as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we ought to sign these codes. When we

Speaker: NA
Text: have their response we will be able to make a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision. How else would we make such a decision?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: The y start on 1 January.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: The Government will have

Speaker: NA
Text: time because the codes have been circulated for a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of months. Already we are getting reac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from industiy. We will make our decision in

Speaker: NA
Text: ample time. We will be successful in this oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation, as we have been in all the others. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said today ought to expose the falseness of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments he has made. He would like us to reveal

Speaker: NA
Text: the nature of our negotiations. In some cases that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be completely discourteous. At the worst it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be irresponsible. Why should we give

Speaker: NA
Text: away the advantage of negotiations by declaring

Speaker: NA
Text: in advance what the arrangements have been?

Speaker: NA
Text: Negotiations are still proceeding with Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: and Switzerland. Until settlement of the nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiations with all the countries involved, it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the intention of the Government to reveal them

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House. That could embarrass some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations which are taking place.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Armitage)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The right honourable member'stimehas

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Wills) (12.24)- Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Hodges) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the business of the day be called on.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The question is:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the business of the day be called on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of that opinion say aye, of the contrary no.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the ayes have it.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: No .

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I s a division

Speaker: NA
Text: required?

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: I f my dissent is recorded I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied. People will know the malevolence that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Street, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr STREET
Text: Corangamite-Minister for In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial Relations) (12.25)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill proposes amendments to the Concili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation and Arbitration Act which are designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: remedy deficiencies in the operation of the Act

Speaker: NA
Text: which have become evident in recent months.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will:

Speaker: NA
Text: require a commissioner to consult with his

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy president before making or varying an

Speaker: NA
Text: award relating to wages and condiuons;

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibit the Commission from ordering,

Speaker: NA
Text: recommending or sanctioning in any way, an

Speaker: NA
Text: employer paying wages to an employee for

Speaker: NA
Text: time when the employee was engaged in in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial action;

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for the expeditious hearing of

Speaker: NA
Text: stand-down applications, either before a

Speaker: NA
Text: single member of the Commission or a full

Speaker: NA
Text: bench;

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that the question of whether an

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial dispute exists may be the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: a reference to a full bench;

Speaker: NA
Text: enable an industrial dispute or part of an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial dispute to be referred to a full bench at

Speaker: NA
Text: the conciliation state;

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforce the powers of the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission by enabling him to withdraw a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter from another member of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission and either deal with it himself or refer

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter in a full bench; and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide increased protection for the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity by creating an alternative path to the

Speaker: NA
Text: deregistration of organisations and thereby re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move delays in the deregistration process in

Speaker: NA
Text: cases where the safety, health or welfare of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community are put at risk by industrial action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consultation with the National Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Consultative Council

Speaker: NA
Text: Before dealing more fully with the substance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposed amendments, I want to refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of consultation in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Consultative Council. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: established the National Labour Consultative

Speaker: NA
Text: Council by statute in 1977 as a continuing, tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: partite consultative body. As a general practice,

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals involving industrial relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: manpower issues, including possible legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: are submitted to the Council for discussion and

Speaker: NA
Text: expression of views for Government's consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. The Government's initial proposals about

Speaker: NA
Text: the particular issues dealt with in the Bill before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House were discussed by the NLCC at its

Speaker: NA
Text: 12th meeting on 6 August this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives of the Australian Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Unions and the Council of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Employee Organisations did not

Speaker: NA
Text: attend that meeting. Both organisations had for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mally advised me that their executives had

Speaker: NA
Text: jointly resolved on 16 July not to participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: NLCC discussions pending resolution of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wrote to both organisations on 26 July,

Speaker: NA
Text: stressing the importance the Government placed

Speaker: NA
Text: on the role of the Council. I received no response

Speaker: NA
Text: to these letters prior to 6 August meeting of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NLCC. I might add that I subsequently received

Speaker: NA
Text: replies in late August and early September advis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that both organisations were prepared to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume their participation in NLCC discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to certain conditions. I replied to their let-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters on 7 September and I hope to see both or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisations resume their participation in Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Council regretted the absence of union

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives at the 6 August meeting. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, the Council felt obliged to carry out its

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory functions. As on previous occasions, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, in finalising its proposed legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, has given careful consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: points raised in the Council's discussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Requirement of Consultation by Commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill proposes that a commissioner be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to consult with his deputy president be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore making or varying an award with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and conditions. There is a complex range

Speaker: NA
Text: of awards and registered agreements operating

Speaker: NA
Text: in industries coming within the jurisdiction ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ConciUation and Arbitration Commission. This

Speaker: NA
Text: very fact demands consistency of principle in de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision making within the Commission itself. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: grettably there have been some occasions when

Speaker: NA
Text: such consistency has been lacking. The conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences for the community have been very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious, both industrially and economically. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed consultative process is designed to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide greater co-ordination and consistency in de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision making within the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Powers of the Commission in Relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments to Workers for time lost through

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial action

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn next to the proposal to limit the powers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commission in relation to payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: workers for time lost through industrial action.

Speaker: NA
Text: At present the Commission may provide for pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to employees in respect of time not worked

Speaker: NA
Text: because they were engaged in industrial action.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is undesirable by any standards. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: does it encourage irresponsible industrial action,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also it forces the employer to pay for the very

Speaker: NA
Text: disruption that puts his business at risk and dam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages the economic and social life of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. It is an outlandish concept and indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: makes a mockery of any supposed 'right to

Speaker: NA
Text: strike'. This legislation now makes it quite clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commission wUl not be able to award,

Speaker: NA
Text: or in any way sanction, payment for time lost

Speaker: NA
Text: through industrial action. Accordingly the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes an amendment to the Act to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commission is not empowered to make

Speaker: NA
Text: an award, certify a memorandum of agreement,

Speaker: NA
Text: make a recommendation or take any other

Speaker: NA
Text: action, whether by way of concUiation or arbi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration, in respect of a claim for the making of a

Speaker: NA
Text: payment to employees in respect of a period dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing which those employees were engaged in in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stand-down applications

Speaker: NA
Text: The BUl proposes amendments to require the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission to deal expeditiously with stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: down applications. A stand-down clause is one

Speaker: NA
Text: that authorises an employer not to pay some or

Speaker: NA
Text: all of his employees in specified circumstances,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, where they cannot be usefully

Speaker: NA
Text: employed because of a breakdown of machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: or industrial action by other employees. Appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for stand-down clauses are usually dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with by a Commissioner or Deputy President.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are 3 main reasons why the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing these amendments to speed up the

Speaker: NA
Text: process for consideration of stand-down clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: in awards. Firstly, the harmful effects of indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial action on any enterprise are often serious,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they can be disastrous in the case of small

Speaker: NA
Text: employers. There is little they can do to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. Employers should not be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: 'carry' employees for whom there is no work be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the industrial action of other employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, stand-down clauses protect employees

Speaker: NA
Text: from being sacked-the y enable the employer to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the need to dismiss employees for whom

Speaker: NA
Text: no work is avaUable as a result of industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: action by others. Thirdly, provision for prompt

Speaker: NA
Text: access by employers to the Commission in appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for stand-down clauses should encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: unionists generally to exert a moderating

Speaker: NA
Text: influence on particular union members and

Speaker: NA
Text: officers who are quick to call strikes rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: use the processes of conciUation and arbitration.

Speaker: NA
Text: A decision to take industrial action all too often

Speaker: NA
Text: gravely affects innocent people not directly in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved. Any person considering industrial action

Speaker: NA
Text: should be sensitive to the possible consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of that action for his fellow workers and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: References to a Full Bench

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to the proposed amendments which

Speaker: NA
Text: remedy deficiencies in the Conciliation and Arbirelations

Speaker: NA
Text: tration Act inhibiting the referral of matters

Speaker: NA
Text: full bench ofthe Commission. Those deficiencies welfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: were highlighted during proceedings in the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciliation and Arbitration Commission concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: a claim by the Australian Telecommunication

Speaker: NA
Text: Employees Association for a 20 per cent increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in all wage levels of ATEA members employed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Australian Telecommunications Community.

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. The Telecommunications Commission these

Speaker: NA
Text: resisted the claim on the grounds that it the

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicted with the principles governing wage

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation. ATEA members then imposed bans

Speaker: NA
Text: and limitations which caused the breakdown

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Telecommunications system with

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious social and economic consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the gravity of the situation, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: essential, in the public interest, that the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to a full bench. However, there were

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties in getting such a reference. It is clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: unacceptable that the processes of the Comprotect

Speaker: NA
Text: mission for the proper settlement of industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes should be frustrated because of prowatch

Speaker: NA
Text: cedural deficiencies. It is proposed to remedy

Speaker: NA
Text: those deficiencies by the following amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Act:

Speaker: NA
Text: First, an amendment to provide that the

Speaker: NA
Text: question whether or not an industrial dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: exists may be the subject of a reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: bench of the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second, an amendment to enable an indusadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: trial dispute or part of an industrial dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: be referred to a full bench at the conciliation

Speaker: NA
Text: stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third, an amendment to empower the uals

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the Commission to withdraw a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter from a member of the Commission and

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with it himself by conciliation and/or

Speaker: NA
Text: bitration or refer it to a full bench.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cancellation of Registration

Speaker: NA
Text: For some time now the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that in certain situations there

Speaker: NA
Text: need to provide an alternative to the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: deregistration processes presently available

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: need arises from the actions of a few pursuing

Speaker: NA
Text: selfish interests with reckless disregard for the

Speaker: NA
Text: commumty. Many unions, or sections of them,

Speaker: NA
Text: are strategically placed to interfere with the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of goods and services to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, they have used the vulnerability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community to their disruptive tactics as a power-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful industrial weapon, and even, on occasions,

Speaker: NA
Text: for blatantly political purposes. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not believe that any member of our com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, whether a direct participant in industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: or not, should have to put up with tac-

Speaker: NA
Text: to a tics which threaten their health, safety or

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that it is proper for all organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations effectively to represent the legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of their members. But these organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations also have a responsibility to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an unfortunate fact that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, or sections of them, have in

Speaker: NA
Text: past ignored that responsibility and rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: the proper process for settling their disputes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: need only remind honourable members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: of disruption caused by members of the Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Union in support of claims for wage in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases under a number of awards. That disrup-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion had a dramatic effect, for example, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: be supply of milk and other vital foodstuffs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government is concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of individuals. We have already acted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of individuals in relation to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial organisations. We will not stand by and

Speaker: NA
Text: while individual Australians are denied

Speaker: NA
Text: their right to obtain goods and services affecting

Speaker: NA
Text: their safety, health or welfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: Registration under the Conciliation and Arbi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration Act confers very significant rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges upon an organisation. It also carries

Speaker: NA
Text: a full with it obligations. The Government believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that the present deregistration provisions are not

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with the special circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: to where organisations, or sections of them, en-

Speaker: NA
Text: danger the safety, health or welfare of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families. In this context, the existing grounds for

Speaker: NA
Text: deregistration do not sufficiently protect individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: or the public interest. Accordingly, this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes that another process of deregistration

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided which will be additional to the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: aring provisions. I will briefly deal with the main

Speaker: NA
Text: features of the proposed new provision.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister may apply to a full bench of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission for a declaration that industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: is a action by an organisation or a group of its

Speaker: NA
Text: members has had, is having, or is likely to have,

Speaker: NA
Text: a substantial adverse effect on the safety, health

Speaker: NA
Text: or welfare of the community or a part of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. At this point I ask honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: to note that it is not any adverse effect due to

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial action that will make an organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: liable to deregistration by these processes; the

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse effect must be substantial. Moreover, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to initiate proceedings is restricted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, and the decision as to whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold test has been satisfied lies with a full

Speaker: NA
Text: bench of the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where the full bench makes a declaration the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General may within 6 months direct

Speaker: NA
Text: the Registrar to cancel the organisation's regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration or make orders suspending the rights,

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges or capacities of the organisation or giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing directions as to the exercise of any of its

Speaker: NA
Text: rights, privileges or capacities or for restricting

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of its funds or property to ensure observ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of the order. Cancellation of registration

Speaker: NA
Text: need not follow a declaration. If the organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakes not to pursue the industrial action

Speaker: NA
Text: that might be the end of the matter. If it were to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back on its undertaking, deregistration could

Speaker: NA
Text: be directed at any time up to 6 months after the

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration by the full bench. After thattime,of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the Minister would need to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: another declaration by a full bench.

Speaker: NA
Text: The orders that the Governor-General may

Speaker: NA
Text: make as an alternative to cancellation of regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration are the same as those that may be made

Speaker: NA
Text: as an alternative to deregistration under the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing provision for cancellation of registration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where such an order has been made it will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main open to the Governor-General, within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next 6 months, to direct that the organisation's

Speaker: NA
Text: registration be cancelled. I remind honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that the Acts Interpretation Act pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides that a reference to the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: in an Act shall, unless the contrary intention

Speaker: NA
Text: appears, be read as referring to the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General acting with the advice of the Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, that is, with the advice of Ministers. No

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary intention is expressed in these amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. Consequently, in exercising powers under

Speaker: NA
Text: the section, the Governor-General will act with

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice of the Executive Council. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the Governor-General has directed that

Speaker: NA
Text: an organisation's registration be cancelled, the

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation cannot be re-registered without the

Speaker: NA
Text: consent of the Governor-General. He may make

Speaker: NA
Text: his consent conditional upon the organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: complying with conditions he prescribes.

Speaker: NA
Text: These new provisions are designed specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect the job security, safety, health or

Speaker: NA
Text: fare of Australian men and women and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families. They would be used only where these

Speaker: NA
Text: rights, fundamental to any democracy, are legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened. If any group acts in a way which puts

Speaker: NA
Text: these rights at risk, then they cannot expect the

Speaker: NA
Text: community to continue granting them the privithe

Speaker: NA
Text: leges to which they would otherwise be entitled.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the basis oflife is under attack, the public

Speaker: NA
Text: is entitled to expect its Government to protect its

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. Irresponsible behaviour endangering

Speaker: NA
Text: the very foundation of our society is, fortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: uncommon. But it does occur and cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with by the usual means. This proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation recognises that fact, and will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government with the necessary procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect its citizens. I commend the Bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Young) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEFENCE SERVICE HOMES

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Adermann, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Text: Fisher-Minister for Vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans'Affairs)(12.43)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill has two main purposes. Firstly, it pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to give effect to those recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: which were made by the House of Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives Expenditure Committee which looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence service homes scheme and which

Speaker: NA
Text: were accepted by the Government in November

Speaker: NA
Text: last and require amending legislation. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of freedom of choice for

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiaries in the selection of a house insurer

Speaker: NA
Text: and revision of the long title of the principal Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, it provides for the removal from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Service Homes Act of a number of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: strictive lending conditions. Since the inception

Speaker: NA
Text: of the scheme in 1919, it has been compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: for defence service homes to be insured and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance to be effected under the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: service homes insurance scheme. It is proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to change the legislative provisions so that per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons who obtain loans under the scheme may, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they wish, insure their properties with another in-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer. This proposal follows the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: decision last year that the insurance scheme be

Speaker: NA
Text: updated to conform with current insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will recall that last

Speaker: NA
Text: November, the Defence Service Homes Act was

Speaker: NA
Text: amended to authorise the Defence Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Homes Corporation to provide insurance cover

Speaker: NA
Text: welunder terms set out in a statement of conditions,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby enabling changes to the terms and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions to be made by administrative rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: process. The statement and any vari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations to it are subject to the approval ofthe Min-

Text: ister and must be tabled in Parliament. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement of this provision was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred so that the further changes now proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: in clause 9 of this Bill could be incorporated

Speaker: NA
Text: the new arrangements. The proposal in clause

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling beneficiaries under the Act to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: whether to insure their homes with the Corporcal

Speaker: NA
Text: ation or with another insurer is,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Corporation retaining the normal rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: a mortgagee. It will be necessary for the home to

Speaker: NA
Text: be insured adequately with an insurer authorised

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Insurance Act 1973 and for the insurer

Speaker: NA
Text: to enter into an agreement of a kind that would

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the Corporation's interests notwithstand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing any breach of policy conditions by the

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgagor.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Act stands, an applicant for an advance

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot insure his home with the Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: until it has acquired an interest in that home. To

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that an eligible person is not disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: taged during the waiting period for an advance,

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 9 authorises the Corporation, if the appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant so chooses, to insure his home during this

Speaker: NA
Text: period. Insurance cover taken out with the Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration in these circumstances will be ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: minated on reasonable notice if it becomes evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent that the loan will not be granted. I

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasise, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the oppor-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: been made.

Text: and by other provisions of the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: REPLACEMENT OF CRANES AT

Speaker: NA
Text: COCKATOO ISLAND DOCKYARD

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Public Works Committee

Speaker: Mr GROOM
Text: Braddon-Minister for Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Construction) (12.47)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Works Commitiee Act 1969, the following proposed work be

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the Parliamentaiy Standing Committee on Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Works for investigation and report: Replacement of cranes

Speaker: NA
Text: at Cockatoo Island dockyard, Sydney, N.S.W.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal is for the replacement of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: obsolete cranes at Sutherland Dock at Cockatoo

Speaker: NA
Text: Island with three new portable cranes of 30

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes, 5 tonnes and 3 tonnes capacity respect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ively. Ship towing facilities are incorporated in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 5 tonne and 3 tonne cranes. The work will

Speaker: NA
Text: also include associated crane rails and beams on

Speaker: NA
Text: the north and south sides of the dock, building

Speaker: NA
Text: alterations, new pavement around the dock and

Speaker: NA
Text: electrical and civil engineering services. The

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated cost of the proposed works at July

Speaker: NA
Text: 1979 prices is $4.2m. I now table plans of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed work.

Text: Question resolved in the'affirmative.
