Speaker: NA
Text: COMPENSATION (COMMONWEALTH

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES)

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Gwydir-Minister for Health)

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second ume.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main purpose of this Bill is to provide for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in benefits payable under the Compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion (Commonwealth Government Employees)

Speaker: NA
Text: Act which provides workers' compensation for

Speaker: NA
Text: employees of the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: its statutory authorities. This legislation was

Speaker: NA
Text: amended for this purpose during the 1976

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget session of the Parliament. Since then

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been significant increases in the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of living and in the benefits payable under the

Speaker: NA
Text: arworkers' compensation legislation in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania and

Speaker: NA
Text: while legislation is pending in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is therefore necessary that the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Compensation (Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Employees) Act should again be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation for Total Incapacity

Speaker: NA
Text: Employees who have been injured in activities

Speaker: NA
Text: connected with their work are entitled to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly compensation payments equal to their

Speaker: NA
Text: normal full sick pay rate during the first 26

Speaker: NA
Text: of total incapacity for work. For long term cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: where total incapacity has exceeded 26 weeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: the compensation is based on fixed weekly rates

Speaker: NA
Text: that are specified in the Act. Under the Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed weekly rate for a totally incapacitated

Speaker: NA
Text: ployee without dependants will increase from

Speaker: NA
Text: $80 to $90. The additional weekly supplement legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: for a dependent spouse will increase from $21

Speaker: NA
Text: $23.60 and the weekly supplement for each depensions

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent child will increase from $ 10 to $ 11.25.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation for Partial Incapacity

Speaker: NA
Text: A similar increase, from $80 to $90 a week,

Speaker: NA
Text: will also apply to the ceiling which operates

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to the compensation payable for partial

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation for Death

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill also provides for increases in the

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of compensation payable where an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: jury results in the death of an employee. The

Speaker: NA
Text: basic lump sum payable to dependants will in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease from $25,000 to $28,000. The weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: amount payable in respect from $10 to $11.25

Speaker: NA
Text: and the minimum total amount payable for each

Speaker: NA
Text: child will increase from $1,000 to $1,125.

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum amount payable in respect of funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses will increase from $650 to $730.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation for Specified Losses

Speaker: NA
Text: The lump sums payable under the Act for

Speaker: NA
Text: specified losses will also increase. The maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: lump sum payment for such a loss will increase

Speaker: NA
Text: from $25,000 to $28,000 in the same proportion.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, payments for severe and permaother

Speaker: NA
Text: nent facial disfigurement will increase from

Speaker: NA
Text: $12,500 to $14,000 and compensation for loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sense of taste or smell will increase from

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Increases

Speaker: NA
Text: The maximum amount payable for alterations

Speaker: NA
Text: to buildings or vehicles, or repair or replacement

Speaker: NA
Text: of certain aids and appliances, will go up from adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: $700 to $780. However, clause 7 of the Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: allow the Commissioner for Employees Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation to approve payments beyond this limit

Speaker: NA
Text: where he is satisfied that the circumstances of the

Speaker: NA
Text: case would justify an increased payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: The opportunity has also been taken to make

Speaker: NA
Text: other amendments of a relatively minor nature.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thefirstof these, in clause 3 of the Bill, increases

Speaker: NA
Text: the upper age limit for a dependent student child

Speaker: NA
Text: from 21 years to 25 years, standardising the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of a student child in Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation legislation with that applicable

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks under the Social Services Act. The amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: in clauses 4 and 5 will clarify the application of

Speaker: NA
Text: offsetting provisions of the principal Act to em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees of Commonwealth authorities and of the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory administration where invalid

Speaker: NA
Text: empensions are payable for the same injury. Clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: 6 and 9 are consequential upon changes in other

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in the principal Act. Clause

Speaker: NA
Text: to 8 will allow partial invalidity superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: to be taken into account in calculating

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation entitlements. The amendments in

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses 10, 11, 12 and 13 will facilitate handling

Speaker: NA
Text: of requests for reference to a compensation tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bunal for reconsideration of a compensation de-

Speaker: NA
Text: in retermination. The amendment in clause 14 is

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsequent on the amendments in clause 15

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides for references of questions of law

Speaker: NA
Text: from a compensation tribunal or a prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: court to the Federal Court of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Application of Amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill provides that the increases in monet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary benefits come into operation on 1 September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1979. All other amendments will come into oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation on the day the Act receives the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: The Assent. The Bill also contains the usual pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions for the increased weekly payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply from 1 September 1979, notwithstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: the the payments relate to an injury sustained be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore that date. The increased lump sums for

Speaker: NA
Text: death and specified losses will also apply from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1979 in all cases where the death

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs or the loss is suffered after that date, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though the death or loss may have resulted from

Speaker: NA
Text: an injury sustained before that date. Increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits will apply in a similar way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cost of Increased Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: The total cost of the increased benefits author-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised by the Bill is estimated to exceed $ 1 m in a

Speaker: NA
Text: full year. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)

Speaker: NA
Text: SEAMEN'S COMPENSATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Gwydu-Minister for Health)

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main purpose of this Bill is to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: rates and amounts of compensation payable

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Seamen's Compensation Act to sea-

Speaker: NA
Text: men and their dependants. The Bill will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the monetary rates payable under the Act

Speaker: NA
Text: are kept in line with those contained in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pansation (Commonwealth Government Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees) Amendment Bill 1979. I should men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, however, that the proposed amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: will not involve any cost to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government as payments under the Seamen's

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Act are the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shipowners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increased Compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: Under clause 4 of the Bill the weekly compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation for total incapacity for work is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased from $80 to $90 for a seaman without

Speaker: NA
Text: dependants. The additional weekly supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: for a dependent wife will be increased from $21

Speaker: NA
Text: to $23.60 and that for each dependent child from

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 to $11.25. The ceiling wliich applies in cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain circumstances in relation to the weekly pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for partial incapacity is also to be increased

Speaker: NA
Text: from $80 to $90. In addition to the increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly incapacity payments, the Bill provides for

Speaker: NA
Text: the lump sum death benefit, to which the lump

Speaker: NA
Text: sum benefits for specified injuries and maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation are related, to be increased from

Speaker: NA
Text: $25,000 to $28,000. The weekly payment in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of each dependent child of a deceased sea-

Speaker: NA
Text: man will be increased from $10.00 to $11.25 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum total amount payable for each

Speaker: NA
Text: child will increase from $1,000 to $1,125. The

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum amount payable in respect of funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses will increase from $650 to $730.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: The opportunity has also been taken in clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 to make other amendments of a relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: minor nature. The first of these is in response

Speaker: NA
Text: representations from the parties to the Maritime

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Seagoing Award 1975 and operates to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent the application of offsetting provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: the principal Act to make-up provided by virtue

Speaker: NA
Text: of that agreement. A further amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 3 increases the upper age limit for a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent student child from 21 years to 25 years. intended

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in line with a similar amendment to the force

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation (Commonwealth Government government . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading Employees) Amendment Bill 1979 and will stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dardise the definition of 'child' in Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth compensation legislation with that appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cable under the Social Services Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Application of Amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill provides for the increases in monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to come into operation from 1 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 1979. The other amendments will come

Speaker: NA
Text: into operation on the day that the Act receives

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Assent. The Bill also contains the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions for the increased weekly payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply from 1 September 1979 notwithstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that the payments relate to an injury sustained

Speaker: NA
Text: before that date. The increased lump sums for

Speaker: NA
Text: death and specified losses will also apply from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1979 in all cases where the death

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs or the loss is suffered after that date, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though the death or loss may have resulted from

Speaker: NA
Text: an injury sustained before that date. The in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in other benefits will apply in a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: way. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate on motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY

Speaker: NA
Text: INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed from 19 September.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clauses 1 to 4-b y leave-take n together, and

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 5 (Meaning of subversion when not of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign origin).

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause S, page 3, line 5, omit 'ultimately'.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are commencing a debate on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Intelligence Organisation Bill as drafted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. The Opposition is putting

Speaker: NA
Text: forward a series of amendments because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is not prepared to draft the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: other than in its present form. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will give serious consideration to

Speaker: NA
Text: the matters we will mention because we make

Speaker: NA
Text: this contribution in a bipartisan manner. Clause

Speaker: NA
Text: to 5 relates to the meaning of subversion when not

Speaker: NA
Text: of foreign origin. We say that the clause should

Speaker: NA
Text: be amended so as to delete the word 'ultimately'.

Speaker: NA
Text: of There has been a lot of comment on how difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: it is to define subversion. At present the clause

Speaker: NA
Text: in defines subversion in this way:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) activities lhat involve, will involve or lead to, or are

Speaker: NA
Text: or likely ultimately to involve or lead to, the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: or violence or other unlawful acts . . . for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of overthrowing or destroying the constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: Everybody agrees that any act which has the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention of destroying the constitutional govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is subversion. If one gets to the point of say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that an act will ultimately do that, one is

Speaker: NA
Text: really drawing a long bow as to its intent. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the danger ofthe word 'ultimately'. It enables

Speaker: NA
Text: some value judgments to be made about what

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen in the long term. In other words, one

Speaker: NA
Text: could imagine that each and every one of us

Speaker: NA
Text: would be prepared to make a prediction but not

Speaker: NA
Text: a judgment. What we are saying is that we want

Speaker: NA
Text: a judgment, not a prediction. The actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: people have to be directly related to overt activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties from which one can form the view, with ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience and appropriate intelligence gathering,

Speaker: NA
Text: that what is intended is the constitutional over-

Speaker: NA
Text: throw of the lawfully elected government. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Justice Hope said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Subversion is difficult to define, but is nonetheless

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . very real, and may be . . . very

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, if the subversion is very real and very

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous there must certainly be a fair amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of evidence as to its reality and the dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of it. To read into that that an. act which is

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet dangerous might well be dangerous in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future requires subjective judgment. We believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the definition of subversion should be

Speaker: NA
Text: centred on the question of the reality of violent

Speaker: NA
Text: action. It can be confined to that. The word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ultimately' does not assist the security service in

Speaker: NA
Text: conducting surveillance of people who it thinks

Speaker: NA
Text: are reasonably likely to commit violent action. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, one would be expanding the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: concept if one made a prediction or took the view

Speaker: NA
Text: that a person may be likely to cause violent

Speaker: NA
Text: action in the future. There would be a lot of sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance of people and a lot of telephone tap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping. There would be a lot of interference with

Speaker: NA
Text: the mail and with the human and civil rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: which people are entitled. Under this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: these rights can be infringed on the basis that

Speaker: NA
Text: people at some stage in the future might be likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to commit violent action.

Speaker: NA
Text: We say that taking out the word 'ultimately'

Speaker: NA
Text: would still leave the security service free to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct surveillance of people likely to use force.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, this would not allow it to conduct sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance of people because they might engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric or have something in the constitution of

Speaker: NA
Text: their organisation to bring about an ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the nature of society. People can talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about new ideas of government. They can talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about a better form of government. That is part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the normal democratic process. The omission

Speaker: NA
Text: of the word 'ultimately' would make the clause

Speaker: NA
Text: much clearer and wouuld centre it on the essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial concept of violence. As His Honour Mr Jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice Hope endeavoured to say: Subversion does

Speaker: NA
Text: mean overthrow and ruin; it does have a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to activity associated with the immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: overthrow of a government. One could get to the

Speaker: NA
Text: point where somebody might say: ' I think that in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future I will run a campaign to get rid of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that we have at present'. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric or a platform about which people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can form a judgment. If the person

Speaker: NA
Text: making those sorts of statements is putting them

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis that it would only happen with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the majority of Australians, nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: could take objection to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: One has to use this definition clause in a most

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient and very rigid way. We have no objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at all to defining activities that would in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volve or lead to the destruction of a consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutional government, but to use the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ultimately' brings this mental decision by

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of ASIO as to how they think people or a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of persons may eventually act. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: like a psychiatrist trying to suggest whether any

Speaker: NA
Text: one of us in five to ten years time will be fit to be

Speaker: NA
Text: here or otherwise. None of us would want to be

Speaker: NA
Text: under that sort of a judgment. That is a judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: by people about other people's ultimate inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. It is on that basis that we are suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that this legislation would be improved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public interest-th e thrust of all our amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the public interest-i f the definition section

Speaker: NA
Text: was limited to the extent I have mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: There shouuld be a definite sanction as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are to be subject to infringement of

Speaker: NA
Text: their liberties without them knowing. This

Speaker: NA
Text: should centre on those people who are likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage immediately in violent action. In our

Speaker: NA
Text: view that would be adequate. It is on that basis

Speaker: NA
Text: that we make the submission in regard to clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. We hope that there will be some intelligent

Speaker: NA
Text: and rational discussion as to why it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Werriwa) (2.35)- I fully support

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks made and the amendment moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lionel Bowen). This provision is so wide that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: singularly dangerous. It is capable of almost

Speaker: NA
Text: indefinite extension. As it is worded, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an excellent charter for the secret police

Speaker: NA
Text: of any state, including Pinochet's police in Chile

Speaker: NA
Text: and the KGB. It is all encompassing as it is. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition is proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: that we remove the word 'ultimately'. By doing

Speaker: NA
Text: that we would at least put some stress back on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider fully the definition of the word 'sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version ', which is far too wide.

Speaker: NA
Text: As it is, it could affect anyone, as we have

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out during the second reading debate. It

Speaker: NA
Text: could affect church groups, civil rights groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: protest groups, minority political groups and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, any opposition party. It could affect any

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian who works with, is married to, does

Speaker: NA
Text: business with, employs, is a friend of, drinks beer

Speaker: NA
Text: with, attends the same club as, goes to church

Speaker: NA
Text: with, is a neighbour of or talks to any member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the groups I have just mentioned. The Bill pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides for a very wide definition and interpret-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of the word 'subversion'. The very vague-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of the definition as it stands also leaves a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive amount of discretion to low grade oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: atives. I stress the term 'low grade operatives' be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause there is a tendency when speaking of ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel that all is well because it has a Director-

Speaker: NA
Text: General of integrity in Mr Justice Woodward.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that many decisions on surveillance

Speaker: NA
Text: are made at a lower level and in State branches.

Speaker: NA
Text: If a low level or low grade officer is given an inch,

Speaker: NA
Text: he will end up by taking a lot more. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: have abundant evidence of that in what Mr Jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice White said following his investigation in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. Very importantly, we have evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of that also in what the right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lowe ( Sir William MCMahon) said.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a former Prime Minister, he would know

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what transpired on many occasions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of our security forces. He said again

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning on the radio program A.M. that he

Speaker: NA
Text: knew of occasions when ASIO went beyond its

Speaker: NA
Text: charter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The product of the kinds of attitudes to

Speaker: NA
Text: version contained in this definition leads to the

Speaker: NA
Text: abuses described by Mr Justice White in his rethat

Speaker: NA
Text: port on the South Australian Special Branch

Speaker: NA
Text: the early 1950s. He said, for example:

Speaker: NA
Text: After 1953/4, Special Branch files assumed a new dimen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of intense interest of Labor opinion and Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: unions. All elected State Labor leaders became subjects

Speaker: NA
Text: index cards, and sometimes of subject sheets and

Speaker: NA
Text: Interest in extreme right wing organisations dwindled

Speaker: NA
Text: insignificance. Interest in moderate right wing opinion was

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually non-existent. Interest in centre, moderate

Speaker: NA
Text: ical and extreme left opinion was the main preoccupation.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we know for a fact by the process of judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: audit, if one likes to put it that way, that ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: has been overly concerned and has exhibited

Speaker: NA
Text: political bias. A former Liberal Prime Minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honourable member for Lowe-ha s

Speaker: NA
Text: hinted that he knew of this when he was Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I believe that we need to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'ultimately' from paragraph (a) of subaccount,

Speaker: NA
Text: clause (1) of clause 5 because, as I said at the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset, it would at least put some pressure back

Speaker: NA
Text: on to ASIO to be more careful when it handles,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it deals with and when it acts under all the

Speaker: NA
Text: inferences contained in this rather wide-ranging

Speaker: NA
Text: definition ofthe word 'subversion'. The defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is unsatisfactory. It needs to be much more

Speaker: NA
Text: precise. I basically believe that we in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: have a democracy which is robust enough to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able us to accept precision written into laws

Speaker: NA
Text: which concern security and intelligence and

Speaker: NA
Text: which protect the rights of every Australian per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son. That is what the Opposition in this place is

Speaker: NA
Text: about; we are here to protect civil rights and to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the rights of every Australian. It should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be hard to compose a form of words that

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantees those civil rights. I believe that if we

Speaker: NA
Text: remove the word 'ultimately' we will go at least

Speaker: NA
Text: some way towards doing that.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: Lalor) (2.39)- I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that clause 5 is drawn far too broadly. In going

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary

Speaker: NA
Text: and looking at the precise wording of that clause,

Speaker: NA
Text: the words that begin the clause, I find they are

Speaker: NA
Text: far too wide. Clause 5(1) reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: For the purposes of this Act, the activities of persons-

Speaker: NA
Text: The following words are in parenthesis-

Speaker: NA
Text: other than activities of foreign origin or activities directed

Speaker: NA
Text: against a foreign government-

Speaker: NA
Text: That part can be left out for the purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: meaning of the clause-

Speaker: NA
Text: that are to be regarded as subversion are-

Speaker: NA
Text: The clause then sets out the activities in para-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphs (a), (b) and (c). The point about the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of the word 'regarded' is that it con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains an absolutely and totally subjective judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: subment. The clause does not say that those things

Speaker: NA
Text: 'are' or 'are to be defined as subversive'; it states

Speaker: NA
Text: they 'are to be regarded as'. What is troub-

Speaker: NA
Text: in ling about this dragnet definition of the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'subversion' and what makes it different from

Speaker: NA
Text: the definition of 'arson', 'theft', 'rape' or any

Speaker: NA
Text: trade other kind of offence is that all those offences

Speaker: NA
Text: of have an objective element in them. In the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: files. arson something has to be burned down. One

Speaker: NA
Text: into cannot say: 'Look, notionally, cognitively, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: left radgoing to regard that as a matter of arson. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, nothing has burned down but I choose to

Speaker: NA
Text: regard it as so'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Shorter Oxford English Dictionary has an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously long definition of the word 'regard'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not inflict the whole of that definition on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee, but the essential sections of it

Speaker: NA
Text: are: To take notice of; to pay attention to; to give

Speaker: NA
Text: the heed to. Synonyms for 'regard' are: Repute,

Speaker: NA
Text: or estimation. We are not even saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that subversion consists of a particular matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The definition simply refers to activities which

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be regarded subjectively, in somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: else's judgment, as subversion. That is far from

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that it is subversion, that it is to be defined

Speaker: NA
Text: as a particular offence. The clause goes on to

Speaker: NA
Text: state in paragraph (a):

Speaker: NA
Text: activities that involve . . . or are intended or

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately to involve or lead to . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The point again is that that puts in an extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: subjective judgment, because the word 'ultiMinister

Speaker: NA
Text: mately' might mean 100 years, 150 years or 200

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and that could lead to such an extraordiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: narily cautious or repressive view being taken of

Speaker: NA
Text: what is legitimate or illegitimate behaviour that

Speaker: NA
Text: we will find ASIO's powers being extended in

Speaker: NA
Text: way which I think is quite objectionable in a

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic community like ours.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, I applaud the amendment moved by spare

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Consider

Speaker: NA
Text: the insertion of the word 'unlawful' at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning of paragraph (b), which reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering

Speaker: NA
Text: with the performance by the Defence Force . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: At least by inserting the word 'unlawful' there

Speaker: NA
Text: we have an objective test rather than purely a

Speaker: NA
Text: subjective test. Paragraph (c) of the clause talks

Speaker: NA
Text: about activities directed to promoting violence

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred between different groups of persons. Not time.

Speaker: NA
Text: one of us would not like to see a reduction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of hatred in the community. I have very

Speaker: NA
Text: grave doubts about whether one can eliminate

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred by legislation, as much as one might like

Speaker: NA
Text: to do that. I think that is a futile kind of exercise.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! Is the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member foreshadowing his remarks on the

Speaker: NA
Text: sequent amendments? We are currently dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with amendment No. 1.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: I confess that I have an

Speaker: NA
Text: probably strayed to some extent, but I will

Speaker: NA
Text: about the word 'ultimately'. Perhaps I could

Speaker: NA
Text: a brief example to illustrate my concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: the unduly wide range of the definition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'activities of persons' that are to be regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: subversive. I shall describe a brief incident in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own career. It is the only time to my absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: certain knowledge that my telephone was that

Speaker: NA
Text: tapped. I am not particularly paranoid about

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone tapping, but I will relate one particular

Speaker: NA
Text: instance of which I am absolutely sure. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisanflavourto it because a Liberal MinisBranch

Speaker: NA
Text: ter was involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February 1967, prior to the hanging of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ronald Ryan, a number of people-no t just activities

Speaker: NA
Text: those in the Labor Party but also those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of politics-wer e concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. An incident occurred in the middle of

Speaker: NA
Text: night which made me quite convinced that my

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone was being tapped. The sequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: events is as follows: Around midnight on a par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular night a drunk, I think, rang my home

Speaker: NA
Text: number. At the time a number of us were sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: around there wondering what we were going to

Speaker: NA
Text: likely do next. The person on the telephone suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was only one way in which to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: hanging put off and that was to kidnap a Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: or, i f not a Cabinet Minister, some

Speaker: NA
Text: official or senior member of the Victorian Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: I was not then in the Victorian Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I replied that I did not think that abduction was a

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly useful activity to engage in and that

Speaker: NA
Text: a it was not likely to improve the situation, cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly so far as Ronald Ryan was concerned. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: disregarded that completely. A few minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: later, a friend rang- I think perhaps that I should

Speaker: NA
Text: his feelings and not name him, but suffice it

Speaker: NA
Text: to say, he is a Minister in the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: beGovernment-t o say that he thought that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a senior member of the Victorian parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Liberal Party whom we ought to go to see

Speaker: NA
Text: and that if we went to see him, he might be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to have quite a significant influence on the Prem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ier, Sir Henry Bolte, even at that late stage. We

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that we would meet at the home of this

Speaker: NA
Text: or senior parliamentarian in about 20 minutes'

Speaker: NA
Text: So at, I suppose, about quarter past one in the

Speaker: NA
Text: morning we arrived independently at his address

Speaker: NA
Text: in a Melbourne suburb. Within a matter of sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: onds a police car had pulled up with its siren

Speaker: NA
Text: going and its blue light flashing. Policemen

Speaker: NA
Text: subjumped out and grabbed us. We both said:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'What are you trying to do to us?' My friend was

Speaker: NA
Text: not then a Minister but a State member. The

Speaker: NA
Text: police said: 'Well, we have reason to believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt is going to be made tonight to kidnap

Speaker: NA
Text: talk a Minister of the Victorian Government or a

Speaker: NA
Text: give senior parliamentarian'. My friend, now the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, said: 'Turn it up. I am a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian Parliament myself. It is extremely un-

Speaker: NA
Text: as likely that we would be involved in that kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: activity'. It seemed quite clear to me that the only

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which a police car could have come with

Speaker: NA
Text: particular story at that particular spot at that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time was if my telephone had been

Speaker: NA
Text: tapped. It is clear that this was not an ASIO oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: a ation but that somewhere in the State Special

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria it was thought: These people

Speaker: NA
Text: are probably engaged in some kind of dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: activity, therefore it is necessary to treat their

Speaker: NA
Text: as potentially subversive so far as Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria is concerned and tap their phones. In that

Speaker: NA
Text: the case we behaved with absolutely perfect pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: the priety and in a politically bipartisan way. My

Speaker: NA
Text: friend pursued his political career; I maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: my political interest. But the point is that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was, I believe, a quite illegitimate police inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in what we were doing. That is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that concerns me. That is the only experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence I can speak of where I have been personally

Speaker: NA
Text: interfered with. But I do not wonder that there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be many other people in the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement who would be similarly placed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that such action is coercive. I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the State ought to exercise this kind of sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance of people's activities unless there is

Speaker: NA
Text: some kind of prima facie case that there is likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a breach of the peace or some illegal act,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on. Even then, I have very great doubts

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. So I believe that we ought to remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'ultimately' because if we do so it means

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has to be some real pre-supposition

Speaker: NA
Text: that something illegal, something that will dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: turb the public peace, will happen. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to rely on the this extraordinary broad

Speaker: NA
Text: dragnet clause wherein we use the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'regarded '- a completely subjective test.

Speaker: Mr KEVIN CAIRNS
Text: LUley) (2.49 ) - I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is showing an unnecessary fear

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to the word 'ultimately'. Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly I do not understand the concern the

Speaker: NA
Text: position is showing for this word. Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Senate debates, I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: same kind of concern was shown by the Oppodifficult

Speaker: NA
Text: sition there, but it never came through in the

Speaker: NA
Text: stance of the propositions the Opposition put

Speaker: NA
Text: ward for the deletion of the word 'ultimately'.

Speaker: NA
Text: course this whole section requires that there

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment. Since there has to be a judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: about an action which has not yet occurred-tha

Speaker: NA
Text: is what we are talking about; the overthrow of a

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional government-therefor e there have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be difficulties.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn my attention to the word 'ultimately'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me give an example. If a series of actions

Speaker: NA
Text: take place, which on all accounts can be quite

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to one another, but one of which has an

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimate intention of bringing about the

Speaker: NA
Text: overthrowing or the destroying of a consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutional government of the Commonwealth or a

Speaker: NA
Text: State, that can be very different from a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: action whose ultimate aim is not to do that. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me give honourable members an example from

Speaker: NA
Text: recent history. I choose a strike, not because it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a strike, but because it is appropriate. When

Speaker: NA
Text: there were the great strikes on the coalfields in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales during the late 1940s, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister of the day, Mr Chifley, was very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned. We all know that he took a very de-

Speaker: NA
Text: liberate and unique action in respect of those

Speaker: NA
Text: coal strikes. He was concerned not merely be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it was another strike, but because involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in that strike were quite powerful communist el-

Speaker: NA
Text: ements, who made no bones of the fact that they

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to alter the nature of government

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia. So Mr Chifley took quite delib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate action. Going back to the earlier strikes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: great strikes of the 1890s, they were just as effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. They held up economic life in those days

Speaker: NA
Text: just as greatly as did the strikes on the coalfields

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 1940s. But the strikes in the 1890s were

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian strikes about Australian issues and

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no intention to have, as the final end of

Speaker: NA
Text: those strikes, a change to the constitutional pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess within the States at that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those two actions which, on looking at them,

Speaker: NA
Text: could be on all fours similar, could have and

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately were judged to have a different final

Speaker: NA
Text: aim and end. I suggest, therefore, that to take out

Speaker: NA
Text: the word 'ultimately' would destroy that ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity to make different judgments about those

Speaker: NA
Text: two events because different judgments were

Speaker: NA
Text: made by those in constitutional power and those

Speaker: NA
Text: events were blessed with authority at each time.

Speaker: NA
Text: To take out the word 'ultimately', I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: would do a disservice and would betray an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary anxiety on the part of the Opposition. I

Speaker: NA
Text: Opturn it round the other way: If 'ultimately' is

Speaker: NA
Text: taken out and if judgment is to be made as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what would be a subversive action, is the task too

Speaker: NA
Text: to accomplish? If it is taken out one has

Speaker: NA
Text: subto demonstrate that there is an approximate and

Speaker: NA
Text: foralmost immediate relationship between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Of action contemplated and the revolutionary over-

Speaker: NA
Text: be throw of a government of the Commonwealth or

Speaker: NA
Text: the State. If there is to be an approximate and

Speaker: NA
Text: t immediate relation between the two, that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: task that is so difficult that it would be almost im-

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to accomplish. The hurdle would be too

Speaker: NA
Text: great.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I suggest that for sound reasons and with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out having any secondary aim about the word,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ultimately' ought to be left in. If it is taken out,

Speaker: NA
Text: the task is too great and too impossible to prove.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it is left in one can make an appropriate judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment between those who are undertaking a

Speaker: NA
Text: course of action which may have several connec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to it and several gradations of incidents to

Speaker: NA
Text: it, but whose ultimate aim is a revolutionary aim

Speaker: NA
Text: and whose final course of action can be a revol-

Speaker: NA
Text: utionary aim. We ought not to put that prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: osition out of our minds and we ought not to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move that series of actions from others which

Speaker: NA
Text: would contemplate an appropriate judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: being made as to the action itself. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons I suggest that the word 'ultimately'

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to remain in the clause and, in fact, being

Speaker: NA
Text: in, it can be a protection as much as anything

Speaker: NA
Text: else.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: Cunningham) (2.54)- I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that all the clauses up to clause 5 are sympto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic of what is very dangerous legislation. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is anti-democratic legislation because it simply

Speaker: NA
Text: redefines and widens the Australian Security In-

Speaker: NA
Text: telligence Organisation's powers to collect infor-

Text: mation regarding national security. It also legal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ises many previously illegal activities pursued by

Speaker: NA
Text: But I believe also that because the Hope report

Speaker: NA
Text: precedes all of this legislation, it ought to be seen

Text: also as morally fraudulent because it identifies

Speaker: NA
Text: problems and then relies on ASIO to reform

Speaker: NA
Text: itself from within.

Text: the honourable member for Cunningham I point

Text: itself to an amendment proposed to clause 5. In

Text: that respect the honourable member is required

Text: ticular question; namely, that the word proposed

Text: to be omitted stand part of the question.

Text: thought that we were dealing with all the clauses

Text: up to clause 5, besides the actual amendment.

Text: resolved.

Text: preface my remarks regarding the amendment

Text: by dealing with the earlier clauses because they

Text: relate to it.

Text: sustain relevance.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: A11 right. I was saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusions of the Hope report were inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: and, since these introductory clauses also follow

Text: the Hope conclusion through, the legislative con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trols over ASIO will also be seen to be inad-

Text: equate. I believe that these security organisations

Text: 'ultimately' and the words to which it relates. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, I draw your attention to the defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of espionage, sabotage, subversion, security

Text: and so on, and I then move on to the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to clause 5. Clause 5 (I) (a), in dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'meaning of subversion when not of foreign ori-

Speaker: NA
Text: gin', reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities that involve, will

Speaker: NA
Text: or likely ultimately to involve or lead to, the use of force or

Speaker: NA
Text: violence . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The definition is the key to the use of the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ultimately'. The key words, of course, are 'secur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity' and 'subversion'. Any definition of those

Speaker: NA
Text: words is very important to the use of the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ultimately'. In my belief, the key word is 'secur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity'; but one has to examine the question, 'Secur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for whom?' before one can examine what is

Speaker: NA
Text: meant by this clause in a definitive way. The very

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the ASIO beast ensures that security

Speaker: NA
Text: will remain a matter of subjective definition.

Speaker: NA
Text: ASIO lives in the shadows of overseas multina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionals that control Australia and the structure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the society which incorporates the ASIO creature

Speaker: NA
Text: must be retained if ASIO is to survive. So ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: will always oppose political and social change,

Speaker: NA
Text: because such a change challenges its very

Speaker: NA
Text: existence.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is not at all relevant to the question be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Committee. I must ask him to become

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately relevant or to resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: Mr Chairman, with respect, what

Speaker: NA
Text: I am trying to show is that, if we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the word 'ultimately' and what these facts

Speaker: NA
Text: will ultimately lead to, it is obvious that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately lead to a threat of subversion or a

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to security. Surely a proper examination of

Speaker: NA
Text: what is meant there must hinge on what is meant

Speaker: NA
Text: by'security' and 'subversion'.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Th e Chair cannot accept

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's argument.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: A11 right. Thank you, Mr Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man. I will proceed. The use of the word 'ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately' implies the use of judgment, and one

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts the argument of the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lilley ( Mr Kevin Cairns). The question is:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whose judgment? If one reads the Hope report

Speaker: NA
Text: one will see that Mr Justice Hope was not at all

Speaker: NA
Text: impressed by the calibre of the ASIO agents who

Speaker: NA
Text: would be seen to exercise judgment. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members to read the Hope report in

Speaker: NA
Text: that respect. This is the cardinal point on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter: The use of the word 'ultimately' and

Speaker: NA
Text: what sort of a person is making a judgment on

Speaker: NA
Text: what acts will ultimately lead to further unlawful

Speaker: NA
Text: acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, if honourable members read

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hope report they will see that Mr Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: Hope did not have any confidence in the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: of employees of ASIO to reach such judgments.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why, during the late 1960s and early

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970s we had the spectacle of ASIO agents

Speaker: NA
Text: placing under surveillance people who marched

Speaker: NA
Text: in anti-Vietnam demonstrations-clergymen ,

Speaker: NA
Text: involve or lead to, or are intended

Speaker: NA
Text: academics and trade union leaders-becaus e in

Speaker: NA
Text: their judgment those actions were ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: bound to lead to threats against security and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituted subversion. When the record of ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: agents is considered, I suggest that one can have

Speaker: NA
Text: no confidence in their judgment on these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we can have no confidence in the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to make those judgments, then obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously any word such as 'ultimately' ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: removed since the legislation needs to be as clear

Speaker: NA
Text: and definitive as possible.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Dundas) (3.2)-What has

Speaker: NA
Text: been suggested by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham ( Mr West) is absolute nonsense.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact of the matter is that the people who he is

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting should not make a judgment in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to the word 'ultimately' are called upon to

Speaker: NA
Text: make all sorts of other judgments in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other definitions in this clause. Those definitions

Speaker: NA
Text: are quite sweeping. They include an assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the following:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities that involve, will involve or lead to, or are

Speaker: NA
Text: or likely-

Speaker: NA
Text: Without the word 'ultimately'-

Speaker: NA
Text: to involve or lead to, the use

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful acts . . . for the purpose of overthrowing or

Speaker: NA
Text: destroying the constitutional government of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth or of a State or Territory;

Speaker: NA
Text: The people who he is suggesting should not do it

Speaker: NA
Text: in case of that one word 'ultimately' are the

Text: people who are going to be making the sweeping

Speaker: NA
Text: judgments, as he alleges, in relation to the bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of that clause and in relation to the whole

Text: scheme of this legislation. If he is not prepared to

Text: why is he prepared to entrust any of these de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions to those personnel? Obviously he is pre-

Text: pared to trust them to make those decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise he would have voted against the whole

Text: scheme of the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carlton-Whic h he will do in Committee.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: I am not certain about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members opposite have indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: general acceptance of the scheme of the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and the honourable member has accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: that by his votes to date. If he is going to vote in a

Text: different way, if he is going to oppose the clause

Text: entirely and vote against the legislation entirely,

Speaker: NA
Text: that may be another matter. The word 'ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately' was dealt with by the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Durack) in another place and it is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps timely that I read out why the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that this word is important. I quote from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate Hansard, where the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General is recorded as saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government believes that anybody or any organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation which believes in and has a commitment to the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: force or violence at some future stage, even though it may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be engaged in such activities at the moment or may not

Speaker: NA
Text: even intend to engage in them in the near future, for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses of overthrowing the constitutional Government of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country should be regarded as subversive and should be kept

Speaker: NA
Text: under surveillance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme of this legislation does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: anything more than that the security organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation will obtain, correlate and evaluate intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence relevant to security. So, in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'subversion', again all the personnel are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing is obtaining, correlating and evaluating

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: What honourable members opposite are sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gesting is that, because we use the word 'ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately' in relation to our definition of acts that

Speaker: NA
Text: might lead to the overthrowing of our consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutional government, that is an extension of a

Speaker: NA
Text: power which gives an organisation a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: control over the events of men and their lives. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course that is not the case. The scheme of this

Speaker: NA
Text: intended legislation is to establish an organisation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply going to correlate, evaluate and collect in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation. I hasten to suggest to honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: of force or violence or other un-

Speaker: NA
Text: members that, when we are looking at what or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisations say they might want to do and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps looking at their constitutions, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty that they will tell us in an obvious way

Speaker: NA
Text: at all times that their intention is subversive.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have only to look at the Communist par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in Europe at the moment. The Italian Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist Party seems to be putting aside its objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives which it has had for a long time-wit h other

Speaker: NA
Text: Communist parties-ultimatel y to overthrow our

Speaker: NA
Text: systems of government. Now it has changed its

Speaker: NA
Text: tack. It is saying that it is not so concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: this objective because it wants to win an election.

Speaker: NA
Text: At least we ought to have an awareness of what

Speaker: NA
Text: these parties are about. In making our judgments

Speaker: NA
Text: are we not entitled to look at what ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: might be their purpose and objective? Now they

Speaker: NA
Text: might be saying that they are not interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: doing such a thing. It was and maybe still is in

Speaker: NA
Text: their platforms but they are putting that objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive aside to create a facade, an image of moder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. Should we put aside such considerations

Speaker: NA
Text: and not be cautious when looking at what

Speaker: NA
Text: governments are doing? How can anyone have

Speaker: NA
Text: any objection to a little caution?

Speaker: NA
Text: All that is provided for in this legislation is the

Speaker: NA
Text: collecting of information-obtainin g it, correlat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it and evaluating it according to the functions

Speaker: NA
Text: set out in clause 17. That is the important test.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is all the Organisation is required to to. The

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'security' is defined in the Bill. Clause 5

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to qualify that definition. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme of it. It ought to be obvious to all honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members that this is not an unreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: provision. In my view it is certainly not some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that can be categorised in the broad and

Speaker: NA
Text: sweeping way that it has been categorised by

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite. In my view and

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment the clause is deserving of the support

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Committee.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: Batman) (3.7)- I support the ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gument that has been put by various members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition with regard to this clause. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: concern is expressed in this context: Throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of Australia's history as a nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-occupied with the question of so-called sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version. I shall quote some of the final sentences

Text: of Richard Hall's book on security services

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause. Referring to domestic security, he

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: It must reject the whole obsession about subversion

Speaker: NA
Text: vated over the past two generations. A free society can and

Speaker: NA
Text: should suppress violence but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is no longer a free society.

Text: text of the clause I think one is simply trying

Text: been the experience of people who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ciety as being involved in actions or movements

Text: tered so often in the past. This

Text: mental respects, and those people who might

Speaker: NA
Text: will involve or lead to, or are intended or likely

Text: ultimately to involve or lead to the use of force'.

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the use of the word 'force' as an

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional word to the word 'violence' is open to

Speaker: NA
Text: some question.

Text: I had a look at the dictionary of the honourspoke

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Lalor ( Mr Barry Jones) and I

Text: saw that one of the definitions of the word 'force'

Speaker: NA
Text: is simply to exert one's strengths to the utmost.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people in our society passionately believe

Speaker: NA
Text: in causes such as the saving of some rain forests

Text: in New South Wales or the prevention of their

Speaker: NA
Text: houses being destroyed by the building of a freewide

Speaker: NA
Text: way. In my own electorate I was involved in a this clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful demonstration which caused something

Speaker: NA
Text: like 400 police to attend to deal with a relative

Text: handful of local residents whose only concern

Text: was the construction of a freeway that would de-

Text: stroy their homes and pollute their environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brought about that kind of display of force.

Speaker: NA
Text: People got the impression that somehow this

Speaker: NA
Text: rather scraggly group of local residents was a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of revolutionaries. They were pho-

Speaker: NA
Text: tographed on that occasion. They were just

Text: ticular action that was being taken that would

Speaker: NA
Text: have an effect on their homes and on the environ-

Text: ment in which they were living. One can mention

Text: many issues-i n a society which is divided on

Text: many issues-o n which people have exerted

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves to the utmost to defend their

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, to push a particular point of view or

Text: perspective. Surely within the context of a demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: culticratic society that is their right.

Speaker: NA
Text: when it suppresses free inquiry

Text: which it is used in this clause leads to possibili-

Text: to subjective judgment to be made between

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: be constitutional government of the Common-

Text: I tremely important in a situation such as this that

Text: adthe Parliament attempts to get some real consen-

Text: sus on critical terms. Last night when the honour-

Text: had been denied information by the Director-

Text: General of ASIO. That seems to me to indicate

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: divisions of opinion concerning the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: In my view this clause has been drawn too

Speaker: NA
Text: wide. Inevitably it will affect groups of people

Text: who certainly have no revolutionary purpose, no

Text: purpose whatever to change the nature of the

Text: tablished order. Under this legislation it is open

Text: state-t o the overthrow of the government of the

Text: Commonwealth, of a State or of a territory. It is

Text: simply a chain reaction. How much subjectivity

Text: damental change.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the history of this Organisation and it

Speaker: NA
Text: set out in the Hope report. That report refers to

Text: the dubiousness of the evidence collected and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that people's lives have been destroyed bewas

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the existence of the earlier legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The situation is not resolved by this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that in the past this Organisation has

Speaker: NA
Text: used the legislation in a totally one-sided way.

Speaker: NA
Text: has been used in a way which has been directed

Speaker: NA

Text: Stirling-Minister for Employresult

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Youth Affairs) (3.17)-This debate ment

Speaker: NA
Text: today in the Committee of the Whole House

Text: completely justifies the decision of the GovernState

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that this forum-the Committee of the

Text: Whole House-i s the appropriate and best forum

Text: in which to debate this legislation. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting aspect of this debate- I think it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious as the debate unfolds-i s that we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to discern those who do not wish to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: security organisation in Australia at all and those

Text: who simply desire to improve the structure and

Text: substance of the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the honourable member for Lilley ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin Cairns) and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dundas ( Mr Ruddock) for their contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have demonstrated the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: the prescence of this word 'ultimately' in the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of subversion. Of course it must be a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of judgment. From the very nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: subversive acts intended to be kept under sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance it must be a matter of judgment, both

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Australian Security Intelligence Organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation as well as by society, because a mixture of

Speaker: NA
Text: social, political and constitutional elements of

Speaker: NA
Text: the framework of Australian democracy are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved. I think this is an important matter to ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate when we are talking about ASIO.

Speaker: NA
Text: One honourable member referred to the Or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation as 'this beast'. I simply say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cunningham ( Mr West)

Speaker: NA
Text: is that ASIO is not a foreign beast like the KGB or

Speaker: NA
Text: even the Central Intelligence Agency. It is a crea-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the Australian democratic body politik. It

Speaker: NA
Text: established by a parliament of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me also remind him that ASIO began under

Speaker: NA
Text: the charter of Prime Minister Chifley in 1949. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was put into legislative form and given the auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: It ority of legislation by the Menzies Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1956. In 1974 the Whitlam Government es-

Speaker: NA
Text: retablished the Royal Commission on Intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: disand Security under the chairmanship of Mr Jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: the tice Hope. This legislation is the product of that

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Commission. All along the way the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this country has been improving,

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening andtighteningthe framework of

Speaker: NA
Text: Subversion necessarily being a matter of judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, as the honourable member for Lilley has

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, one cannot limit the judgment of

Speaker: NA
Text: ASIO to conduct presently being committed. One

Speaker: NA
Text: must be prepared to look at what is beyond that

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct, the end intention of that conduct, the

Speaker: NA
Text: belief which underlies the conduct, so that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: said that whatever is happening, whatever is

Speaker: NA
Text: being done, has, or is likely to have, as the end

Speaker: NA
Text: the overthrow of the constitutional govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country or the destruction of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutional government of the Commonwealth, a

Speaker: NA
Text: or Territory. I think the example cited by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Lilley is apposite to

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter that we are debating. As he illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trated, a strike of one kind may have no subvers-

Text: ive element in it at all but a strike of another

Speaker: NA
Text: kind, such as the great coal strikes of the late

Speaker: NA
Text: 1940s led and underwritten by communist el-

Speaker: NA
Text: ements in this country, had, one could say, as

Speaker: NA
Text: their ultimate intention the overthrow or destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the constitutional government of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inclusion of this word 'ultimately' in

Speaker: NA
Text: definition is not merely something that was in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind of the Government; in fact, it picks up the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of the Hope Royal Comelectricity

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. Let me, in summary, again point to the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic reasons we believe the definition should

Speaker: NA
Text: main as it is written in the Bill. We believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hope Commission did, that any body or any ortralians.

Text: committee stage debate is that the Opposition

Text: If i may be permitted Party

Text: to speak without interruption, it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant that the people on the Government side

Text: the Cairns) had to say. Of course there was a coal

Text: ditions. We have had nothing but success since

Speaker: NA
Text: have had no more worries since there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: better apportionment of what were deemed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: financial resources derived by mining coal.

Text: I withdraw the re-

Text: mark if it is objectionable.

Text: reply to the Minister for Employment and Youth

Text: Affairs. One person is in charge of the proceed-

Text: ings of this Committee, that is, the Chairman. I

Text: would be grateful if there were no more interjec-

Text: tions. We have listened to nonsense about the

Text: Communist Party in Italy. We do not mind the

Text: Communist Party in Australia. We of the Labor

Text: can beat it every time. We are involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: sigthe trade union movement. We are out on the

Text: in posite only create communists.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman is straying from the

Speaker: NA
Text: clause.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: I may be straying

Speaker: NA
Text: from the clause but I am speaking in reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been said. The other significant point in

Speaker: NA
Text: what was hoped might be an intelligent debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: how we should draft the clause. In the New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand security legislation the word 'ultima-

Speaker: NA
Text: tely' is not used in relation to subversion. That

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation refers to illegal action or action by

Speaker: NA
Text: force. It does not use the word 'ultimately'. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are trying to achieve a proper definition of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version. The United States legislation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: use the word 'ultimately' in its definition of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version. It talks about illegal means prohibited

Speaker: NA
Text: by statute. There is an intelligent way of drafting

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause. I do not know of any other country in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world with statutes dealing with subversion

Speaker: NA
Text: which has drafted such a clause in this way. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the reason for the Opposition's objection to

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without straying too far from the clause, I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind honourable members that they should bear

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind that His Honour Mr Justice Hope said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the most dangerous groups happened to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the right wing radical groups that existed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. They were not mentioned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Members of those groups are also

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Liberal Party of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. We are trying to promote intelligent dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion by the Committee. The discussion will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be intelligent if it is allowed to proceed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which it did on the last occasion. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: no reflection on you, Mr Chairman. You are en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled to make the point that people can argue to

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent of proving what the legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: about. I make the point that I believe in the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for a new Constitution for Australia. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious for people throughout Australia to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to achieve this end. Do honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite suggest that that is subvers-

Speaker: NA
Text: ive? I do not advocate a republican Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: but it will not belong to a monarchy either. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: belong to Australia. It is nonsense to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: people who form groups to talk about a new

Speaker: NA
Text: ideal are subversive. What we are concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about is violence, illegal acts and the possible

Speaker: NA
Text: overthrow of a constitutional government by

Speaker: NA
Text: force. To take out the word 'ultimately' would

Speaker: NA
Text: still leave us with all the protection we need.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have spent an hour considering one clause

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Bill. We have heard a lot of garbage as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what people in this country have to put up with.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hope report clearly shows that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: subversive elements in this country but that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are basically within the radical right wing. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: of them try to overthrow governments in other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. For that very reason we cannot allow

Speaker: NA
Text: certain heads of state to come here. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious to avoid terrorism. We are fully in

Speaker: NA
Text: accord with the principles of ASIO provided its

Speaker: NA
Text: operation relates to our needs. The appendix to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hope report indicates that 70,000 assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments a year are made on people. Is this worth

Speaker: NA
Text: while? Effectively, perhaps only 70 are essential.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to reduce that margin of error. The in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation, once collected, can be distributed

Speaker: NA
Text: right across the length and breadth of this land.

Speaker: NA
Text: As was said by the honourable member for Lalor

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Barry Jones), who watches the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: watch us? Who are the custodians of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves are deemed to be the custodians? We

Speaker: NA
Text: are arguing in simple terms that there is no need

Speaker: NA
Text: to retain the word 'ultimately'. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: democracies, such as New Zealand and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, have not had to do it. We would

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve a better definition by deleting the word.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Dundas) (3.30)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Lionel Bowen) was, to say the least, disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing. I expect far more of him. I expect him
