Text: not to indulge in descriptions of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on our side of the chamber in the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which he does. I expect him to bring greater

Speaker: NA
Text: credit on his office in leading for the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and indicate that he can rise to a higher standard.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sort of innocence with which he has

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken-

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: I t is a normal tactic. Talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the facts.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition will remain silent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Dundas will address

Speaker: NA
Text: himself to the question before the House.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Mr Chairman, through you

Speaker: NA
Text: and in response to the remarks of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker-

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! There is some mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: conception. A Minister has the right to respond

Speaker: NA
Text: in a debate at any frequency which he deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines. Members on respective sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber do not have the right to respond in a

Speaker: NA
Text: manner other than within their ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement, which requires relevance.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: What I am saying is very

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to the clause we are debating. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: just been told that if a person advocates a new

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution for this country or espouses in a

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful way the establishment of a republic in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia he will be in conflict with the definition

Speaker: NA
Text: of subversion in this clause. Nothing is further

Speaker: NA
Text: from the truth. There are three parts to the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition. The first deals with activities. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ond deals with the way in which a person carries

Speaker: NA
Text: out an act. The third deals with the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: the act. Simply to advocate a new Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: does not amount to subversion in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: three parts of this clause. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite have to understand that. A person has

Speaker: NA
Text: to indulge in activities which will lead to the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of force, violence or other unlawful acts for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of overthrowing a constitutional govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Quite clearly, each of the three parts of this

Speaker: NA
Text: clause have to be satisfied. We have to consider

Speaker: NA
Text: what a person is ultimately likely to do and what

Speaker: NA
Text: it will lead to in terms of force, violence or other

Speaker: NA
Text: unlawful acts as well as the purpose of such acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple advocating of a new Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia would not be subversive in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the definition in this clause. The simple advocacy

Speaker: NA
Text: of a republic is not subversive. It is specious of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is or to suggest that we would like to stop

Speaker: NA
Text: his advocating that approach. I am quite happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to listen to his arguments. If he were convincing I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be happy to be persuaded. He has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been convincing to date. That is part of our sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem. We are not trying to undermine it. We want

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at the organisations which do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: in our system. I am happy to talk about organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations of the right and any totalitarian organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations that do not permit people to have their

Speaker: NA
Text: own points of view.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: Ca n you name one from the

Speaker: NA
Text: right?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: I would certainly not sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port any fascist regime. But I will not accept any

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion by the honourable member that I

Speaker: NA
Text: might be a fascist. I would not support any totali-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarian regime that does not permit different

Speaker: NA
Text: points of view. I am equally critical of the far

Speaker: NA
Text: Right as I am of the far Left. I am waiting for

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite to speak equally

Speaker: NA
Text: about the activities of the KGB as they do about

Speaker: NA
Text: the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am waiting for them to look at the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: that organisation in the same critical way as they

Speaker: NA
Text: look at those of the United States organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United States is a country in which people

Speaker: NA
Text: can speak out. They have an opportunity to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: press their concerns. We have the same oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to do so when participating in this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not hear about the security organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: in communist countries. We do not hear about

Speaker: NA
Text: what might constitute subversion in those coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries and about how their people are denied free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom of speech. I do not want to be restricted by

Speaker: NA
Text: any organisation that gives us the capacity to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist movements that want to take that freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: secfrom us, regardless of whether they come from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Right or the Left.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am prepared to support a definition which

Speaker: NA
Text: enables us to do what the legislation will permit

Speaker: NA
Text: us to do, that is, simply to look at those move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. That is all we will be doing. It does not en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able them to be arrested and it does not enable

Speaker: NA
Text: them to be taken in charge. If one goes on from

Speaker: NA
Text: that definition as to what is subversion-becaus e

Speaker: NA
Text: it relates to security-an d then looks at where se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity comes into the functions of the organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation one sees that Clause 17 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) The functions of the Organisation are-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) To obtain, correlate and evaluate intelligence rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant to security;

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what its purpose is. It is to obtain,

Speaker: NA
Text: correlate and evaluate information. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is saying that if organisations have these

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of subversive objectives-whethe r they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make them overt in quite and obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: way or hide them in the bowels of their

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation-w e ought to be able to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: them and be able to know what they are doing. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not see how any reasonable person could

Speaker: NA
Text: object to that approach.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr GILES) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! May I just remind the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member that the amendment aims to omit the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'ultimately'. I am under a disadvantage,

Speaker: NA
Text: having just assumed the chair. Would the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member care to return to the point in

Speaker: NA
Text: the remaining time as to why the word should re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main or why it should be removed?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: The word certainly should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be removed. I have given the reasons for

Speaker: NA
Text: that. What has been suggested in debate on this

Speaker: NA
Text: clause is that the arguments of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on this side ofthe House have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: some way irrelevant; in some way they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been extreme; in some way they represent some

Speaker: NA
Text: extreme right wing point of view. I accept that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member opposite was asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw the remark. He suggested that it

Speaker: NA
Text: evidenced some paranoia on my part in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to security. I found that suggestion offensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite properly the honourable member with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drew the inference. But the fact of the matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: that in terms of this debate people simply want to

Speaker: NA
Text: know, and want our security organisation to

Speaker: NA
Text: know, what is going on in organisations that are

Speaker: NA
Text: subversive. We are defining subversive so the

Speaker: NA
Text: community will know what these organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: are about and what we believe constitutes sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version so that these organisations can be moni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tored and our community and our Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will be informed through the Australian Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Intelligence Organisation being able to do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The word 'ultimately' in this context is de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to give the organisation the capacity to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to monitor those activities, whether the or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation wishes to hide its objective, whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to try to put it aside in some surreptitious

Speaker: NA
Text: way, or whether it wants to indicate in an open

Speaker: NA
Text: way that it preaches subversion. It certainly does

Speaker: NA
Text: not-a s has been suggested by honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite in this debate-preven t

Speaker: NA
Text: people from going out into the community and

Speaker: NA
Text: advocating a different form of democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: government. That was the suggestion. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite were suggesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was some fear that they should not or that

Speaker: NA
Text: they would be constrained not to go out and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vocate a republic and that we do away with our

Speaker: NA
Text: monarchial system. They felt that they might be

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted in some way from going out to advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate, as a result of events that have taken place in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, that there ought to be a different

Speaker: NA
Text: form of constitution. It is quite clear from the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition in clause 5 (1) (a) that they would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be prevented. The scheme of the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: would not prevent them from doing it in any

Speaker: NA
Text: event because the scheme requires the organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation only to evaluate and collect information. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not see how honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: would be worried about that, in any event. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowen) would probably send ASIO a copy ofhis

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches, I imagine, as he is so proud of what he

Speaker: NA
Text: has to say.

Speaker: NA
Text: How can one be afraid of advocating a course

Speaker: NA
Text: like that and be concerned-eve n if one could

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the wording in a way in which the OppoAustralian

Speaker: NA
Text: sition has suggested-o r scared of some organisgentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: ation monitoring one's activities in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: that point of view? The Opposition ought

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the position it is taking if it really be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieves it. I think that is the point of the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst I would not want to be unparliamentary I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that if there is any paranoia in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters it is not on this side of the House.

Text: Mr GILES) - tice

Text: Before I call on anyone I remind the Committee

Text: that the honourable member for Dundas ( Mr clear

Text: his speech on clause 5 itself, which is the meanlook

Text: ing of subversion when not of foreign origin.

Speaker: NA

Text: must allow some reference to that. What I am

Text: anxious to have honourable members do in he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: future speeches- I am at a disadvantage in that I

Text: the Committee why the word 'ultimately'

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: Melbourne Ports) (3.40)-If

Speaker: NA
Text: one were to approach this clause in another way,

Speaker: NA
Text: could any member of the Government say: 'If we

Speaker: NA
Text: were in fact to accept the amendment so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'likely ultimately' were omitted from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, would we seriously jeopardise the functions

Speaker: NA
Text: and the activities of the Australian Security Intel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ligence Organisation?'. That would leave a

Speaker: NA
Text: definition section of subversion which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Activities that involve, will involve or lead to, or are

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to involve or lead to, the use of violence or other

Speaker: NA
Text: unlawful acts for the purpose of overthrowing or destroying

Speaker: NA
Text: the constitutional government ofthe Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that if the clause were worded in that

Speaker: NA
Text: way that would be a sufficiently wide mandate to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable ASIO to properly discharge its respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities to the Government and to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: Mr GRAHAM
Text: Wha t is the difference?

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: I will tell the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member what the difference is. Even though we

Speaker: NA
Text: might want to be preoccupied with the KGB or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Bureau of Investigation, I think our

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility has to be with our own intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation. One cannot judge the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: that organisation in a vacuum or on a basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is going to do or is likely to do in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. One has to look at the historic back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground of that organisation. Looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: background of ASIO, no member of Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: can say that in the past it has not abused its pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: rogatives and has not-i n many cases wrongly,

Speaker: NA
Text: on a number of occasions illegally-jeopardise d

Speaker: NA
Text: the fundamental rights of many thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens. I do not ask the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept my word for that. I ask him

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at all the independent judicial inquiries

Text: the exercise of its functions.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: I will try to simplify i t -I

Speaker: NA
Text: draw that because I know the honourable gentlethe

Speaker: NA
Text: man is making an effort to see what it is all about,

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at from my point of view. I have lived doing it.

Speaker: NA
Text: through one of the most turbulent times in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian political history.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Donald Cameron-Yo u caused it.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: A good deal of it, yes, and give

Speaker: NA
Text: brought it to a satisfactory conclusion; we

Speaker: NA
Text: moved you lot from office in 1972. When I first

Speaker: NA
Text: became involved in politics, the Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Dissolution Bill was one of the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: factors in public discussion. Nearly everybody,

Speaker: NA
Text: even people who just gave out tickets for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party at the referendum, were being

Speaker: NA
Text: dubbed as communists and so on. Communists,

Speaker: NA
Text: by definition, were people who were against the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of the Commonwealth. People were

Speaker: NA
Text: being judged in an atmosphere which, to most of

Speaker: NA
Text: us here now, seems so foreign and alien that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to believe. But it could occur again.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we have embarked upon an almost im-

Speaker: NA
Text: possible task to attempt to define subversion in

Speaker: NA
Text: this way. Most of the people involved in making

Speaker: NA
Text: these judgments are people isolated from the

Speaker: NA
Text: community in many respects. They are making

Speaker: NA
Text: judgments probably from fixations and ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessions and prejudices of their own-a s we all

Speaker: NA
Text: must-an d then they are recorded somewhere. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is true it is not an executive instrument, as I think

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard the honourable member for Lilley ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: beKevin Cairns) say in the course of the debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but insofar as it helps in the construction of ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: judgments it is a very powerful in-

Speaker: NA
Text: strument for injustice. 1 think this clause sets out

Speaker: NA
Text: on an impossible task. I do not think one can

Speaker: NA
Text: subversion. I think one can define particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar acts and that is the best one can do. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: the Crimes Act, the Defence Act and probably

Speaker: NA
Text: other areas where these matters are defined.

Speaker: NA
Text: As mentioned in clause 5, activities directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting violence or hatred between different

Speaker: NA
Text: groups of persons in the Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to endanger the peace, order or good

Speaker: NA
Text: demgovernment of the Commonwealth, can include

Speaker: NA
Text: to a lot of people-al l the Government members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have attacked me so vigorously in the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on. Sometimes I may even have defined

Speaker: NA
Text: in a similar way. I make the point that these

Speaker: NA
Text: are not facts in the strict sense of judgments

Speaker: NA
Text: about people's attitudes and behaviour which

Speaker: NA
Text: out the adcannot be defined.

Speaker: NA
Text: In ASIO, which we are not just creating but

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening in its own work rather than in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's work, we are likely to be marching

Speaker: NA
Text: down a path that will perpetuate injustices and

Speaker: NA
Text: withprobably compound them. I do not know that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community needs that kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: definition. I think there must be better ways of

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with the Deputy Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) that this provision

Speaker: NA
Text: needs reconsideration. I do not believe we can

Speaker: NA
Text: it consideration in this sort of give and take.

Speaker: NA
Text: reThere must be some way in which we can all sit

Speaker: NA
Text: around and finally put on the statute books

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what we mean, if the majority of people

Speaker: NA
Text: think we need to have it defined this way. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not happen to agree that we need to do it. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian society has changed in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 years. It is a substantially different society

Speaker: NA
Text: its ethnic background from what it was, but it is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the few countries in the world that, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: strict sense, has never had a traitor. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: never had to shoot anybody for betraying us. On

Speaker: NA
Text: many occasions people have been accused of

Speaker: NA
Text: having done that but we have never had to shoot

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We have never had to shoot any soldiers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the circumstances, we are dealing with a

Speaker: NA
Text: society that is different from most others. ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: itself was created out of a particular problem at a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time in the late 1940s. I am not too

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the legislation and the actual apparatus

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are considering here has not become an

Speaker: NA
Text: anachronism. Perhaps we need to take a fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the whole situation.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Text: Fadden) quesuons

Speaker: NA
Text: (5.24)- I will be very brief because I cannot see

Text: any real point in taking up the full 10 minutes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the three previous speakers have done, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee stage. That it is happening underlies

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a legislation committee because we have spent

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: vious speaker, the honourable member for Wills

Text: ( Mr Bryant). I say that with respect, because

Text: example his experience when coming back from

Text: the defence of Darwin. I am not sure whether

Speaker: NA
Text: served outside Australia. Did he?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Martin-O f course he did. He was a

Text: gallant soldier.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Text: He was a soldier examine

Speaker: NA
Text: who had served overseas and in the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin. He talked about a train stoppage,

Speaker: NA
Text: strike, when he was coming back on leave. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was a strike and the soldiers had to find alternadefence

Speaker: NA
Text: tive means of getting back to Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever they were going to take their leave.

Speaker: NA
Text: That underlies the quaint, shortsighted approach

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been espoused by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member. The fact is that the shipping of armaKillen)-woul

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to men involved in the defence of Darwin

Speaker: NA
Text: and men fighting in the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: men who were laying down their lives in the

Speaker: NA
Text: name of this country and in the name of free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom, could well have been affected because

Speaker: NA
Text: some stupid shortsighted people back here de-

Speaker: NA
Text: in cided to pull on a strike. As one who is too young

Speaker: NA
Text: to remember the war, it surprises me to learn that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are members of the Opposition who are

Speaker: NA
Text: quite happy to accept that even in that time of

Speaker: NA
Text: national emergency people just went out on

Speaker: NA
Text: strike as they chose. I have spoken for exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: two and a half minutes. I endorse the preser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation of the clause in its present form. I am quite

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the Minister for Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner), who is at the table,

Text: will be rather stunned.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: Lalor) (5.27)- I also

Speaker: NA
Text: will try not to take the full 10 minutes which I

Speaker: NA
Text: have at my disposal. I agree that at first glance

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a kind of'motherhood' element in this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular sub-clause. But if we are to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: that are implicit in the clause as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: drafted, we have to ask first of all: What is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: as 'regarded as subversion'? Sub-clause (b) states

Speaker: NA
Text: that it relates, among other things, to 'activities

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering

Text: with the performance of the Defence Force'. We

Speaker: NA
Text: by then go further and ask whether such activities

Text: have to be unlawful. The answer is no, they may

Speaker: NA
Text: be perfectly lawful. But they are still subversive,

Speaker: NA
Text: on Tueswhether lawful or unlawful.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must admit that it is harder to think in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case, where something relates specifically to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force. At least this has the merit of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: a specific identifiable group of people at

Speaker: NA
Text: the other end who have to be subverted. That

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it much more specific. In one way this sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: clause is not quite so vague as sub-clause (a). But

Speaker: NA
Text: we see that the activities to be covered are

Speaker: NA
Text: an not just unlawful activities, about which we

Speaker: NA
Text: might very well have consensus in the House, but

Speaker: NA
Text: he activities which are unlawful-presumably-an d

Speaker: NA
Text: also activities which are perfectly lawful. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: other existing Acts may need to be broadened.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps some of the state crimes Acts or some

Speaker: NA
Text: defence Acts need to be broadened. But let us

Speaker: NA
Text: a very well informed criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force. Supposing we take the criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: a expressed in another place by Senator Hamer,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, about the ramshackle nature of our

Speaker: NA
Text: operation and how ineffectual it is. If

Speaker: NA
Text: or those words were uttered outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament-the y were certainly trenchantly

Speaker: NA
Text: critical and were very deeply resented, as we all

Speaker: NA
Text: remember, by the Minister for Defence ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: d that be regarded as an activity

Speaker: NA
Text: which hinders or interferes with the performance

Speaker: NA
Text: and in Europe, of the Defence Force?

Speaker: Mr YATES
Text: No .

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: That is absolutely a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of opinion. In this case I would be pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to accept the opinion of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Holt because in many ways he is an

Speaker: NA
Text: old-fashioned liberal. I think his judgment could

Speaker: NA
Text: be relied upon more than the judgments of some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the more rabid members of the Liberal Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: not to mention the members of the National

Text: with unlawful activity, that is all right. But if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about general activities, I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about how broad the dragnet can become

Speaker: NA
Text: by the elimination of a single word. We are talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about onus on proof-abou t whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be taken for granted that the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary citizens are to be regarded as legal un-

Text: less there is some prescription to the contrary, or

Text: whether we say: 'Oh no, we are going to work on

Text: the basis that the powers to be conferred on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: ESTIMATES COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Report of Standing Orders Committee

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I present a report from the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Leader ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: House)-b y leave- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: orders to provide for the operation of estimates committees,

Speaker: NA
Text: be adopted:

Speaker: NA
Text: Committal and consideration in estimates committee:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) After the speech of the Leader of the Opposition, or a

Speaker: NA
Text: Member deputed by him, on the motion for the sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond reading of the main Appropriation Bill for a year,

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed expenditures for the departments and

Speaker: NA
Text: services contained in the Schedule to that Bill may

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to an estimates committee. Such referral

Speaker: NA
Text: (which shall not affect the second reading debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill) shall be on motion, moved by a Minister, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which nouce has been given. A committee may be

Speaker: NA
Text: ordered to report by a specified date.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) There shall be 2 estimates committees, to be known

Speaker: NA
Text: as Estimates Committee A and Estimates Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: B which shall not vote on, but shall examine and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port upon proposed expenditures for the Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance to the Minister for Finance and each De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of State; such report may contain a resol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ution or expression of opinion of the committee but

Speaker: NA
Text: shall not vary the amount of a proposed expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Each estimates committee, to consider each proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, shall consist of the Minister responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House of Representatives for the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure under consideration, together with not

Speaker: NA
Text: less than 12 Members and not more than 18

Speaker: NA
Text: Members, excluding the Chairman.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Members of an estimates committee shall be nomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, the Government Whip or the deputy Whip

Speaker: NA
Text: and either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, the Opposition Whip or the

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy Whip and every nomination of a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee shall be forthwith notified in writing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) In nominating Members to an estimates committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider each proposed expenditure regard shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: had to the qualifications and interests of those

Speaker: NA
Text: Members nominated and to the composition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, the Government Whip or the deputy Whip

Speaker: NA
Text: and either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, the Opposition Whip or the

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy Whip, shall have power to discharge from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time any of those Members nominated by

Speaker: NA
Text: them and to nominate others in substitution for those

Speaker: NA
Text: discharged. The responsible Minister may nominate

Speaker: NA
Text: another Minister to act for him as required.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) The nomination of Members to consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed expenditure of each department or service

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be incorporated in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman:

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) The Chairman of an estimates committee shall be-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the Chairman ofCommittees: or

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) a Deputy Chairman of Committees to be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed by the Chairman ofCommittees.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) The Chairman of Committees, a Deputy Chairman

Speaker: NA
Text: ofCommittees or any member ofthe committee shall

Speaker: NA
Text: take the Chair temporarily whenever requested so to

Speaker: NA
Text: do by the Chairman of the Committee during a sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: of that committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quorum:

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) The quorum of an estimates committee shall be 5, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding the Chairman, and, if at any time a quorum

Speaker: NA
Text: be not present, the Chairman shall suspend the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings of the committee until a quorum be present,

Speaker: NA
Text: or adjourn the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Participation by other Members:

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) Members of the House, not being members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee may participate, at the discretion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, in the proceedings of the committee, but

Speaker: NA
Text: shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of a quorum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minutes of Proceedings:

Speaker: NA
Text: be (11) All proceedings of a committee shall be recorded by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Clerk to the Committee, and such records shall

Speaker: NA
Text: constitute the Minutes of Proceedings of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee, and shall be signed by the Clerk to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proceedings in estimates committee:

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) Condisderation of proposed expenditures in an esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates committee shall follow, as far as possible, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures observed in a committee of the whole with the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing exceptions:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Speech time limits and the restriction on the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of times a Member may speak to each

Speaker: NA
Text: question (S.0.91) shall not apply.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Voting shall be taken by a show of hands; tellers

Speaker: NA
Text: shall not be appointed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Time limits on report:

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) During consideration in the House of the reports

Speaker: NA
Text: from Estimates Committees A and B, the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: period for which a Member may speak shall be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Each question before the Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers-Period s not specified

Speaker: NA
Text: Any other Member-1 0 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Report from estimates committee and further

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration:

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) A report of an estimates committee shall be pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by the Chairman of that committee or a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the committee deputed by him and shall

Speaker: NA
Text: contain any resolutions

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: (15) On a report from a committee being presented, a

Speaker: NA
Text: future day shall be appointed for taking the report

Speaker: NA
Text: into consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: (16) On the calling on of the order of the day for

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of a report from an estimates committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: the following quesuon shall be proposed in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: each proposed expenditure:

Speaker: NA
Text: "That the proposed expenditure be agreed to (and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the resolution(s) or expression(s) of opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to by the committee in relation thereto, be

Speaker: NA
Text: noted)".

Speaker: NA
Text: (17) Upon the completion of consideration of the reports

Speaker: NA
Text: of Estimates Committees A and B the question shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be proposed forthwith-"Tha t the remainder of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill be agreed to".

Speaker: NA
Text: (18) When an Appropriation Bill which has been referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to an estimates committee is finally agreed to by the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, a future day shall be fixed, on motion,

Speaker: NA
Text: third reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: The discussions that were held by the Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders Committee are reflected in the report

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being distributed to honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members. It recommends some modifications of

Speaker: NA
Text: the original draft sessional orders which were cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: culated to honourable members at the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: autumn session. The proposals take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: what I believe is a reasonable compromise be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the concern of all members of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: to get these Estimates committees started, at

Speaker: NA
Text: least on a trial basis, the concern of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to ensure that its program will be

Speaker: NA
Text: completed and the concern of the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that there will be an adequate oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity within the procedures of the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: for members to examine the Estimates in the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner that they believe necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite obviously, our difficulty is the necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Government to provide adequate debat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing opportunities in this Parliament for a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislative measures which are either on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice Paper or are yet to be introduced. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that at the same time, in the scrutiny

Speaker: NA
Text: of these estimates, we must ensure that this com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee system shall work. There is therefore a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of procedures which will certainly re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire co-operation between the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. I can assure the Opposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is my intention to co-operate with it as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to ensure that its particular concerns are

Speaker: NA
Text: met. I hope that in turn I will receive the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the Opposition. I believe that as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result the Estimates committees in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: envisaged could be given a fair trial. Obviously, a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of debates will be held in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: which might make it difficult for the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: committees to meet. Divisions or other matters

Speaker: NA
Text: will require the attendance of members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. It is the intention of the Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business ( Mr Young) and me to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer and to try to ensure that, as far as possible,

Speaker: NA
Text: or expressions of opinion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates committees will not meet when those

Speaker: NA
Text: matters are taking place. Accordingly, it is the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention that there be reference on the daily

Speaker: NA
Text: program to the particular committee or com-

Speaker: NA
Text: the con- mittees which will be meeting on that day. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that honourable members will take note of that

Speaker: NA
Text: program. It will also be possible for them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: an overall idea of when the particular com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees in which they have a specific interest will

Speaker: NA
Text: be meeting so that their membership within their

Speaker: NA
Text: party arrangements can be accommodated.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further motion will be necessary to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement those detailed procedures. The motion

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have just moved sets down the framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: for the The next motion that I will move will set down

Speaker: NA
Text: the particular estimates to be referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committees and the program for those com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees. I hope that some flexibility will be per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted in this regard for, as I have suggested,

Speaker: NA
Text: there might well be occasions when, because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the occurrence of debates in this chamber on the

Speaker: NA
Text: day when it is suggested in the daily program

Speaker: NA
Text: that Estimates committees will meet, it might not

Speaker: NA
Text: be practicable as a result of the discussions be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Manager of Opposition Business and

Speaker: NA
Text: me for the Estimates committees to meet. It

Speaker: NA
Text: could mean that there will have to be some

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustments to the program over the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: the period that we have set down. It is my inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to resume the debate on the Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill on Tuesday so that the Estimates committee

Speaker: NA
Text: can at least meet on that day and, I hope, start

Speaker: NA
Text: the procedure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I presume that the program after that will de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pend a little on how far the House progresses on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other matters before it that are temporarily

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned. But on Tuesday we will return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill and enable the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: committees to commence their deliberations

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I hope, to commence the procedure and

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. If it can be arranged, I will therefore be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving the other motion for reference to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committees later this day.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide) (5.39)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, as you know, a week in politics is a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time. A week ago it did not seem possible that we

Speaker: NA
Text: would reach this stage with this matter. The Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position welcomes the opportunity to experiment

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Estimates committees. We have reached

Speaker: NA
Text: some understanding as to how they will operate.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was not available to us prior to the meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Standing Orders Committee yesterday.

Speaker: NA
Text: We led a very powerful delegation to it and were

Speaker: NA
Text: able to persuade those present that perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition had some right to have some say in

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: It appears that the committees will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: give a great deal more time to scrutinising the Es-

Speaker: NA
Text: timates than was possible in the Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Whole. In fact, some people have suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that the way in which the estimates were dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with in debates previously was really a bit of a

Speaker: NA
Text: joke, given the role of the Senate and the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: winded second reading debate that took place on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget. This will give us a more specific op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to question Ministers and perhaps get

Speaker: NA
Text: answers from the bureaucracy than was pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously available to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not underestimate the ability of my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues on both sides of the Senate, but I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a fair bit of talent in this House as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should be given the opportunity to compete

Speaker: NA
Text: with them. As I said yesterday, I think it is more

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility of this House than of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate to carry out this task. I do not know that

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir John Kerr would agree with me, but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the point of view I hold.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the manner in which we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to resolve this matter in that the two com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees will meet over the period from next Tues-

Speaker: NA
Text: day to the third week in October and both com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees will be dealing with no more than two

Speaker: NA
Text: departments per day with the time allocated and

Speaker: NA
Text: the times for the meetings being placed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: daily program each morning gives all members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House an excellent opportunity to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to arrange their day-thei r party meetings, their

Speaker: NA
Text: House duties, et cetera-s o that they can attend

Speaker: NA
Text: either as a member or observer at the meetings of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Estimates committees and see whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I would urge those honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not intend to participate in the activities

Speaker: NA
Text: of either ofthe committees to go along to a meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and see for themselves whether they are fruit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful in the running of the House. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure of letting honourable members know

Speaker: NA
Text: what is to occur will be beneficial to them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: times set down for the committees to meet seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to be ample. According to advice received from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, the Committee of the Whole

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with the Estimates last year for 21Vi hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this occasion we are to have something like

Speaker: NA
Text: 46 hours, taking into account the time taken up

Speaker: NA
Text: by both committees in looking at the estimates.

Speaker: NA
Text: So ample time is being provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: One problem still to be discussed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House ( Mr Sinclair) is the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of time we will have to debate the committees'

Speaker: NA
Text: reports to the Committee of the Whole. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that that is something that cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: solved at the moment in terms of defining that

Speaker: NA
Text: time, but if the committees do not take up all the

Speaker: NA
Text: time that is allocated to them and if the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment continues as it has for the last four years

Speaker: NA
Text: with the policy of not having very important

Speaker: NA
Text: business dealt with by the House, we will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to give proper discussion to the reports as they

Speaker: NA
Text: come back here. I hope that we can overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter which will have to be the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject of discussion between the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and me is what is to be debated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House when the Estimates committees meet. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has indicated that, if the Budget de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate continues, it will have no objection to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates committees meeting at the same time.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will have to play that by ear and see what

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation comes before the House. If we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider it to be of such importance and we want

Speaker: NA
Text: people readily on hand to come into the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: take part in debates, obviously we would not

Speaker: NA
Text: want the Estimates committees to meet at such a

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Standing Orders Committee also took into

Speaker: NA
Text: account the fact that one of the committees may

Speaker: NA
Text: make approaches to meet outside the normal sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting hours of the House. I do not think that is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely. The attitude of most honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: in this day and age, is that from Monday night to

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday morning is long enough to be in Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: and we like to return to our electorates. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, we have made provision for leave of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to be given should a committee find it

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to meet outside the normal sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: times of the House. I hope we have found a suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful way in which to experiment with a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more reform of the House of Representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reform of institutions of this nature is very slow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless the Labor Party, as the party of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form, has moved quickly to accommodate the

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion put to it by the Government. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will work out. I put it to you, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition feels that it would be in order

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Standing Orders Committee to review the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of these committees. If we do run into

Speaker: NA
Text: problems, perhaps that Committee could meet

Speaker: NA
Text: again and do as it did yesterday, that is, over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come the objections of both sides.

Speaker: Mr YATES
Text: Holt) (5.43)-Let anyone should

Speaker: NA
Text: gain the impression that the Opposition is the

Speaker: NA
Text: sole and only party of reform, I think I should

Speaker: NA
Text: point out that there is a large number of private

Speaker: NA
Text: members on this side of the House who are just

Speaker: NA
Text: as interested and active as the Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: examining government expenditure and in en-

Speaker: NA
Text: suring that the Executive does not exceed itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the reason why, about a fortnight ago, I

Speaker: NA
Text: made rather a violent speech during the adjourn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment debate pressing for reforms of this nature.

Speaker: NA
Text: The framework of these committees is sensible. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that their establishent will receive the full

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the House. It is only charitable that I

Speaker: NA
Text: should say to the Leader of the House ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair) that those private members on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House who have been actively involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking reforms of this sort are grateful. I assure

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that we will play a full part in the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of these committees.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Text: Corio) (5.44)-Someone

Speaker: NA
Text: famous once said that he was taking a small step.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that a more liberal attitude- I use the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pression hesitantly-toward s the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the legislation and Estimates committees

Speaker: NA
Text: are used can help this House to perform the func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions its members are elected to perform. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: functions are twofold. One is to provide a rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentative forum in which to examine and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the case of honourable members opposite, to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the actions of the government of the day

Speaker: NA
Text: and the other is to provide a representative

Speaker: NA
Text: forum of the people of Australia in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the government of the day is under

Speaker: NA
Text: constant scrutiny by the only body which has a

Speaker: NA
Text: realistic chance of performing that role. Because

Speaker: NA
Text: of an accident of numbers some years ago which

Speaker: NA
Text: denied the then government a majority member-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship of the Senate and, I think it is fair to

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the reformist zeal of Mr Justice Murphy

Speaker: NA
Text: when Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and

Speaker: NA
Text: of other members of the Senate, the Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures have changed dramatically over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 10 years. It undertook roles which were the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact one of those roles was the establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Estimates committees which deal in de-

Speaker: NA
Text: tail with the actual line and form of the Esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates. One of the results of that situation is that

Speaker: NA
Text: now we have available a detailed and prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: set of estimates of Departments in muchfinerde-

Speaker: NA
Text: tail than ever existed before. I am not sure

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Departments like that, but certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: it means that a closer examination is possible

Speaker: NA
Text: merely because that information is available.

Speaker: NA
Text: This particular reform will work if the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees function as we see they should. At this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage I think we all have varying views on how

Speaker: NA
Text: they should in fact operate. We are now

Speaker: NA
Text: confronted with the problem of determining the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual method of operation in the very short time

Speaker: NA
Text: that is left before the committees operate. Cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly, I would have liked to have seen this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion accompanied by a motion which would

Speaker: NA
Text: have required a re-examination of the operations

Speaker: NA
Text: of committees after this session of Parliament is

Speaker: NA
Text: over. Then no one could say: 'Well, we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: a look at the situation sometime'. I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: liked this to be a terminal resolution that had to

Speaker: NA
Text: be re-adopted as a fresh set of sessional orders

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to the next Budget session. I again make

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to the fact that the reform of Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should be a continuing process. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that reform is not within the ambit of the Stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Orders Committee whose report ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: brings the reform to the Parliament, but as an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cidental occurrence rather than as an initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: We still have before us the report of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on the Parliamentary Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: System which examined this matter in extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: detail and which carried out its work during the

Speaker: NA
Text: period of two governments. The report was

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately presented to the Parliament when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee was under the chairmanship of the

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the Senate, Sir Magnus Cormack.

Speaker: NA
Text: That report made numerous suggestions, some

Speaker: NA
Text: of which are probably dated already by changes

Speaker: NA
Text: in procedures. But one of the more significant

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations was the suggested creation in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House of a procedures committee. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been on the Notice Paper since March of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year a Notice of Motion in my name for the es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablishment of that committee, although I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: claim credit for originating that idea. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: say, bethat if back bench members of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: who have shown an interest in the reform of Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament take up the cause of that committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: allow that motion to be debated by the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will take major steps forward in the manner

Speaker: NA
Text: in which this House operates. As members ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament we can consider what is the best and

Speaker: NA
Text: most effective structure of the Parliament, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the means by which members of Parliament can

Speaker: NA
Text: best carry out the functions for which they are

Speaker: NA
Text: elected. I have always felt that the best results in

Speaker: NA
Text: the examination of our procedures come from

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members collectively putting their

Speaker: NA
Text: own points of view. Governments of whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: colour have a vested interest in the procedures of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament which is different from that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously the Leader of the House ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair) has a very definite responsibility. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has to keep to the Government's legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: program. The members of the House have a

Speaker: NA
Text: different responsibility. Their responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutinise the legislation of the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent that it is possible and within their

Speaker: NA
Text: power to bring about changes, without unduly

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing the time of the House and without in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: making it impossible for the actual performance

Speaker: NA
Text: of honourable members' duties other than those

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have in this Parliament. This reform is

Speaker: NA
Text: long overdue. Whether it will work will very

Speaker: NA
Text: much depend on how successfully the forms and

Speaker: NA
Text: the procedures of these committees can be estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished without prior experience, and without real

Speaker: NA
Text: prior consideration by the Parliament or its

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I believe that future reforms depend

Speaker: NA
Text: on goodwill and on a continual examination of

Speaker: NA
Text: our procedures with continual recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: on change. I believe that situation depends on

Speaker: NA
Text: the ultimate estabUshment of a procedures com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee and I ask the House to move to that mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter quickly.

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Text: Moore) (5.49)-This is a relanipotent

Speaker: NA
Text: tively small but significant step in the improveat

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of procedures in this chamber. The ally

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber should note that it came from the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of private members of the chamber. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: record and with appreciation I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber to note the work that was done in danger

Speaker: NA
Text: developing these committees over quite some

Speaker: NA
Text: time by a group of back bench members on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House. On behalf of that group

Speaker: NA
Text: thank both the Government and members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition who co-operated in that venture.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Wills) (5.50)- I want to promible.

Speaker: NA
Text: ulgate an idea which will be regarded as a major

Speaker: NA
Text: heresy. In fact, it may well be regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: versive under the terms of the Australian Securview,

Speaker: NA
Text: ity Intelligence Organisation Bill which we

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Preachin g succession, are you,

Speaker: NA
Text: Gordon?

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Yes, that is right. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that I see is that when we start on the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: we look at history. We sit there and drag infornecessary

Speaker: NA
Text: mation out of people and make an input of

Speaker: NA
Text: sort, but that is about all that we will do.

Speaker: NA
Text: time is long past, I think, when the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: had some input into the construction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates. I do not regard that statement as

Speaker: NA
Text: heresy, as do some of my more progressive colwhen

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues. For instance, there are thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people scattered throughout the Australian Pubdo

Speaker: NA
Text: lic Service who for a number of months before

Speaker: NA
Text: the final construction of the Budget have had

Speaker: NA
Text: their input. They draw up the estimates for their

Speaker: NA
Text: little section and it is sent through the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their estimates are analysed at departmental

Speaker: NA
Text: is to and various other levels. Some of those people

Speaker: NA
Text: have been elected to this Parliament although 1

Speaker: NA
Text: am not one of them, of course. When they are

Speaker: NA
Text: elected to this Parliament they are not allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: take part in any sort of discussion like that. 1 do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think it would be difficult at an early stage in

Speaker: NA
Text: the consideration of the Estimates to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: apparatus of departments and Ministers placed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the disposal of the ParUament so that some

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas can be put into the Estimates from the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torates which we represent. This is a collective re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility which we have.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course the final decision about the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities could well be left to the departments

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Ministers. I can see no real difficulties in

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of system at all. I hope that each of us

Speaker: NA
Text: has a more intimate knowledge of problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: the communities which we represent than even

Speaker: NA
Text: the most gifted person in the Public Service or

Speaker: NA
Text: even the most gifted, wise, omniscient and om-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers such as those who are sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: the table. I therefore hope that we will eventu-

Speaker: NA
Text: get around to that sort of approach. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ministers at the table had better agree to that

Speaker: NA
Text: now so that when they are on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: the House again-the y wouid both be in serious

Speaker: NA
Text: at an election-the y will be able to take

Speaker: NA
Text: part in Estimates committees instead of being on

Speaker: NA
Text: the outer. 1 thank honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: I who took the matter up and who have managed

Speaker: NA
Text: to persuade the fairly difficult and incorrigible

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the other side of the House with whom

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to deal at times, for making this poss-

Speaker: NA
Text: They have succeeded. Mr Speaker, while I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that sometimes you might be a bit rough on

Speaker: NA
Text: subus when it comes to our expressing a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: you rapidly called the Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: are Committee together. The firm hand you applied

Speaker: NA
Text: to the meeting yesterday has made something

Speaker: NA
Text: happen in 24 hours which has taken about 24

Speaker: NA
Text: years in gestation. Of course this makes eleph-

Speaker: NA
Text: ants look pretty spritely.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: Bonython) (5.54)-As it was

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday to make a protest about our

Speaker: NA
Text: some non-involvement in the evolution of these

Speaker: NA
Text: The schemes, I take this opportunity today to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate those back bench members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government who were responsible for the evol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ution of this scheme. I hope that in the future

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts are made to reform this institution-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I believe that is necessary-w e will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: that activity at least co-operatively. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: think that this is an important advance in what I

Speaker: NA
Text: see as being a major institutional struggle in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country between the two Houses of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It always seemed to me to be an anomaly

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Senate should have Estimates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees and that this House, which, whatever the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate, is certainly the primary House in the field

Speaker: NA
Text: of finance, did not have such committees.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it was regrettable that when the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Committees for the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: examined these issues, although it recognised the

Speaker: NA
Text: prior claims of the House of Representatives in

Speaker: NA
Text: finance it nevertheless decided against recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mending the establishment of Estimates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees for this House. I think that in making this

Speaker: NA
Text: decision today a minor but significant gain has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made in what we see as being a vital insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutional struggle in this country. Of course, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: now up to the members of this House to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that our Estimates committees work more

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully than, according to rumour do some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Senate Estimates committees.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Befor e I put the question, I

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the co-operation that existed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House in achieving this reform was something

Speaker: NA
Text: that was welcomed by me. The members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Orders Committee were very glad to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the opportunity to play a role in bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter to finality yesterday,

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to stand at the service of the House at any

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 5.57 to 8 p.m.
