Text: on the specific order in which these matters will

Speaker: NA
Text: be dealt with to try to ensure that there is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict with the matters that are conducted in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: (8.1)- I see no objection to this motion. My col-

Speaker: NA
Text: league is not able to be present in the chamber at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment but I understand that he has had

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions on this matter with the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House ( Mr Sinclair). As far as I am aware there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no objection, so I think that we are in agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are ment at this stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY

Speaker: NA
Text: INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: Mackellar) (8.2)-We are

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 5 (1) (b) of the Australian Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity Intelligence Organization Bill to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has moved an amendment which

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to insert the word 'unlawful' before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Comword 'activities'. The clause at present provides

Speaker: NA
Text: that activities regarded as subversion will

Speaker: NA
Text: include:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering

Speaker: NA
Text: with the performance by the Defence Force of its functions

Speaker: NA
Text: or the carrying out of other activities by or for the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth for the purposes of security or the defence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth;

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition seeks to insert the word 'unlaw-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful' before the word 'activities'so that before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation is

Speaker: NA
Text: able to regard an activity as a matter requiring

Speaker: NA
Text: attention that activity should be unlawful. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are a couple of points I would like to make about

Speaker: NA
Text: this. The first is that activities have to be directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to obstructing, hindering, et cetera. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough that the activities simply obstruct or

Speaker: NA
Text: hinder, et cetera. For example, something could

Speaker: NA
Text: happen inadvertently. The defence forces, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of their duties, may be obstructed by

Speaker: NA
Text: something on the road which had got there for

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones-Bu t not unlawful activities.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lalor will please restrain himself. I am coming to

Speaker: NA
Text: that point. The fact is that the activities must be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to obstructing. In other words, there

Speaker: NA
Text: must be some intention to obstruct. For example,

Speaker: NA
Text: there has to be an intention to obstruct the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence forces in the performance of their duty, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just some activity that they may be engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: but activity which is for the purposes of security

Speaker: NA
Text: or defence of the Commonwealth. On the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terpretation of this particular clause there is that

Speaker: NA
Text: restriction.

Speaker: NA
Text: As with all the clauses in the ASIO Bill, there

Speaker: NA
Text: a question of judgment on the part of ASIO as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what is considered subversive under this particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar clause. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Lionel Bowen) has suggested-an d I am

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful to him for raising this example-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: there could be industrial activities which could

Speaker: NA
Text: obstruct the Defence Force in the performance

Speaker: NA
Text: of its functions. One could easily imagine some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing happening on the wharves, as the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member suggested, which might make it

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible for the Army or the Navy to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: materials which may be essential for a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: defence purpose. Therefore the point is that

Speaker: NA
Text: although these activities may not be strictly un-

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful under the Conciliation and Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, nonetheless the Australian Security Intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence Organisation may feel that it is obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: build up a file on those engaged in these activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. This is a very interesting example because it

Speaker: NA
Text: raises quite an important point.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that it would be possible to have a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union activity which in itself was lawful but

Speaker: NA
Text: which was being engaged in with the objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: obstructing the defence forces in the perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of their legitimate duties. 1 think we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be very realistic in our consideration of this mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter because there are certain elements within the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union movement-an d I hasten to add, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore anybody from the Opposition side jumps on

Speaker: NA
Text: me, that they are extreme minority elements-

Speaker: NA
Text: which would not be democratic in their inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. It is conceivable that such people could

Speaker: NA
Text: make use of an industrial situation to carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: activities which were designed to restrain the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence forces in their legitimate activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The situation, in the present context, is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps not as serious as it could be in a future con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text. I draw the Committee's attention to the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent decisions taken at the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Conference in Adelaide. This is quite im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant because within the decisions of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in Adelaide were a number of resolutions

Speaker: NA
Text: which related to the legal position of trade

Speaker: NA
Text: unions and trade unionists. Resolutions were

Speaker: NA
Text: passed at that conference which sought to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: move the activities of unionists from judical

Speaker: NA
Text: oversight in very significant respects. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Committee should regard this with the

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost seriousness. As this legislation presum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably will last for a number of years and as it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: inconceivable-peris h the thought-tha t there

Speaker: NA
Text: could be a change of government, and as the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal Opposition party has decided at its

Speaker: NA
Text: annual conference that the trade union move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will be removed from certain judicial re-

Speaker: NA
Text: straints, legal restraints, it is quite possible that

Speaker: NA
Text: is trade unionists could be in a position of being

Speaker: NA
Text: able to indulge in certain activities which are

Speaker: NA
Text: quite legal under Commonwealth law but which

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly could obstruct the defence forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: their essential duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not drawing a long bow here in any re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect because the principal Opposition party

Speaker: NA
Text: passed at its Adelaide conference a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions which would remove trade unions

Speaker: NA
Text: and trade unionists from legal restraint. I point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that its resolutions are binding on the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary members of its Party. Within that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text, I think it would be essential for a security in-

Speaker: NA
Text: telligence organisation to be able to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: determination of its own as to whether activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: which under the statutory arrangements were

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful or unlawful, were directed to obstructing,

Speaker: NA
Text: hindering or interfering with the performance by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Defence Force of its functions out of other

Speaker: NA
Text: activities by or for the Commonwealth for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of security or the defence of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. I think, therefore, that it is essential

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to retain this clause in its present form.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a secondary argument which I think I

Speaker: NA
Text: should mention. I should think that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: various defence Acts-again , I am not totally

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar with all aspects of the law-activitie s

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to obstructing, hindering, et cetera

Speaker: NA
Text: would be, ipso facto, illegal. I cannot imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Defence Act or the various laws relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the defence forces would allow members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the general population to obstruct, hinder or in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terfere with the performance of those forces

Speaker: NA
Text: when they were engaging in activities for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of security or the defence of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, without deeming them to be acting

Speaker: NA
Text: illegally. To a degree, one could say that under

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause activities directed to doing those

Speaker: NA
Text: things would be illegal anyway. I would not want

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a situation in which a person employed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Security Intelligence Organisation had to

Speaker: NA
Text: think about 400 times whether a particular ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity was strictly legal or illegal before that per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son observed it as something which was poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially subversive.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to retain this sub-clause in its

Speaker: NA
Text: original condition. I do not think that the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's amendment is a good one. In particular, I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think that it is wise to accept this amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, in view of the decisions of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party Conference in Adelaide which

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to remove the trade union movement and

Speaker: NA
Text: members of unions from judicial restraint. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: that decision, if it were enacted by a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Security Intelligence Organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation would be quite restrained specifically by

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause from taking note of activities which

Speaker: NA
Text: could be absolutely subversive because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular quirk of the government of the day as

Speaker: NA
Text: to what it regarded as legal or illegal.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: Lalor) (8.12)-Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: just go through the point about the word 'unlaw-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful ' again, to show the absolute hollowness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument that is put forward. We might be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to solve the problem by putting in a compromise

Speaker: NA
Text: wording. Let us suppose that we changed the

Speaker: NA
Text: wording slightly-absolutel y in accord with what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Mackellar ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Carlton) said. Let us suppose that we changed

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 5 (1) (b) to say that things to be'regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as subversion' include 'lawful or unlawful activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties'. If we say 'lawful or unlawful activities' the

Speaker: NA
Text: real hollowness of the argument comes through

Speaker: NA
Text: because what is being said is simply that activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties that are defined as perfectly lawful are still to

Speaker: NA
Text: be deemed to be subversive. When

Speaker: NA
Text: that way, 1 do not think that there is anyone on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government side who would accept that

Speaker: NA
Text: wording; Government members would say: 'No;

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not want to find ourselves committed in

Speaker: NA
Text: statute to saying that lawful activity

Speaker: NA
Text: too'. But that is the logic of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Ho w about'permitted'?

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: I find that suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: about 'permitted' very objectionable because

Speaker: NA
Text: very often there is a basic assumption that civil

Speaker: NA
Text: liberties in Australia is what is left over after

Speaker: NA
Text: police, Customs, the Australian Security Intellifirst

Speaker: NA
Text: gence Organisation and various other authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: have had their go. They say to the ordinary citithe

Speaker: NA
Text: zen: 'What is left over is yours. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: are permitted to do'. I do not believe that there

Speaker: NA
Text: a single Government member here who would

Speaker: NA
Text: accept an amendment which said that clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 (1) (b) would begin with the words 'lawful or

Speaker: NA
Text: unlawful activities'. If those words were adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: it would reveal the absolute hollowness of what

Speaker: NA
Text: is being done; it would reveal just how wide the

Speaker: NA
Text: dragnet is being cast.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think for a minute that some honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite have thought this thing

Speaker: NA
Text: through seriously. They have taken it for granted

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has to be an organisation which will

Speaker: NA
Text: protect society and that all the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: to do is to say that that organisation has its own

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons. One of the most horrifying remarks that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard-i t is horrifying because of its

Speaker: NA
Text: implications-cam e from the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dundas ( Mr Ruddock) this after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon. I am sure that he did not think it through.

Speaker: NA
Text: His argument was: If people have nothing to be

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed of, what have they to be frightened of if

Speaker: NA
Text: ASIO is surveilling their activities? We could

Speaker: NA
Text: come to the stage where we accept that it is a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fectly normal and routine thing, say, for tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phones to be tapped. I remember going to a pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic meeting in Auckland, New Zealand in 1977

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue and being horrified. One fellow got

Speaker: NA
Text: up and said:' I have strong evidence that my tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone is being tapped; but I do not mind, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause I have nothing to hide. Why should anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: in this society be worried if his telephone is tap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ped, i f the people all have clean consciences?'

Speaker: NA
Text: Once we accept that basic premise and say 'Yes,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is all right if they tap our telephone and it is all

Speaker: NA
Text: right if they intercept our mail. We all have clean

Speaker: NA
Text: consciences. They can do what they like', it

Speaker: NA
Text: means immediately that the rights of the private

Speaker: NA
Text: citizen are annihilated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carlton-Bu t that is not suggested.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: No. I am simply saying

Speaker: NA
Text: it is put in that once we accept i t -

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carlton-Tha t is totally unacceptable.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: I am glad to hear the

Speaker: NA
Text: a honourable member say that. I am glad to see an

Speaker: NA
Text: is subversive element of spirit.

Speaker: Mr YATES
Text: Ther e has to be a warrant.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: I am aware of that. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: once the dragnet has been cast so wide that it

Speaker: NA
Text: encompasses unlawful and lawful activities and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government says 'They are to be regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: the part of the process of surveillance', that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: step towards some kind of police state where

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of the citizen are qualified and where

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of the security organisation are unlimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: you ted; where the Parliament keeps putting re-

Speaker: NA
Text: is straints on itself and keeps giving carte blanche

Speaker: NA
Text: to somebody else. What this debate is all about is

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are honourable members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber who say of themselves: 'We cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: trusted with power; they can. We do not mind

Speaker: NA
Text: limiting our power, but we will give all the more

Speaker: NA
Text: power to them because their judgment is better

Speaker: NA
Text: than our judgment'. What sort of a democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary institution are we if we really are

Speaker: NA
Text: abdicating our rights and saying to somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: else: 'You take them. You go away with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: You can be trusted with them; we cannot'?

Speaker: Mr YATES
Text: Holt) (8.17)- I am just trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: get back to the actual clause. What this operation

Speaker: NA
Text: is all about is something perfectly simple. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Organisation shall have the right, at

Speaker: NA
Text: its discretion, after a warrant has been issued

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to telephone tapping, to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: report on a situation which it thinks is correct and

Speaker: NA
Text: justifiable. Therefore, I agree with my friend, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Lalor ( Mr Barry Jones),

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is an element of trust involved in this,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this Committee has to decide this evening

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is going to insist on not putting in 'un-

Speaker: NA
Text: lawful'. That in itself would not succeed. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would put another onus upon those who have to

Speaker: NA
Text: do the reporting work. They would then have to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider whether they were going to make a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port because they thought that the activity was

Speaker: NA
Text: unlawful.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think that an organisation set up to

Speaker: NA
Text: look after the affairs of our country can operate

Speaker: NA
Text: within that parameter. I understand my friend's

Speaker: NA
Text: objections, but I must come down in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: my friend on this side of the chamber-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mackellar ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Carlton). I do not want the Opposition to think

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are always concerned with the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: of just the trade unions or the very extreme el-

Speaker: NA
Text: ements in the trade unions. We are not. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes involved in a situation in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Act might be called into operation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Services called upon to aid the civil power. In

Speaker: NA
Text: those cases, if somebody obstructs the forces

Speaker: NA
Text: called to aid the civil power, surely a report can

Speaker: NA
Text: be made upon the person who is doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: obstructing.

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Text: Yo u are very prone to giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that kind of thing a licence.

Speaker: Mr YATES
Text: Th e honourable member has

Speaker: NA
Text: made his speech and has given his views. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we paid attention to them. Surely he

Speaker: NA
Text: must show us the courtesy of allowing us to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plain our views. I have done so. The more one

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks about it, the more one has sympathy

Speaker: NA
Text: the point made by the Minister for Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner), and my friend the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mackellar, that to put in

Speaker: NA
Text: the word 'unlawful' would make the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: even more difficult. Therefore, the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very well advised to leave out the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'unlawful'.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Wills) (8.20)-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mackellar ( Mr Carlton) confirmed

Speaker: NA
Text: our worst fears. The moment we come to some

Speaker: NA
Text: form of definition of what we mean here he turns

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian Labor Party's policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: actions of the trade union movement. I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: that in a sense some of the matters we quoted in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vite that. But this shows exactly how the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will go step by step until it has removed all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of protections from people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carlton-Don' t trivialise the argument.

Speaker: NA
Text: You know what I was talking about. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: limited.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: I t was not. As the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Holt ( Mr Yates) put it, we should.at

Speaker: NA
Text: least be paid respect. We have been around for a

Speaker: NA
Text: long while and we have been through much of

Speaker: NA
Text: this activity. Do not let us fool ourselves. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: lived close enough to it. I have had brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: my notice in my time things which I regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: very dangerous to the rights of individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: their future. These things can flow only from the

Speaker: NA
Text: system that we have developed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two aspects are involved. One is the law. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other is the collection of information. I expect

Speaker: NA
Text: that in general none of us is against the collection

Speaker: NA
Text: of information. We do not need to send out

Speaker: NA
Text: spooks to see what is happening in a trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement. We can telephone somebody after a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting to ask who said what about which. On a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of occasions I have met people outside

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings and have said that they could either

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the meeting or be supplied with a list of

Speaker: NA
Text: those attending. We were not ashamed. But that

Speaker: NA
Text: is easy. If somebody driving a train goes on strike

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts are easy to determine. We are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about reports on individuals and infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation that ends up on dossiers and files which

Speaker: NA
Text: may be considered when people apply forjobs in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Public Service or are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered for promotion somewhere in the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: A person's report may indicate that he once be-

Speaker: NA
Text: haved in a subversive fashion. I do not think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to define the sort of things we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about in the way proposed. The Opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally dissatisfied about the protection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of individuals under this Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation provides for the collection of

Speaker: NA
Text: with information and I am not sure that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Security Intelligence Organisation is the

Speaker: NA
Text: best body to do that. There have been instances

Speaker: NA
Text: of people undergoing military training in forests

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere. Apparently that has gone on for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time before being detected. We have only

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at what is happening in the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world to see the difficulty of the problem. The

Speaker: NA
Text: point I am making is that it is easy to go beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the limits of tolerance in these matters and to

Speaker: NA
Text: take action in respect of the activities of people

Speaker: NA
Text: with whom we disagree substantially on some

Speaker: NA
Text: political basis. A person may be involved in a

Speaker: NA
Text: major confrontation in the community. Ten years

Speaker: NA
Text: later after the confrontation has subsided his in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement is still noted on his dossier. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: element of danger. There is no way that this situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation can be corrected under this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: There must be a better way of meeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Werriwa) (8.23)-When the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position's amendment to this clause was being

Speaker: NA
Text: debated in the Senate the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Durack) said that a clause of this kind

Speaker: NA
Text: must be interpreted in a commonsense

Speaker: NA
Text: not find that point of view altogether satisfactory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think we should be attempting to place ganisations

Speaker: NA
Text: on the statute book laws that have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: interpreted in a commonsense way. Legal inASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: terpretation is bad enough. If one looks at this ations

Speaker: NA
Text: clause in a commonsense way, one finds that control.

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-clause (1 )(a) refers to 'other unlawful acts'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet in relation to sub-clause (1) (b) the Governto

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is saying that we cannot insert the word states:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'unlawful'. Looking at this clause in a common-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense way, I do not know why it is all right to thus

Speaker: NA
Text: have that word in one paragraph and not have it case

Speaker: NA
Text: inserted in the other one.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are worried about two areas of this

Speaker: NA
Text: clause. They are worried in relation to the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of picketing, of people exercising their right

Speaker: NA
Text: of protest-fo r example, outside an office where

Speaker: NA
Text: people were being conscripted during the Viet-

Speaker: NA

Text: Force in its carrying out of its functions in respect

Text: Acts, and the Control of Naval Waters Act.

Text: To say that such a person was not guilty of

Text: subversion because the clause requires an illegal

Text: act to have been committed is to say something

Text: which can only be classified as incompetent and

Text: misleading. Such a person would have carried

Text: out any numberof illegal acts which would qual-

Text: ify for surveillance under this clause long before

Text: he even got a bomb together. I think it is worth

Text: ings is not very good. So far they have not been

Text: able to advise a government of the likelihood of

Text: ity and of ensuring that the security organisations

Text: fidence that they are carrying out those functions

Text: ciety are entitled to expect.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat what I said earlier in the day: The es-

Text: tablishment of a security file on a person places a

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious limitation on that person's civil

Text: rights in this country. It denies that person access

Text: to any number of areas of activity. The ability to

Speaker: NA

Text: would seem to be an extension of the inroads into

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal rights of citizens which should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerated in a democratic society. I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister just does not understand the difficulties

Text: of people who are caught up in this type of situ-

Text: ation. He does not understand people at all,

Speaker: NA
Text: judging by what he says in this House. He cer-

Text: tainly has no respect for the law as a protector of

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of a citizen but he looks on it as a ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle to inhibit the rights of a citizen. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate provisions for security forces to insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute surveillance in any situation in which a per-

Text: son is a security risk or takes part in activities

Speaker: NA
Text: which would bring him under notice as a poss-

Speaker: NA
Text: ible security risk. This clause as drafted is little

Text: more than a pretext. No protection is provided

Text: improperly placed under surveillance and

Speaker: NA
Text: against whom a file is improperly established.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no means of audit, no means of notifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and no means by which even the Minister

Text: can be informed of the establishment of such

Speaker: NA
Text: files.

Speaker: NA

Text: Melbourne Ports) (9.8)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: was worried about this legislation when I first

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at it, but having heard the explanation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Viner), I am now terrified. First of all, in the

Text: course ofhis tortuous legal argument he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition had omitted to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: their minds to the word 'directed' as it appears in

Text: the clause. If by implication the Minister is refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ring to activities which are primarily directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: obstructing and hindering, I would agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: him. But if that is what the honourable gentle-

Text: man meant, that is what should have been said in

Text: the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that by implication the thrust of the

Text: Minister's argument is that an activity, in order

Text: to fall within the definition of subversion, has to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fering with the performance of the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force. That is not what the clause says. The

Text: one of a number of ordinary exercises in the daily

Speaker: NA
Text: life of a citizen which has the effect of being

Text: directed falls within the provisions of the clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: If what the Minister is talking about is where it is

Text: primarily directed, then the legislation ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that. That is the real thrust of the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: argument but that, of course, is not what the

Speaker: NA
Text: clause states. What really terrified me was his

Speaker: NA
Text: own analogy. I invite the House to contemplate

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this Minister wants the House and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia to believe-i t is the most

Text: extraordinary argument I have ever heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyer-i s that some terrorist whom we shall call

Text: Boris, could make himself a bomb. He could

Text: manufacture it in his house, wander through the

Speaker: NA
Text: streets of Sydney with it in his Gladstone bag

Speaker: NA
Text: go down to the wharf while the Minister is innoBoris

Text: cently going about his business. The Minister

Text: looks up and he sees Boris who presumably puts

Text: on his snorkel and his flippers and dives

Text: and plants that bomb on the side of HMAS anything

Text: Melbourne. What then occurs? Boris goes off the

Text: wharf, takes out his little remote control button

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is not until he presses that button that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Security Intelligence Organisation can

Speaker: NA
Text: move in and ask: 'What are you doing?'Accord-

Text: finger on the button there is no illegal activity. It

Text: a Minister of the Crown, a trained lawyer, who is

Text: ( Mr Ruddock). Are honourable members op-

Text: stable wandered into Boris's home because he

Text: operation. My word, you have a bomb there with

Text: day happens to see that as a security threat he

Speaker: NA

Text: by the Government for civilian purposes

Speaker: NA

Text: I make the point that in recent weeks there has

Text: movement of that pig iron over the wharves and

Text: Bill for any audit of the actions of the security

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisations. There is no provision for any exam-

Text: ination of the files that are created or of their

Text: contents and no provision for any person to chal-

Text: lenge the existence of a file in his name or to try

Text: to establish that the charge of subversion which

Text: this clause is a charge which is unwarranted. A

Speaker: NA
Text: person acting in good conscience on a matter

Text: which has a content of conscience can, because

Text: he disagrees with the government of the day

Speaker: NA
Text: which has chosen to use its powers in a way

Text: which may be inadvisable but is legal, finds him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self declared as a subversive.

Speaker: NA
Text: An extensive inquiry has just been carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: by a committee of this Parliament into the denial

Speaker: NA
Text: of civil liberties to persons in the Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: The clause before the Committee is not greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: different from the law in the Soviet Union which

Speaker: NA
Text: permits breaches of civil liberties to occur. We, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a Parliament, feel justified in inquiring into them

Speaker: NA
Text: and complaining about them in this country and

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the world. The framework is very

Speaker: NA
Text: much the same. The way is open, in the light of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal incompetence which has been demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated in this chamber tonight, to extending that

Speaker: NA
Text: framework by administrative action and

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Very wide ranging powers exist in Acts which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been passed by this Parliament over a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of years. I point out to those honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who do not remember the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the Crimes Act of 1961 that the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: example which the Minister gave is beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: being ludicrous. It is an offence under the Com-

Text: monwealth Crimes Act and other Acts of Parlia-

Text: ment to approach a defence establishment. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not make fun of the Minister's speech. I am

Text: alarmed that a person who in this House rep-

Text: resents the Attorney-General should make such

Speaker: NA
Text: a speech showing his complete and utter disre-

Text: gard for the facts.

Speaker: NA
Text: orCamerons, the Grahams and the Campbells

Speaker: NA
Text: The wording of this clause is designed to re-

Text: when an illegal act had been committed. An il-

Speaker: NA
Text: legal act can be committed earlier than the press-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of a button by remote control to ignite a

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb. The point is that the Opposition would

Speaker: NA
Text: deny to ASIO the opportunity to keep under sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance a person committing an act which does

Speaker: NA
Text: not constitute an illegal act. I think that in the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ercise of common sense one would say that ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to have the authority to keep under sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veillance a person who is engaging in an activity

Speaker: NA
Text: which falls short of an unlawful act but which is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering

Speaker: NA
Text: with the functions of the Defence Force. So my

Speaker: NA
Text: example served the purpose of drawing out the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and showing the fallacy of its

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Melbourne Ports

Speaker: NA
Text: also said that this clause deals with the crime of

Speaker: NA
Text: subversion. It does not. It does not create an

Speaker: NA
Text: offence; it does not make a person guilty of an

Speaker: NA
Text: offence when he engages in an activity which is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed towards the end result. The clause gives

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to ASIO to keep under surveillance

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are engaging in this kind of activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is always a salutary exercise to invite

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition to consider them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves sitting on the Government side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. What would they say if they directed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force to carry out a certain task in the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence interests or security interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country? Would not the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) or any member

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House expect a Labor government to tell

Speaker: NA
Text: its security organisation to inform it about any

Speaker: NA
Text: persons activities, either lawful or unlawful,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are directed towards obstructing the very

Speaker: NA
Text: function which it had commanded the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force of this country to carry out in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the defence of this country? Would a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government say to its security organisation that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not interested in getting advice on any activity

Speaker: NA
Text: which is directed towards obstructing the very

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose for which the Government had sent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force on its way? Of course not. That

Speaker: NA
Text: points out the fallacy of the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: As this debate has unfolded and as we have

Speaker: NA
