Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.54)-b y leave-Agai n relating to the overall

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of'subversion', I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 5, page 3, line 13, omit 'or hatred'.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the present time, in an endeavour to define

Speaker: NA
Text: what is subversion, the clause reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) activities directed to promoting violence or hatred be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween different groups of persons in the Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity so as to endanger the peace, order or good govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: to. We all recognise that nobody wants to endanger

Speaker: NA
Text: the peace, order or good government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. We also recognise that people

Speaker: NA
Text: who provoke violence are certainly acting in a

Speaker: NA
Text: 32 subversive way. But when we come to this ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: 64 tion of hatred, we get into the mental approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to what we are all about. We cannot identify

Speaker: NA
Text: 32 hatred by any particular positive or physical act.

Speaker: NA
Text: This thing called hatred becomes a frame of

Speaker: NA
Text: mind, an attitude towards a group of other

Speaker: NA
Text: people or towards another country. It can relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to religious differences and to all sorts of unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate human frailties. It is a bit like anger, which

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw in the chamber in the last few minutes. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very much one of those matters which cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be put into legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the Senate, we were somewhat successful

Speaker: NA
Text: because, prior to containing the word 'hatred',

Speaker: NA
Text: the clause had contained the word 'hostility'.

Speaker: NA
Text: were arguing for the deletion of the words 'or

Speaker: NA
Text: hostility'. We did not seem to be too successful

Speaker: NA
Text: because for some extraordinary reason we got

Speaker: NA
Text: of the words 'or hostility' and wound up with

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'or hatred'. For the life of me I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: how the Government, in its wisdom, felt that

Speaker: NA
Text: was improving the situation, succumbing in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way to the oratory of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate or saving the situation by removing the

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'or hostility' and putting in the words 'or

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred'. It comes down again to what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: about. When we are talking about subversion,

Speaker: NA
Text: we want to get the definitions right. The

Speaker: NA
Text: that we want to make is that this definition is

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate and misses what we are all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Activities directed towards promoting hatred

Speaker: NA
Text: within the community may well need to

Speaker: NA
Text: outlawed. For example, there is a federal law

Speaker: NA
Text: which deals with racial discrimination and racial

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred. There are any number of State laws

Speaker: NA
Text: which prevent people from committing breaches

Speaker: NA
Text: of the peace. Most of these laws are products

Speaker: NA
Text: the last century and could well be infringements

Speaker: NA
Text: of civil liberties.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, to have the Australian Security Inful

Speaker: NA
Text: telligence Organisation involved in the question

Speaker: NA
Text: whether people are seeking to promote hatred

Speaker: NA
Text: quite undesirable. For example, in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members put their points of view

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly about such issues as human remote

Speaker: NA
Text: lations, sexuality and the question of abortion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such dicussions can create the most serious

Speaker: NA
Text: tensions between people. The Parliament itself

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in these matters in which an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of hatred is displayed. We can try to

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse it to some extent because people get

Speaker: NA
Text: volved, but we would not dare to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: these people are guilty of subversion. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: point. The expression of such feelings has

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to do with the peace, order and good

Speaker: NA
Text: government ofthe nation, but those who express

Speaker: NA
Text: them exhibit a lot of what we are about-hate -

Speaker: NA
Text: which is one of the seven deadly sins. There

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be a definition which contains what

Speaker: NA
Text: are all about-th e concept of violence. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what this is about. The subversion must be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to a violent act, that is, the overthrow or

Speaker: NA
Text: ruin of a government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 5 is far too widely drafted. We think

Speaker: NA
Text: that hatred is a phenomenon that we can do

Speaker: NA
Text: without, but it has nothing to do with subversion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have kept my remarks within a short space of

Speaker: NA
Text: time because I think this matter is obvious to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody-th e Government included. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate the Government was prepared to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something towards improving this tedious

Speaker: NA
Text: We method we have to adopt to try to improve legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lative drafting, but it seems to have fallen from

Speaker: NA
Text: one deep pit into another deep pit. How in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rid name of fortune are we going to work out

Speaker: NA
Text: the whether people are exhibiting hatred towards

Speaker: NA
Text: see each other or towards other nations? Clause 5

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be weakened in no way by the exclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the words 'or hatred' in accordance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: in the amendment which has been moved.

Speaker: Mr KEVIN CAIRNS
Text: LUley) (lO.O)-This

Speaker: NA
Text: all matter is not quite so obvious as the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: point member for Kingsford-Smith ( Mr Lionel

Speaker: NA
Text: inBowen), might pretend it to be. This clause deals

Speaker: NA
Text: with activities which are directed to promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: violence so as to endanger the peace, order and

Speaker: NA
Text: be good government of the Commonwealth. It

Speaker: NA
Text: deals also with activities directed to promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred so as to endanger the peace, order and

Speaker: NA
Text: good government of the Commonwealth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition suggests that the words 'or hatred' be

Speaker: NA
Text: of deleted. One ought to have clearly in mind the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of deleting those words. The word

Speaker: NA
Text: which appeared in the sentence previously had

Speaker: NA
Text: been 'hostility'. The words 'or hatred' appear in

Speaker: NA
Text: that position at the moment. One has to be care-

Speaker: NA
Text: that in deleting words such as these one does

Speaker: NA
Text: not make the task of those who have to place

Speaker: NA
Text: is others under surveillance almost impossible.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that there are people who will pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred for the purposes of endangering the

Speaker: NA
Text: peace, order or good government of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: of monwealth. Those people deserve to be under

Speaker: NA
Text: is surveillance. Their activities deserve to be

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed. So the whole clause concerns an incite-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to people to do certain activities which en-

Speaker: NA
Text: so indanger the Commonwealth. I can imagine many

Speaker: NA
Text: cases in which violence wUl be promoted. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: the a danger. The Opposition agrees that we should

Speaker: NA
Text: examine that activity. The clever people do not

Speaker: NA
Text: promote violence directly. They do not get them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves directly involved in violence. The clever

Speaker: NA
Text: people fall just short of it. They may promote all

Speaker: NA
Text: the circumstances in which violence wUl occur

Speaker: NA
Text: we and which will result in the injury to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth that is nominated in clause 5 (1 )(c).

Speaker: NA
Text: One could take an overseas example. One could

Speaker: NA
Text: consider Ireland at the moment. One knows that

Speaker: NA
Text: in certain respects Ireland can be tinder dry in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of a conflagration, and I am not talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about a bush fire. The clever people will not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote violence directly. They know that by pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moting hatred they can gain a certain result.

Speaker: NA
Text: The affect of the amendment proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is the attitude: Such people are not

Speaker: NA
Text: worth watching. They are not worth keeping an

Speaker: NA
Text: eye on. We say that they are. Let us have a look

Speaker: NA
Text: at some examples that have occurred in other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. In Czechoslovakia in the late 1930s

Speaker: NA
Text: there was tension among what I call the Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: manic groups. Some of that tension took the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of physical violence. Much of it was caused

Speaker: NA
Text: by hatred that was promoted among the groups

Speaker: NA
Text: in Czechoslovakia. The hatred that was

Speaker: NA
Text: promoted was as subversive-i n fact history

Speaker: NA
Text: verifies it-a s the actual physical violence that

Speaker: NA
Text: was promoted. The effect of the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed by the Opposition would be to require

Speaker: NA
Text: surveillance of those people who are promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: physical violence but not of those who are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moting the cause of physical violence. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that to produce that kind of gap in clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 (I) (c) would be very serious indeed and that

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be resisted. The Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition spoke for a short time. I will not take

Speaker: NA
Text: my full time. But I would add this: Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: many ethnic groups. People come from overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: with legitimately high feelings and with very

Speaker: NA
Text: great loyalties. Nobody disputes that prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: osition. But situations can arise among groups in

Speaker: NA
Text: a community and hatred can be promoted which

Speaker: NA
Text: would cause, and which would have the inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of causing, an injury to the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The promotion of such hostility or hatred with an

Speaker: NA
Text: intention that I have mentioned deserves to be

Speaker: NA
Text: watched. It should not be ignored. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons I suggest that the clause deserves to be

Speaker: NA
Text: supported and that the proposal to delete the

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'or hatred' would leave a gap that would

Speaker: NA
Text: be impossible to fill.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: Cunningham) (10.4)-Clause Timorese

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 (1) (c) attempts to define the meaning of subin

Speaker: NA
Text: version. The clause, in part, defines subversion

Speaker: NA
Text: as:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities directed to promoting violence or hatred

Speaker: NA
Text: tween different groups of persons in the Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity so as to endanger the peace, order or good

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: In examining this provision two points emerge.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because subversion is a subjective concept,

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is obliged to attempt to define

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kevin Cairns-Yo u have to make some

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: The Government is attempting,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a very loose way, to do the impossible. Subver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion is really not definable because it depends

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the political view in the eye ofthe beholder.

Speaker: NA
Text: Concepts of democracy have been, and still are

Speaker: NA
Text: in some countries, classified as being subversive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Five hundred years ago the idea of the earth

Speaker: NA
Text: being round was considered subversive. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe a few hundred years ago the suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: that the earth revolved around the sun was so

Speaker: NA
Text: heretical that one could have been burned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: stake for expressing it. I do not want to give any

Speaker: NA
Text: history lessons, but perhaps I may be permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: one example. The great astronomer Copernicus

Speaker: NA
Text: withheld for 36 years the publication ofhis revol-

Speaker: NA
Text: utionary work concerning the movement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: heavenly spheres, for fear of joining the thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands of heretics in the great fifteenth century

Speaker: NA
Text: auto-da-fe. So we are trying here to define the

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible; to define subversion is to attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: define the impossible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the Government moves, in a very

Speaker: NA
Text: broad way, to apply that concept to the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'hatred'. In so doing the wording used is almost

Speaker: NA
Text: as stupidly vague as it is in clause 5 (a). How can

Speaker: NA
Text: one legislate to control human emotions? How

Speaker: NA
Text: can one legislate to control human emotions in

Speaker: NA
Text: political situations? How is the word 'hatred' to

Speaker: NA
Text: be defined? This stupid Government really seeks

Speaker: NA
Text: to produce a sterile world. It is really like the

Speaker: NA
Text: world which Jonathan Swift outlined 250 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, a world in which there was no emotion, no

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred, no politics. That was the world of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Houyhnhnms, which he denned in the last book

Speaker: NA
Text: of Gulliver's Travels. The Government wants a

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly-controlled world, as Orwell imagined in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984. But the question is, how would the Bill op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate? In this respect whom would clause 5 (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: cover? Does the Government imagine that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would cover the situation of the Croatians in

Speaker: NA
Text: their hatred of the government of Marshal Tito,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chileans in their hatred of the military junta

Speaker: NA
Text: of Colonel Pinochet, or the attitude of East

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, particularly those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin, who certainly will have a continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to the present regime in Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: under General Suharto? Perhaps it could also be

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to pensioners and their organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: be- which seek to achieve a better deal for their

Speaker: NA
Text: governmembers-a s they did recently in their struggle

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve half-yearly indexation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The domestic group that has the most reason

Speaker: NA
Text: this to hate the Government is the unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: the When one understands what the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing to this group one understands that many

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed people would have good reason to

Speaker: NA
Text: hate the Government and all that it stands for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are they too to be persecuted under clause 5 (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: if they attempt to organise, say, a great national

Speaker: NA
Text: body whose aim is to remove this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: from power? Their leaders would, of course, be

Speaker: NA
Text: put under surveillance by the Australian Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Intelligence Organisation. Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members are having themselves on if they claim

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is not so. The fact is that in this matter a

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment must be made. That is why I object to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Government is doing. Who will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the judgment? We of the Opposition have

Speaker: NA
Text: no confidence in the people in ASIO who will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to make the judgment. The Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: several passages from the Hope report to make

Speaker: NA
Text: his point. I will read again one quote and back it

Speaker: NA
Text: up with another. Mr Justice Hope made a damn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing indictment of ASIO's past activities when he

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . intelligence assessment is no simple or routine ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity but a highly skilled and subtle task.

Speaker: NA
Text: saw little evidence in ASIO that

Speaker: NA
Text: pertise needed wererecognised,or available in any large

Speaker: NA
Text: measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: At page 236 of the report, paragraph 680 reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is evidence to show that ASIO has in the past pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided selected people with security intelligence material for

Speaker: NA
Text: publication. The material provided was apparently drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: from information available in the public arena. It seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: have been ASIO's intention that the material be not

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to it. A propaganda activity of this kind by ASIO is

Speaker: NA
Text: a misconceived enterprise. It crosses the boundary between

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of information, which is proper, and the taking of a

Speaker: NA
Text: ' measure for security', which is not proper.

Speaker: NA
Text: That illustrates the track record of ASIO. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the organisation which this Government is ask-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing us to have confidence in to define the activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of groups of people who might be guilty of

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting hatred against the Commonwealth. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is little wonder that we of the Opposition do not

Speaker: NA
Text: trust the objectivity of ASIO's agents when we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at that sort of material which has been writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten by the learned Justice Hope and, I add, the

Speaker: NA
Text: report on which this legislation is based.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout history man has abhorred the activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of the biased pimp, the lying informer, the

Speaker: NA
Text: intolerant fanatic who allows himself to be used

Speaker: NA
Text: as a weapon of the police state. Throughout his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory men of democracy, great writers and

Speaker: NA
Text: thinkers, men such as Cicero from ancient Rome,

Speaker: NA
Text: Jonathan Swift from England and Orwell of the

Speaker: NA
Text: twentieth century, all feared informers with the

Speaker: NA
Text: clearest of vision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carlton- I wouldn't quote Cicero.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: I will quote Cicero because I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that it will be above your head. In the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence ofthe Roman republic, he once said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Even if these liberators and protectors of ours have with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn from our sight, they have left behind them the

Speaker: NA
Text: example of their deeds.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that that is applicable to ASIO of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in the twentieth century. We cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: trust these people in ASIO to make subjective

Speaker: NA
Text: definitions of a word such as 'hatred'. It is far too

Speaker: NA
Text: broad. That word ought to be removed from

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 5 (1) (c).

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Dundas) (10.13)-In some

Speaker: NA
Text: respects one does not feel that one should be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in the debate as much as one has been,

Speaker: NA
Text: but when one hears a speech like the one we

Speaker: NA
Text: have just heard from the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham ( Mr West) one cannot fail to be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedingly disappointed and with good reason

Speaker: NA
Text: because the honourable member has attempted

Speaker: NA
Text: to use exaggeration to persuade people that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is something sinister in clause 5 (1) (c).

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West-Tha t was not exaggeration; that

Speaker: NA
Text: I must report that I was the Hope report I read.

Speaker: NA
Text: the qualities of mind and ex-

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: It is not a question of quot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from the Hope report; it is not a question of

Speaker: NA
Text: quoting events of the past. It is a question of

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at the words that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has just used in his speech because what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member has suggested is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: words in paragraph (c), which is under dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion and which the Opposition seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend-an d these are the words of the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member-ar e 'legislating to control human

Speaker: NA
Text: emotions in political terms'. No reasonable man

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at the words in this paragraph could say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the legislation is designed to control human

Speaker: NA
Text: emotions in political terms. No one in looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme of this paragraph could reasonably

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that it is the basis for persecution of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals. No reasonable person picking up the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of the honourable member could look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the clause that is under discussion and say: 'That

Speaker: NA
Text: forms the foundation for the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: police state'. These are the words that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: using in his address-emotiv e words-t o try to

Speaker: NA
Text: describe what this Organisation would have the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to do. If one looks objectively at the

Speaker: NA
Text: clause, there is no way that one could construe it

Speaker: NA
Text: in that way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us go back to the clause and see what it is

Speaker: NA
Text: attempting to do. It is dealing with the definition

Speaker: NA
Text: of subversion, which is one of the operative

Speaker: NA
Text: words in defining security. Security is relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is the basis upon which the Organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation is given a precise capacity to obtain, corre-

Speaker: NA
Text: late and evaluate intelligence, that is, to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: information. This clause in relation to subversion

Speaker: NA
Text: refers to activities directed to promoting violence

Speaker: NA
Text: or hatred between different groups of persons in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community so as to endanger- I

Speaker: NA
Text: put emphasis on the word 'endanger'-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: peace, order or good government of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. We have to look at the total scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot just pick out the words that we want

Speaker: NA
Text: to pick out and say that subversion comprises

Speaker: NA
Text: activities directed to promoting violence or

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred. It is not that. The full wording has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at. It refers to those activities directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting hatred so as to endanger the peace,

Speaker: NA
Text: order or good government of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. In no way could any of the examples

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham-eve n if one wanted to give cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence to his argument-involvin g pensioners or

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployed could be construed as constitut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the promotion of hatred between different

Speaker: NA
Text: groups so as to endanger the peace, order or

Speaker: NA
Text: good government of the Commonwealth. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: how far we have to go in our consideration. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a question of just promoting hatred. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: quesuon of promoting it to the extent that it en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dangers the peace, order or good government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. I am repeating that a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of times because I suspect I have to do

Speaker: NA
Text: that to get it through to the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cunningham. The fact of the matter is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are quite specific examples-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West-Wh o makes the judgments?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: I will come back to the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of judgment in a moment. The fact of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is that examples have been given and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the honourable member for Lilley ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin Cairns) picked a good one, of how people

Speaker: NA
Text: can promote hatred between people of different

Speaker: NA
Text: racial or religious backgrounds-w e have seen it

Speaker: NA
Text: in some countries of the world and we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want it here-t o such a degree that the peace,

Speaker: NA
Text: order or good government of a country can be

Speaker: NA
Text: endangered. Who would not at least want to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what those people are doing? Who would

Speaker: NA
Text: not at least want to know what they were about?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a matter of persecuting people, turning

Speaker: NA
Text: the country into a police state; it is a question of

Speaker: NA
Text: finding out that information and making it avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to the Government. That is all ASIO does. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not pick people up in the street, take them

Speaker: NA
Text: off to gaol and prosecute them in the courts. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: merely an organisation for collecting

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Cunningham,

Speaker: NA
Text: who interjected a little while ago, asked who was

Speaker: NA
Text: to make these judgments. Of course, the person

Speaker: NA
Text: who primarily or ultimately has to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment is the Director-General. What we have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard is that that man is a most outstanding indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual. Honourable members opposite have

Speaker: NA
Text: lauded his praises right through this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have spoken of him as having the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities and being a most suitable Director-

Speaker: NA
Text: General. Honourable members opposite take

Speaker: NA
Text: pride in having appointed Mr Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: Woodward. Ultimately, when a judgment has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be made-i f there is any concern about it-i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: the judgment of the Director-General. He is a

Speaker: NA
Text: man in whom we have a great deal of faith. In

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of what the Opposition has accepted with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out offering further amendments, he is a man in

Speaker: NA
Text: whom we have already put a great deal of trust.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can take it funher. Look at the other individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: uals in the Organisation who may have to make

Speaker: NA
Text: some determinations. They are the individuals in

Speaker: NA
Text: whom for other purposes, even accepting the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments proposed by honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, that trust has been placed. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Cunningham is asking: 'Why

Speaker: NA
Text: would you trust that person with this decision in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to whether the activity is directed to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moting hatred? Why trust that same individual

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to activities directed to promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: violence? If we do not trust him in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred, why trust him in relation to violence?'

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that somebody has to have that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility. It is appropriate that ultimately it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in the hands of the Director-General. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course we trust him. The Opposition trusts him in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to most matters, but some Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members are not prepared to trust him in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to this matter. I find that argument quite

Speaker: NA
Text: specious.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are situations which, on the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: probabilities, warrant surveillance and warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: our being aware of certain activities because of

Speaker: NA
Text: their very nature, particularly those directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting violence or hatred between groups

Speaker: NA
Text: that endanger the peace, order or good govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Commonwealth, which have the

Speaker: NA
Text: character described by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lilley ( Mr Kevin Cairns). On the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: probabilities, there are probably many of those

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances. There might be circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: which, notwithstanding the qualifications I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made about the peace, order and good govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Commonwealth, could still be a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more innocent in terms of the description used by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Cunningham. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have to make a judgment as to whether circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances which come within this definition ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be the subject of surveillance. I acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that there may be some difficulty in defining the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, but Opposition members ought to give

Speaker: NA
Text: credit to the Government for the fact that, rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than just talking about subversion and leaving it

Speaker: NA
Text: to somebody else to think about that might be

Speaker: NA
Text: subversive, it has attempted to define it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has not offered any other form

Speaker: NA
Text: of words in an effort to come to grips with the

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of problems mentioned by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lilley. If Opposition members were

Speaker: NA
Text: serious about the matter they would have offered

Speaker: NA
Text: some alternative; they would have considered

Speaker: NA
Text: the difficulties with which we have to deal and

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been prepared to make reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: offers. The Opposition has had opportunities to

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. This is the second opportunity it has had,

Speaker: NA
Text: having in mind its caucus method of making de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions, to proffer alternative amendments. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is giving us the same amendments as

Speaker: NA
Text: have already been debated in another place. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed. It has determined its position. The same

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are proposed. We would like to see

Speaker: NA
Text: some flexibility. We would like the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: take a different position and be constructive in

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters. We might then be in a better pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition to consider alternative propositions. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition were genuine it would offer alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives. I suspect that it is not genuine.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Drummond) ASIO.

Speaker: NA
Text: -Order ! The honourable member's time has ments,

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: Bonython) (10.24)-We are

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing the third of the definitions of definitions

Speaker: NA
Text: subversion-th e one which I find the most the

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect of the three. As it stands at the moment,

Speaker: NA
Text: the definition refers to:

Speaker: NA
Text: activities directed to promoting violence or hatred between

Speaker: NA
Text: different groups of persons in the Australian community so

Speaker: NA
Text: as to endanger the peace, order or good government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: We propose, in our amendment, to retain the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'violence' but to omit the words 'or larly

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred', partly because we find this perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: most subjective and difficult of all the definitions

Speaker: NA
Text: in clause 5(1). With the indulgence of the Chair,

Speaker: NA
Text: I will take as a guiding principle the guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by the honourable member for Lilley

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Kevin Cairns) and the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dundas ( Mr Ruddock)-th e 'Lilley-Dundas have.

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines'-o n how to approach these defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional problems. It seems to me that in their argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments today they have produced three major

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines as the basis for rejecting the amendsupervision.

Speaker: NA
Text: ments proposed by the Opposition. One is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the definitions should not be changed because

Speaker: NA
Text: we must allow an exercise of judgment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another is that the definitions must not be vision

Speaker: NA
Text: changed because we must trust ASIO. The third

Speaker: NA
Text: is that we should not meddle with definitions;

Speaker: NA
Text: rather, we should approach them, in the words of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Dundas, with a little

Speaker: NA
Text: caution. I am perfectly happy to take those

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines on board in discussing this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. I refer first of all to the claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should not interfere with those definitions be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we have to allow the ASIO agents an exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise of judgment. Let me make quite clear the

Speaker: NA
Text: agents about whom we are talking. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dundas suggested a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: ago that all these issues, such as defining which

Speaker: NA
Text: group was creating hatred, somehow would go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Director-General. Quite clearly that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: naive approach because time and again the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions will be made locally by individual agents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and because the definitions are broad enough, or

Speaker: NA
Text: wide enough, then the agent can justify his de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions. Indeed, on this exercise of ASIO judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, even if the Government accepted every

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment proposed by the Opposition, there

Speaker: NA
Text: still would be enormous room for ASIO to make

Speaker: NA
Text: judgments.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are arguing on this side is that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament has a responsibility to be as precise as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible in the definition of the functions of

Speaker: NA
Text: So, even if it accepted all our amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: there still would be a considerable area in

Speaker: NA
Text: which ASIO agents could exercise their judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Opposition is saying that it is the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility of this Parliament to make these

Speaker: NA
Text: as precise as possible. There is then

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of trusting ASIO. I always thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was the conservative parties that had the rather

Speaker: NA
Text: pessimistic view of the nature of man. Here we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a situation in which there is a powerful or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation with, in the Opposition's view, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate supervision. Yet, somehow the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is now displaying an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: optimism that we can trust these people, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: in this very subjective area, to exercise their

Speaker: NA
Text: the judgment in some completely impartial and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps non-political way. All the evidence we have

Speaker: NA
Text: of these types of secret agencies, both overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: and in this country, does not give us confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in trusting such organisations. I suggest that we

Speaker: NA
Text: must use the track record, the evidence that we

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe that we can accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines offered. We are providing inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: If we had much wider supervision

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament would be capable of giving a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater amount of trust because it could then

Speaker: NA
Text: check on how that trust was being exercised.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, because there is inadequate super-

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by this Bill, on the evidence I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe that we can trust the ASIO agents

Speaker: NA
Text: with the kinds of extensive powers that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: being given in this definition of their functions. I

Speaker: NA
Text: again refer honourable members to the activities

Speaker: NA
Text: ofthe Central Intelligence Agency and other re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated secret agencies in the United States. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: activities over the last ten orfifteenyears have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown that they are not the types of organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations one can trust. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dundas this afternoon asked why we on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House always talk about the CIA and simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar agencies; why did we not talk about the KGB.

Speaker: NA
Text: That seemed to me to be simply a piece of parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: san rhetoric. I have not bothered to consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: KGB in this debate because I believed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee was debating the role of a secret

Speaker: NA
Text: agency or a security agency in a democratic so-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciety. Therefore, the KGB is not relevant to that

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration. However, having listened to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate all afternoon, I am beginning to suspect

Speaker: NA
Text: that many honourable members on the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment side do not have a very full or clear ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciation of democratic values. Indeed, if one

Speaker: NA
Text: follows through the implications of some of their

Speaker: NA
Text: statements, those doubts must grow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kevin Cairns-Di d you get the card back

Speaker: NA
Text: at your pre-selection?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: I think that is completely ir-

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant. What I am arguing for is a little caution

Speaker: NA
Text: about these definitions. I think we should be par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly cautious in relation to hatred. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: three reasons for being cautious about the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of hatred as part ofthe definition of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: version. One is that, in a sense, it is novel in that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is not a proposal-

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: M r

Speaker: NA
Text: Drummond)-Order ! It being 10.30 p.m., I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: report progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Administration of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Funds-Politica l Parties: Dissemination of

Speaker: NA
Text: Misinformation-Unemployment-Gilber t and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ellice Islands: Banabans-Senat e

Speaker: NA
Text: Elections-Sydney Football Grand Final

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr MILLAR -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! It being past 10.30 p.m., I propose the

Speaker: NA
Text: question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Text: Corio) (10.31)- I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which is of concern to me, which is of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to a number of people in my electorate and

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be of concern to a number of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. In the Victorian Parliament today, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Geelong East raised a matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects on the administration of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: funds by this Government. He raised the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of what is apparently a direction from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) which re-

Speaker: NA
Text: stricts the amount of funds available to universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in Victoria for the expansion of off-campus

Speaker: NA
Text: studies. This is a significant and growing area of

Speaker: NA
Text: education and one which fulfills a very great

Speaker: NA
Text: need in our society. It is fairly well known,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially by people in Victoria, that patronage

Speaker: NA
Text: is practised in the distribution of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to areas of Victoria. I think it is not un-

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable to suggest that the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate receives at least five times as much in

Speaker: NA
Text: State and Commonwealth grants of funds than

Speaker: NA
Text: any other non-metropolitan area in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is alarming to me in this instance is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is clear evidence that this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: acted to divert funds from an education program

Speaker: NA
Text: which is one of the real successes of the inno-

Speaker: NA
Text: vations in recent years to the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate purely for domestic political purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: People have a right to seek to improve them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves through tertiary education. Many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people doing so are people whose basic skills at

Speaker: NA
Text: the completion of their formal education were

Speaker: NA
Text: such that their job opportunities were limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are seeking to improve their positions so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can fulfil an ambition and improve

Speaker: NA
Text: their position in our society. Many of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: adults who have to gain this education off cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: pus because, quite obviously, they cannot afford

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake full time education as they have to

Speaker: NA
Text: earn their living. The experience of Deakin Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity is that the rate of passes among mature

Speaker: NA
Text: students studying off-campus courses and the

Speaker: NA
Text: levels at which mature students have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake part time courses with success are

Speaker: NA
Text: far in excess of the levels expected of students

Speaker: NA
Text: entering university on a full time basis. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: area of education which is important and which

Speaker: NA
Text: should be maintained. It certainly should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of political interference on a basis

Speaker: NA
Text: which has nothing to do with the relevant merits

Speaker: NA
Text: of the allocation of funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: This follows a matter which I raised on two

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions last week when my electorate was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moved from the list of areas entitled to apply for

Speaker: NA
Text: decentralisation funds from the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a number of occasions during the week, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for National Development ( Mr New-

Speaker: NA
Text: man) has said that if Labor members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place represented more electorates they could

Speaker: NA
Text: apply for a greater share of the funds. As a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: member in this place representing an electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: which was eligible, I know that it is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to comply with that requirement if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister uses his authority to remove an elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate from those areas that are eligible to apply,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think it makes fairly false that sort of sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestion. The allocation of funds not only should

Speaker: NA
Text: be done on the basis of merit but also should be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen to be done on the basis of merit, and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that has accrued over the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years is that they are being applied on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of political patronage, without relevance to

Speaker: NA
Text: merit. That is something which this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: should not allow.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr M i l l a r ) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Text: Moore) (10.36)-In a democracy,

Speaker: NA
Text: no government can coerce its people; it must lead

Speaker: NA
Text: them. If it is to lead them in a direction that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be to their ultimate benefit, it must do so with

Speaker: NA
Text: curate information. Sometimes, political parties

Speaker: NA
Text: of all colours have an interest in misinformation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in that context I wish to say something about

Speaker: NA
Text: the 25 per cent tariff cut. The decision taken

Speaker: NA
Text: some time ago by the then Labor Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut the tariff has had and will have ramifications

Speaker: NA
Text: for decisions taken by this Government and by

Speaker: NA
Text: future governments. That decision was taken in

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1973 and followed a period during which

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's reserve assets had been climbing

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly. In fact, from a level of $ 1,500m in

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1970 they had risen to $4,750m by

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1972. This clearly had inflationary

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for the economy, and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the day had to do something about those

Speaker: NA
Text: inflationary implications. It had a number of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: valuations and it made the 25 per cent tariff cut

Speaker: NA
Text: decision, all of which had an impact on the grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing level of reserve assets and the upward press-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure on the Australian dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 25 per cent tariff cut was equivalent to a

Speaker: NA
Text: revaluation of about 4 per cent in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect that it had on the gross operating surplus. I

Speaker: NA
Text: invite those honourable members opposite who

Speaker: NA
Text: are attempting to distract me not to panic. The

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciations undertaken by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: over that time were in the order of 20 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect of the 25 per cent tariff cut on the

Speaker: NA
Text: operating surplus was relatively minor compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with the effect of the revaluations; but, in any

Speaker: NA
Text: case, the cut was made in lieu of a further revalu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation and there was a revaluation at a later date.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even in the tariff-affected industries, the revalu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations had something of the order of three times

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of the tariff cut, but the wage rises of

Speaker: NA
Text: that time had an even greater elTect on the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fitability of those industries than either the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: valuations or the 25 per cent tariff cut. The tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: cut was equivalent to a wage rise of between 6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent and 13 per cent, depending on how one

Speaker: NA
Text: worked it out. But, in the textile and clothing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries, from December 1972 to September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1974 wages rose by an average of no less than 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-5 6 per cent for males and 73 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: for females.

Speaker: NA
Text: I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: foolish in the light of that information to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the 25 per cent tariff cut was the cause ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment that was apparent in the years

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately following that decision. The unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment was caused partly by the mismanage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the money supply so that inflation blew

Speaker: NA
Text: out but, above all, it was caused by the excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: wage rises. The Australian economy is recover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. We have capital inflow. This is very

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficial to us. We have become far more com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ac- petitive on the overseas markets. Those are good

Speaker: NA
Text: things. But the Australian dollar, if we manage to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve a continuation of those effects, will have

Speaker: NA
Text: an upward pressure. We will have to look again

Speaker: NA
Text: at whether we will increase imports by reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: protection for the import competing industries or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we will merely upvalue the dollar. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would be pity if these decisions were taken in the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of misinformation instead of accurate

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: Albert Ellis of the Pacific Islands Company per-

Speaker: NA
Text: suaded two Banabans to place their marks on a

Speaker: NA
Text: paper conceding to the company sole rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean Island-Banaba-phosphat e for 999 years

Speaker: NA
Text: for the payment of 50 per annum. He raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: Union Jack, and Banaba was annexed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire. Such was the inspiration of membership

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Empire that in 1916 all 500 Banabans

Speaker: NA
Text: donated 10,000 worth of copra to the war

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. Britain repaid this by making Banaba part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands colony, without

Speaker: NA
Text: informing or consulting the people. In 1927

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and New Zealand joined with Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: in the British Phosphate Commission and asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Banabans for more land to mine for phos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phate, but the Banabans refused. In 1928 the col-

Speaker: NA
Text: onial administradon forced the signing of leases

Speaker: NA
Text: gross on the threat that the land would be taken any-

Speaker: NA
Text: way for the empire, and their villages destroyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Continued refusal led to the land being compul-

Speaker: NA
Text: sorily purchased by the colony they did not ask

Speaker: NA
Text: to join.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amazingly the Banabans loyally donated

Speaker: NA
Text: 512,500 to British war funds in 1940. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarded by the British abandoning them to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese, who deponed the majority as slave

Speaker: NA
Text: labour, and shot the 150 remaining, except for

Speaker: NA
Text: one survivor. In 1945, they asked to be allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: to return to their home, but were told this was

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible because of war damage, and were re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moved 1,400 miles away to Rabi in the Fiji

Speaker: NA
Text: islands. Within weeks of their arrival on Rabi,

Speaker: NA
Text: the BPC was recruiting Gilbertese to work on the

Speaker: NA
Text: phosphate and providing them with accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation. In 1947 loyalty prompted the Banabans

Speaker: NA
Text: on Rabi to donate 500 to each of the cities of

Speaker: NA
Text: Plymouth and Portsmouth for post-war recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction, while Britain, through its Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific High Commission, instructed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Banaban adviser, who was paid by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Banabans, not to advise them on the sale of the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining three-fifths of their phosphate land.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only in 1965 did they realise they had been

Speaker: NA
Text: cheated, and they expelled the British colonial

Speaker: NA
Text: service officer appointed to Rabi, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Banaban adviser. In 1967 they sent

Speaker: NA
Text: a mission to London, where the Minister asked

Speaker: NA
Text: them to sign a minute accepting 80,000 as an ex

Speaker: NA
Text: gratia payment in consideration of the effects of

Speaker: NA
Text: phosphate mining since 1900. At long last they

Speaker: NA
Text: refused on legal advice. In 1975 their case went

Speaker: NA
Text: to court. They won against the BPC but not

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Crown. The judge in his judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: described the behaviour of colonial government

Speaker: NA
Text: as outrageous and bullying. Nonetheless the

Speaker: NA
Text: damages awarded were a trifling 9,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total revenue from Banaban phosphates

Speaker: NA
Text: which will have been used by the end of mining

Speaker: NA
Text: this year to meet Britain's obligations in the Gil-

Speaker: NA
Text: bert Islands colony is 62m and the subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years to Australian and New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers a further  17.5m. The Banabans have

Speaker: NA
Text: been offered $A10m by the British Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and $AI.25m by the British Phosphate Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission provided they take no more legal action,

Speaker: NA
Text: but this has been made conditional on the money

Speaker: NA
Text: being tied up in a trust fund, which they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want. But Britain may waive this condition. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would leave only the moral and political issues to

Speaker: NA
Text: be resolved. At present, of course, Britain is still

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing with the process that it has adopted of

Speaker: NA
Text: forcing the Banabans to accept becoming part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the newly independent Republic of Kiribati,

Speaker: NA
Text: which covers the Gilbert and Ellice Islands. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the Banabans will for sometimebe in the unique

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of having two homelands 1,400 miles

Speaker: NA
Text: apart-Banab a and Rabi-th e course which

Speaker: NA
Text: would recognise the uniqueness of their case

Speaker: NA
Text: would be to allow for the separation of Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: Island from the Gilbert group, leaving the

Speaker: NA
Text: Banabans to negotiate a form of association with

Speaker: NA
Text: Fiji, covering the relationships of the two islands.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems sensible that they should have the same

Speaker: NA
Text: defence force and an external affairs minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: Suva.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been the primary beneficiary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the exploitation of the Banabans. I think it is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the most disgraceful, most horrifying stories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and New Zealand have benefited far

Speaker: NA
Text: more than Great Britain from the exploitation,

Speaker: NA
Text: despoliation and destruction of these islands. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that we have a strong moral imperative

Speaker: NA
Text: to do something and to make sure that the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation is handed over and that the compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is more generous.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr MILLAR -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr KEVIN CAIRNS
Text: Lilley) (10.46)-My re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks are related to certain events in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. They are related to the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances surrounding the next Senate election for

Speaker: NA
Text: that State. Not since 1943 has the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party won the Senate in Queensland. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has quite clearly been the most successful State in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for the Liberal and Country parties or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal and the National Country parties in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate. I will relate two instances. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: double dissolutions of 1974 and 1975 six out of

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 coalition senators were returned for

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. It is known that the parties

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved similar success at the double dissol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ution in 1951. Therefore, the parties have been

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificently successful. They have had

Speaker: NA
Text: unparalleled success. The joint team has enjoyed

Speaker: NA
Text: that success. The plain fact is that the success has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been emulated by any other State. Why,

Speaker: NA
Text: then, should a change be proposed? Various

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons have been given. Let me have at least the

Speaker: NA
Text: right or the freedom to put a point of view other

Speaker: NA
Text: than that which is generally put.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why should I show concern? Three issues

Speaker: NA
Text: have been indicated as being the negotiating

Speaker: NA
Text: points for the proposal for a joint Senate team in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. I say how false it is and what non-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense it is to propose these three issues. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: three issues that occur at a State level. What

Speaker: NA
Text: party in Australia would be induced to take

Speaker: NA
Text: action at a federal level for a trinity of State

Speaker: NA
Text: issues. Let me recite them to the House quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The three State issues are: In Queensland there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no public accounts committee, there are certain

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to redistributions and certain pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals to Acts concerning street marches. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore it is proposed that action should be taken at

Speaker: NA
Text: a federal level in terms of a joint Senate team.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not one vote in the Federal Parliament can

Speaker: NA
Text: influence these issues. Were a thousand senators

Speaker: NA
Text: or members to be elected to this Parliament they

Speaker: NA
Text: could have no influence whatsoever. As a Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral member in this place, let me say that that

Speaker: NA
Text: process and that argument have to be total non-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. I do not use any stronger word. I am aware

Speaker: NA
Text: when I say this that Federal endorsements in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own State have been held up. Nevertheless what

Speaker: NA
Text: must be said must be said because the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: have been touted in the public domain. Honesty

Speaker: NA
Text: demands that it be said. I also share the concern

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) at

Speaker: NA
Text: the consequences of actions proposed with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect to Senate elections. Prairie fires-lik e

Speaker: NA
Text: erysipelas-ar e not readily contained; nor will I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that such disputes will be contained

Speaker: NA
Text: within State boundaries given the strong per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonalities involved. Some claim, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: that recent by-elections in Queensland give the

Speaker: NA
Text: green light for any action whatsoever. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Redcliffe by-election, on any serious analysis,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly does not. I cannot share the exultation

Speaker: NA
Text: that has obviously engulfed others with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to those events.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very great honour to be given the

Speaker: NA
Text: ority to be a public representative. That honour

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be frittered away. One's aim ultimamy

Speaker: NA
Text: tely has to be to serve the common good. To

Speaker: NA
Text: so one needs colleagues and partners, and one

Speaker: NA
Text: needs continuing colleagues and partners. One

Speaker: NA
Text: must remember above all that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is the alternative government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: our competitor and it is the organisation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: poised best to benefit from unnecessary conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: To turn away from that knowledge could be

Speaker: NA
Text: astrous and, I believe, could be foolish beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the wildest fear.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: Grayndler) (10.50)-On

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday afternoon the eyes of eastern Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be on one of the local institutions in my

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. On Saturday afternoon the Canterburyclub

Speaker: NA
Text: Bankstown Rugby League Club will be facing

Speaker: NA
Text: the first grand final it will be successful in since Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1949. A number of members of Parliament may

Speaker: NA
Text: think that that is a rather mundane thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak about in the adjournment debate, but Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Canterbury-Bankstown Club is a club that, of all

Speaker: NA
Text: football clubs including those in other States of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, is a local club. It is a club that has

Speaker: NA
Text: spent much time developing local juniors and

Speaker: NA
Text: plays district football at its best. Maybe some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable members from Queensland only

Speaker: NA
Text: want to talk about Rugby Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)- of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! There are too many members on my right

Speaker: NA
Text: offside.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: Canterbury-Bankstow n posal

Speaker: NA
Text: last won the grand final in 1942. Since then that

Speaker: NA
Text: club has come very close to winning it again

Speaker: NA
Text: 1967 and will defeat St George on Saturday. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to see that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for St George ( Mr Neil) has come into the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber to listen to this debate. There are a few

Speaker: NA
Text: political lessons in this for him on Saturday too.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a few lessons I hope that he will ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate in it. The point is that Canterbury-

Speaker: NA
Text: Bankstown has been a club that has always given

Speaker: NA
Text: of its time and effort to the people of the area

Speaker: NA
Text: from which they get their members. My prede-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessor Frank Stewart and his brother Kevin were

Speaker: NA
Text: both patrons of the club. Kevin Ryan, arguably

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the best football players in Australia's his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory, was captain-coach of the club. I might say

Speaker: NA
Text: he was also a very realistic fellow in that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: also one of the prominent Labor parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarians in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: The club has always adopted an attitude of

Speaker: NA
Text: helping the locals. When the team wins on

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday it will be a victory for the battlers. Need

Speaker: NA
Text: authI say that at this time when the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: crushing the battlers it is nice to see a team from

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate do its bit for the working people of

Speaker: NA
Text: do Australia. Canterbury-Bankstown has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: club which has always provided bursaries for its

Speaker: NA
Text: local players. In fact, George Peponis is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the great representatives of that club and a man

Speaker: NA
Text: is who has been nurtured by the club and has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: on to do well as a doctor. In fact, he is a man who

Speaker: NA
Text: is an excellent representative of the area, very

Speaker: NA
Text: dismuch a man of Canterbury-Bankstown and very

Speaker: NA
Text: much a man of Grayndler. I think it would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: miss of me if I did not stand here in this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment this evening and offer that team my best

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes and, I hope, the best wishes of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: elecment so that it will go on to bring glory to the

Speaker: NA
Text: and, might I say, glory to the working

Speaker: NA
Text: people, the battlers of Sydney and New South

Speaker: Mr COTTER
Text: Kalgoorlie) (10.54)- I rise to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night to make a personal appeal to Liberal and

Speaker: NA
Text: parties in Queensland. I do this as a rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentative of another State. I appeal to the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party to reconsider the situation in which it

Speaker: NA
Text: might run separate Senate tickets in that State. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have strong feelings on this matter and I recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nise that there are shortcomings in both parties. I

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that we will not see all matters in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same light all of the time. I am aware of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: frustrations which are felt by the Liberals in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. I recognise the political ambitions

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I am aware that certain de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions were made at the last State conference of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party some time ago. But the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: to run separate tickets in Queensland is

Speaker: NA
Text: political suicide. This question is bigger than the

Speaker: NA
Text: in Senate candidates concerned, bigger than the

Speaker: NA
Text: frustrations and ambitions of some people, and

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger than the State of Queensland and the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party. The action will place at real risk the

Speaker: NA
Text: solidarity of the non-Labor vote in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite the assurances of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Anthony) it will place unnatural

Speaker: NA
Text: and unnecesary stresses on the coalition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: great free enterprise forces of this nation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: great free enterprise governments that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: the bulwark of development and progress have

Speaker: NA
Text: set this great country apart in the eyes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. Under the coalition Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has emerged a a world leader. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: respected in the Western world. We have proved

Speaker: NA
Text: we can control inflation against world trends and

Speaker: NA
Text: can continue to develop. We have a strong econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy and are looked on as a stable and honest

Speaker: NA
Text: government. This has not happened by accident.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been brought about by careful co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation between people with a common goal.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Liberals of Queensland are dissatisfied

Speaker: NA
Text: with the National Party Government there- I

Speaker: NA
Text: make no comment on that-the y should turn

Speaker: NA
Text: their attention to winning State seats in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. If they are successful they can look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the coalition Government in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appeal to the Queensland President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, whom I have known and

Speaker: NA
Text: respected for some years, to reconsider the situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation and to move cautiously on the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: Senatetickets.I am sure that, given good faith, a

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory compromise can be worked out. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the intention to run separate Senateticketsin

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland is carried through, the repercussions

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be quarantined in Queensland. The

Speaker: NA
Text: effects will flow on to all States of this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: could be felt by the coalition Government here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. We should not forget the terrible

Speaker: NA
Text: effect that the Whitlam Labor Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: on this country in its three years of dark govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We must not forget that, following the

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide Conference of the Labor Party, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: now clear that the Labor Party's policies have

Speaker: NA
Text: not changed. They are more socialist than ever.

Speaker: NA
Text: They may be dressed up differently, but they are

Speaker: NA
Text: just as socialist as ever.

Speaker: NA
Text: To keep a strong, honest government in Cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: berra means maintaining a strong coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra, with a strong sense of friendship and

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operation. I ask the Queensland Liberals and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland National Party to lift their sights

Speaker: NA
Text: to national horizons. There are methods of gaindo

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the ideals and goals which they are setting

Speaker: NA
Text: out to achieve. But they will not be achieved by

Speaker: NA
Text: the parties running separate Senate tickets.

Speaker: NA
Text: again appeal to those people in that State to

Speaker: NA
Text: think again on the course on which they are

Speaker: NA
Text: directed at present; to move with extreme cau-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; and to keep in mind at alltimesthe great

Speaker: NA
Text: goal of this nation, Australia, and the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we will go under an honest coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Text: Corio) (10.57)-Having

Speaker: NA
Text: heard what the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie ( Mr Cotter) and the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lilley ( Mr Kevin Cairns) said, 1

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is only fair to say to this House that their

Speaker: NA
Text: pleas for the Liberal Party of Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, for instance, to give up its expec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tations of governing that State is a noble gesture

Speaker: NA
Text: made by honourable members who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: required to live in a State governed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party. The facts of the situation are

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if the Liberal Party does not contest seats

Speaker: NA
Text: held by the National Party in Queensland it can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not change the relationship of the parties within

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition Government of that State so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the partner with the majority. If that is the situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation which honourable members opposite who

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken in this adjournment debate are sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gesting should apply, one wonders why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party should bother even to run in an

Speaker: NA
Text: election in that State. I would have thought that a

Speaker: NA
Text: party which once had self-respect and had

Speaker: NA
Text: shown at least a recovery of some of that self-

Speaker: NA
Text: respect in that State would object to being a

Speaker: NA
Text: party to some of the actions which currently are

Speaker: NA
Text: being taken in Queensland. It is not unreason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to suggest in this Parliament that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong case for holding an inquiry into whether

Speaker: NA
Text: people in that State have even basic civil rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people have more rights than others.

Speaker: NA
Text: and People who live in Queensland are Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people I happen to be talking about are a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility of this Parliament. They are people

Speaker: NA
Text: who, on the basis of race, are denied the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by other people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The facts are that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie said in this House that the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland should not have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: elect a government other than one under the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Premier; that the Liberal Party should

Speaker: NA
Text: accept a political responsibility to seek to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: in come the majority party in a coalition govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, in line with the support it has in that State;

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the Liberal Party should forgo the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to provide the Premier of that State. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: not think that the Liberal Party would ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equately govern that State either, but it would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be preferable to what we have at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: I If people in Queensland are denied the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to support the Liberal Party, we will see

Speaker: NA
Text: political opportunists, for base political reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: denying people their civil rights.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr M i l l a r )-

Text: Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

Text: The House stands adjourned until 2.15 p.m. on

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuesday next.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dobie asked the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Can he state what general elections have taken place

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Republic of Sierra Leone

Speaker: NA
Text: independent country within the Commonwealth of Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, what percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: there a genuine choice of candidates from differing political

Speaker: NA
Text: parties at each election.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) When did Australia establish diplomatic relations with

Speaker: NA
Text: that country.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) General elections were held in the Republic of Sierra

Speaker: NA
Text: Leone in 1973 and 1977.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Sierra Leone People's Party candidates boycotted

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1973 elections and the House of Representatives became

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually a one-party House dominated by the All People's

Speaker: NA
Text: Congress. The other opposition party, the United Demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic Party, remained banned. At the 1977 elections

Speaker: NA
Text: People's Congress again predominated but with the Sierra

Speaker: NA
Text: Leone People's Party gaining a number of scats.

Speaker: NA
Text: No statistics or voting

Speaker: NA
Text: 1973 and 1977 elections.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Australia has not established diplomatic relations with

Speaker: NA
Text: Sierra Leone. However, Sierra Leone is a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth.

Text: Aborigines in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4347)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Everingham asked the Minister represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 21 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4293) (1) Have negotiations been held between the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Aboriginal Affairs and the Queensland Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garding the request of the Yarrabah community and others

Speaker: NA
Text: for freedom from the administration of Queensland which

Speaker: NA
Text: they regard as paternalistic, bureaucratic and discriminatory,

Speaker: NA
Text: and effective self-management, freedom of choice and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility only to their members, as envisaged in the Abor-

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communities Self-management) Act 1978.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, have Aborigines been excluded from these

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) When will the Government enforce the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Will the Government respond to the request of the citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens of Aurukun and Mornington Shires for termination of

Speaker: NA
Text: the local government originally agreed to by them under

Speaker: NA
Text: duress for a 6 months' trial period by amending the Act to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to reserves existing as at 31 March 1978, and enforcing

Speaker: NA
Text: the law as promised.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e Minister for Aboriginal Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided the following answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4295) honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: ( I ), (2) and (3) I have had talks with the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Premier, Dr Edwards, and the Minister for Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Yarrabah Council for self-management and land tenure. A

Speaker: NA
Text: joint meeting was arranged with the Council at Yarrabah for

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 June but the Queensland Government decided that its

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers should not attend. I did meet with the Council at

Speaker: NA
Text: Yarrabah on that date. It is intended to arrange further talks

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments

Speaker: NA
Text: before decisions are made on a response to the Yarrabah

Speaker: NA
Text: Council's request. I shall continue to keep the Council

Speaker: NA
Text: informed about progress of talks.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) I am not aware of any such request from the Aurukun

Speaker: NA
Text: or Mornington Shires.
