Text: Diplomatic Courier Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many persons are in the diplomatic courier

Speaker: NA
Text: service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many missions have a courier on their staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What is the cost ofthe service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What are the duties of couriers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What classes of documents are sent by courier.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) What is an example of an average work pattern for a

Speaker: NA
Text: courier (e.g. number and length ofjourneys undertaken each

Speaker: NA
Text: month).

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Eight (8) officers are employed full time as diplomatic

Speaker: NA
Text: couriers shortly to be increased to nine (9).

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) None. Staff from certain overseas missions are rostered

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake connecting services.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Estimated cost for 1979-80 is $1,391,000 (excluding

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries).

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The protection at all times and safe delivery to an

Speaker: NA
Text: authorised recipient of the classified matter under their

Speaker: NA
Text: control.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) All classified government material.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) The normal roster for a courier covers a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: twenty-eight (28) weeks during which ume he would under-

Speaker: NA
Text: take twenty four (24) journeys varying between two (2) days

Speaker: NA
Text: and sixteen (16) days.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Th e Minister for Social Security has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the following answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Miss E. Lucas.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Miss Lucas is a permanent member of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Public Service. She was appointed to the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: Director on 22 June 1978. This is a Class 10 position in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Public Service, for which the salary range is

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) By the normal public service selecdon and promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Yes: in the Commonwealth Gazette.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Miss Lucas is an occupational therapist by profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4380) At the time of her appointment, she was engaged in special

Speaker: NA
Text: projects in the Central Office of the Depanment of Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, having previously been Senior Occupational Thera-

Speaker: NA
Text: pist in the NSW branch of that Depanment. She has assisted

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Bailey enquiries on Health/Welfare co-ordination

Speaker: NA
Text: and held various other professional positions in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: thirteen years employment in the Commonwealth Public-

Speaker: NA
Text: Service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Miss Lucas acted as escort for a team of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: children who travelled to Mexico between 24 April 1979 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 May 1979; cf Answer to Question No. 4383. She has not

Speaker: NA
Text: made any other official visits overseas.

Text: 1979: sources, upon notice, on 22 August 1979:

Text: (1) How many tourist bodies or companies made appli-

Text: cation for Export Market Development Grants during

Text: (2) What is the estimated cost to the Commonwealth of

Text: these grants.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: number of tourist industry applications for 1978-79.

Speaker: NA
Text: individual member states in that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: ful estimation of either the total number of claimants or the

Speaker: NA
Text: total cost of their claims to the Commonwealth.

Text: Visit the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Were visas to visit the United States refused to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Noble and Ms Cilia Prior by the United States Consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate in Sydney, after Ms Prior was promised on 14 May 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: that a visa would be available at 12.30 p.m. on 16 May.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is he able to say whether this reversal of a

Speaker: NA
Text: due to advice from Australian Government sources; i f so,

Speaker: NA
Text: was any political discrimination exercised and, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: was (a) the Australian Government a party to restriction of

Speaker: NA
Text: movement to representatives of minorities seeking inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national support for removal of discrimination or for com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation for dispossession of indigenes by later settlers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and (b) an Aboriginal subject to refusal of a visa

Speaker: NA
Text: on account of unsubstantiated political objections raised by a

Speaker: NA
Text: State Government, but not applied in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: non-Aborigines.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Neither I nor my Department had any knowledge of any

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining visas to enter the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only information on this matter which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed by inquiries by my Department is contained in a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port in the NQ Message Stick of July 1979. We have no in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation to suggest that speculations made in that report

Speaker: NA
Text: are correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: The matter of visa issue for entry to United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America is entirely a matter for the US authorities and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government is unable to comment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Everingham asked the Minister represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 22 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the book A

Speaker: NA
Text: Black Reality: Aboriginal Camps and Housing in Remote

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, which has a dozen contributors and which was

Speaker: NA
Text: edited by Dr Michael Heppell, who was recently dismissed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government from the Aboriginal Housing Panel.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, does the book argue that Government planners

Speaker: NA
Text: are arrogant and that the Prime Minister has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratisation in providing Aboriginal housing by mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Department of Housing and Construction respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for all remote Aboriginal housing programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Does the book also state that increased drunkenness

Speaker: NA
Text: and violence has resulted from the construction of $40,000

Speaker: NA
Text: houses in remote Arnhem Land and that there is a better ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptance of free palm thatched houses than of $45,000 ones

Speaker: NA
Text: being constructed in North Queensland; if so, is there evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence to support these statements.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Is current expenditure inadequate and are more famil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies being inadequately housed

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations of every Government investigation into Ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: original housing and all related problems and in breach of

Speaker: NA
Text: election undertakings of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Does the book concur with these investigations and

Speaker: NA
Text: policy in insisting that constant and sympathetic contact with

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines is required to prevent squandering of funds on

Speaker: NA
Text: the European-devised programs now entrusted to officials

Speaker: NA
Text: with little opportunity to achieve such contact: if so, is any

Speaker: NA
Text: action being taken to correct the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4454)

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e Minister for Aboriginal Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided the following answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) 1 have seen the book A Black Reality: Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Camps and Housing in Remote Australia edited by Dr M.

Speaker: NA
Text: Heppell andrecentlypublished by the Australian Institute of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Studies. The Government did not dismiss Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: decision was Heppell from the Aboriginal Housing Panel.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) I note that Dr H. C. Coombs in a Foreword to the book

Speaker: NA
Text: comments on the disappointing results of Government hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing policies for Aboriginals over the years and, acknowledg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that he is 'one who must bear some responsibility for this

Speaker: NA
Text: failure' refers to 'our haste (and our arrogance)' in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the housing of Aboriginals. I have not found any reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister, or to 'increased bureaucratisation' by

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Heppell nor does he indicate that the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing and Construction has been made 'responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: all remote Aboriginal housing problems'. He does indicate at

Speaker: NA
Text: page 42 that the Government requires 'the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction to act, wherever practicable, as consultant to

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Housing Associations'.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) 1 have found no statement that 'increased drunkenness

Speaker: NA
Text: and violence has resulted from the construction of $40,000

Speaker: NA
Text: houses in remote Arnhem Land', in either of the two papers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the book which deal with communities in Arnhem Land.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a paper on housing at Mitchell River and Edward River in

Speaker: NA
Text: North Queensland, Dr Taylor sets out the evidence for his

Speaker: NA
Text: view that 'the thatched houses and shanties of the earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: days' were closer to being entities 'firmly linked to peoples'

Speaker: NA
Text: needs, abilities, ambitions and expressive drives' than 'the

Speaker: NA
Text: present day prefabricated housing'.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) and (5) Expenditure to date on Aboriginal housing by

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments throughout Australia has been inadequate to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the needs and both Commonwealth and State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments haverecognisedthis. The greatly increased provision

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4458) for Aboriginal housing in the 1979-80 Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget should enable a substantial reduction to be made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the housing shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The papers in this book provide a useful reminder ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: complexity of the problems Aboriginal communities and

Speaker: NA
Text: governments face in improving housing conditions in the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote areas where tradition-oriented Aboriginals live and

Speaker: NA
Text: they deserve serious study by all concerned.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1977. I do not know what stage ofthe criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings against Mr Gale had then been reached.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Government has granted the Foundation the sum

Speaker: NA
Text: of $5,500.00 in each orthefinancialyears 1975-76, 1976-77,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1977-78 and 1978-79. The amount of the grant proposed for

Text: Aboriginal Self-management

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Everingham asked the Minister represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 28 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Have (a) Yarrabah, (b) The Gorge, (c) Weipa and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) Kowanyama Queensland Aboriginal communities ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plied to the Federal Government for self-management under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serves and Communities Self-management) Act 1978.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, what stage of

Speaker: NA
Text: at 30 July 1979 between the 2 Governments in each of the 4

Speaker: NA
Text: cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) If any of the negotiations have been delayed, what is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reason.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e Minister for Aboriginal Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided the following answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yarrabah Council requested to be declared under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serves and Communities Self-management) Act 1978 and

Speaker: NA
Text: residents of both the Mossman Gorge and Kowanyama

Speaker: NA
Text: communities submitted petitions last year. A request has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been received from the Weipa community.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) and (3) Discussions have been initiated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Government on the issues of self-management

Speaker: NA
Text: and secure land tenure for reserve communities in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. (See my reply to Question No. 4347.)

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4486)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Willis asked the Minister for Defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 29 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many officials in his Depanment are working full

Speaker: NA
Text: ume on any aspect of disarmament.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is his Depanment contributing financially to the study

Speaker: NA
Text: of any aspect of disarmament by persons in any other organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: isation; if so, which are the organisations and what sum is

Speaker: NA
Text: being contributed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Killen-Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: to the member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Department adopts a multi-disciplinary approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to this subject, drawing as necessary upon officers with

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities in military, scientific, legal and policy areas

Speaker: NA
Text: the Depanment. At the present ume a scientist and an

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army officer from the Depanment are working full ume as

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian delegation to the meeting of a

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations conference on the use of certain conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional weapons in Geneva.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Depanment endows a Research Fellowship at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategic and Defence Study Centre, Australian National

Speaker: NA
Text: University, at a cost of some $30,000 per annum. Aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: disarmament, along with many other defence related mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, may be studied under this Fellowship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: Will he consult with appropriate Australian Ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government of Malta to see if Australia could pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide large numbers of appropriate trees for planting in Malta

Speaker: NA
Text: as a tangible gesture of goodwill which could be of great

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to that largely treeless island.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The suggestion that, as a gesture of goodwill, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: might consider providing appropriate trees for planting in

Speaker: NA
Text: Malta is an interesting one and warrants further examin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. I have noted the honourable member's interest in this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject and shall keep him informed of any developments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr James asked the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice, on 29 August 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: Trees for Malta (1) Is it a fact, as reported in Newsweek of 23 July 1979,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the United States of America has cut off aid to Pakistan.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4527)

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If the United States of America was satisfied with in-

Speaker: NA
Text: telligence reports that the Pakistanis are developing a nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear weapon and the resultant decision was the complete

Speaker: NA
Text: abandonment of aid, will Australia take similar action; if

Speaker: NA
Text: not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) As a result of a legislative requirement, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States announced on 6 April that it was moving to suspend

Speaker: NA
Text: its $US40m annual development aid program to Pakistan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United States has not suspended food aid and other

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) I outlined, in response to a question in the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives on 23 August, the Government's concern

Speaker: NA
Text: about the possibility of Pakistan's acquiring a nuclear ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plosive capability. This concern has been made known to

Speaker: NA
Text: Pakistan. The Government is also in close and continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: Aid to Pakistan contact with a number of concerned governments and has

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4543) made its views known to a wide cross-section of states. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has not considered the suspension of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's aid to Pakistan, which is mainly in the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: food aid and project aid in agriculture.
